'''James William Anderson III''' (born November 1, 1937), known professionally as '''Bill Anderson''', is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, and television host. His soft-spoken singing voice was given the nickname "Whispering Bill" by music critics and writers.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> As a songwriter, his compositions have been covered by various music artists since the late 1950s, including [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]] and [[George Strait]].

Anderson was raised in [[Decatur, Georgia]], and began composing songs while in high school. While enrolled in college, he wrote the song "[[City Lights (Ray Price song)|City Lights]]", which later became a major hit for Ray Price in 1958. His songwriting led to his first recording contract with [[Decca Records]] the same year. Anderson began having major hits shortly thereafter. In 1963, he had released his most successful single in his recording career, "[[Still (Bill Anderson song)|Still]]". The song became a major country pop [[crossover music|crossover]] hit and was followed by a series of top ten hits. These songs included "[[I Love You Drops (song)|I Love You Drops]]", "[[I Get the Fever]]" and  "[[Wild Week-End]]". His songs were being notably recorded by other artists. In 1964, [[Connie Smith]] had her first major hit with his composition "[[Once a Day]]". In 1971, [[Cal Smith]] had a number one single with Anderson's "[[The Lord Knows I'm Drinking]]".

In the 1970s, Anderson continued having major hits as a recording artist as well. Songs including "[[Love Is a Sometimes Thing]]", "[[All the Lonely Women in the World]]" and "[[World of Make Believe]]" became major hits. As the decade progressed his style moved towards the polished [[countrypolitan]] genre of country music, with songs such as "[[I Can't Wait Any Longer]]". He was dropped from his record label in the early 1980s and began a brief career in television which included hosting the game shows ''[[The Better Sex]]'' and ''[[Fandango (game show)|Fandango]].'' Anderson began writing songs again in the early 1990s for the next generation of country performers. Collaborating with other writers, he wrote material that went on to become hits for [[Vince Gill]], [[George Strait]], [[Kenny Chesney]], and [[Steve Wariner]] in the next two decades.

Anderson also continued recording into the 1990s. In 1998, he released his first major label album in over a decade, entitled ''[[Fine Wine (Bill Anderson album)|Fine Wine]].'' He continued releasing music through his own TWI record label. This included projects of gospel and bluegrass material. His most recent studio album was released in 2020. In his career as both a writer and performer, he has received awards from the [[Academy of Country Music]], [[Country Music Association]], [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] and the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]].

==Early life==
Anderson was born James William Anderson III to Elizabeth and James William Anderson Jr. in [[Columbia, South Carolina]]. He was the oldest of two children. His sister, Elizabeth Anderson, was born two years after. Anderson's father was an [[insurance broker|insurance agent]] while his mother was a homemaker. He spent his early childhood with his family in Columbia.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=9}} The family moved to his grandparents' home in [[Griffin, Georgia]], while Anderson was in the third grade. Shortly afterward, the family relocated into their own home in [[Decatur, Georgia]], where he spent the remainder of his childhood.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=15–16}} In Decatur, his father opened his own insurance agency firm, which he continued to own until his retirement. In his 2016 autobiography, Anderson described his childhood as "average", recalling that he "never went to bed hungry" even though the family did not have many material possessions.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=16–17}} 
[[File:UGASLC.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Anderson briefly attended the [[University of Georgia]] in the late 1950s, where he studied journalism.]]

In school, Anderson was active in [[4-H]] organizations and played both baseball and football.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=16}} However, he was most interested in music, having been inspired by his grandparents who played instruments.<ref name="PBS">{{cite web |last1=Burns |first1=Ken |title=Country Music: Bill Anderson Biography |url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/bill-anderson-biography |website=[[PBS]] |access-date=August 6, 2020}}</ref> His interest grew further after watching country musicians perform on a radio station, located directly above his father's insurance company.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=17–19}} Anderson soon saved enough money to purchase his own guitar. At age ten, he wrote his first song called "Carry Me Home Texas".<ref name="PBS"/>

In high school, Anderson and his friends formed their own band and won a school talent contest. The band began performing around the local area, eventually performing on local radio as "The Avondale Playboys".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=19–22}} Anderson's strong interest in baseball continued through high school as well. He became his high school team's pitcher and was scouted to go to the [[Chicago Cubs]] training camp. However, Anderson declined the offer after realizing that his family would be upset if he did not attend college.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=22–23}} Upon graduating high school, he enrolled at the [[University of Georgia]] and majored in [[journalism]].<ref name="PBS"/>

Anderson had dabbled with journalism before enrolling in university. While still in high school, he wrote for his school's newspaper and also obtained a job covering sports events for ''[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]].''{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=27}} In his freshman year, he pledged the [[Kappa Sigma Fraternity]].{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=28}} He and several students formed a country band called the "Classic City Playboys" and began playing local events. He also became interested in radio station work after a DJ friend introduced him to some of the controls. "I thought I was Superman. I knew that night I had to get a job as a disc jockey", he recalled.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=32}}

Anderson graduated from college in 1959.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Anderson papers and records |url=https://sclfind.libs.uga.edu/sclfind/view?docId=ead/ms3941.xml |website=[[University of Georgia]] |access-date=24 April 2022}}</ref> During his first summer out of college, he got a job working as a rock and roll DJ at [[WGAU]] in [[Athens, Georgia]]. However, he was fired after playing country records over the air and was then hired at [[WJJC]] in [[Commerce, Georgia]]. Anderson began songwriting again after obtaining the new position. In Commerce, Anderson wrote the song "[[City Lights (Ray Price song)|City Lights]]". The song ultimately brought him to Nashville where both his songwriting and recording career began.<ref name="PBS"/>

==Recording career==
===1958–1962: Early success===
Anderson's own recording career began in 1957 after releasing two singles for the independent label, TNT. Both songs (including his own version of "City Lights") attracted little attention.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=46–47}} However, the success brought by Ray Price's version of "City Lights" led Anderson to frequent [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. In the city, he brought compositions for artists and producers to record. [[Owen Bradley]] of [[Decca Records]] was impressed by Anderson's writing and decided to sign him as a recording artist to the label. Anderson officially signed with Decca in the summer of 1958.<ref name="PBS"/> His early Decca singles were entirely self-composed. Anderson's first Decca released was issued in December 1958 called "[[That's What It's Like to Be Lonesome]]".<ref name="whitburn">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> The song became a major hit the following year when it climbed to the number 12 position on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country and Western Sides]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="That's What It's Like to Be Lonesome" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> He followed this in 1959 with the top 20 hits "[[Ninety-Nine (song)|Ninety Nine]]" and "[[Dead or Alive (Bill Anderson song)|Dead or Alive]]".<ref name="whitburn"/>

[[File:Bill Anderson 1970.JPG|thumb|right|180px|A publicity image of Anderson from his time at Decca Records]]
In 1960, "[[The Tip of My Fingers]]" became his first top ten hit on the country chart, reaching number seven in August 1960.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="The Tip of My Fingers" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> The song was later recorded and made hits individually by [[Eddy Arnold]], [[Roy Clark]], [[Jean Shepard]] and [[Steve Wariner]].{{sfn|Trott, Walt|2012|p=12}} In 1961, the single "[[Po' Folks (Bill Anderson song)|Po' Folks]]" reached number nine on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Po' Folks" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> The success of "Po' Folks" led Anderson to receive an invitation to join the [[Grand Ole Opry]] cast. Anderson accepted and joined the program the same year.{{sfn|Trott, Walt|2012|p=12}} This was followed by his first number-one hit, "[[Mama Sang a Song]]".<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Mama Sang a Song" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> It was also his first single to chart on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], reaching number 89.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Mama Sang a Song" chart history (Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> Although successful, Anderson's early singles were not initially included on studio album releases.<ref name="whitburn"/> Instead, Decca issued his early hits on the 1962 compilation ''[[Bill Anderson Sings Country Heart Songs]].''<ref name="Heart Songs Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Bill Anderson Sings Country Heart Songs'' (Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Decca Records]] |date=January 1962 |id=Dl-4192}}</ref>

===1963–1976: "Still" and further career success===
By 1963, Anderson's recording career was expanding further. He was frequently touring and making public appearances to promote his music. Anderson was inspired to write his 1963 composition, "[[Still (Bill Anderson song)|Still]]", after encountering an ex-girlfriend while promoting a song. The same night, he wrote the lyrics to the track on an [[Underwood Typewriter Company|Underwood typewriter]] at three o'clock in the morning.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=80}} "Still" became the biggest single of his recording career.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> In April 1963, it reached number one on the ''Billboard'' country and western songs chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Still" chart history (Country Songs) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> It also became his second single to reach the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, but was his first (and only) successful crossover hit there, reaching number eight in June 1963.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Still" chart history (Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> The track was also his first single to become a hit on the ''Billboard'' [[Adult contemporary (chart)|easy listening chart]], reaching number three that June.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Still" chart history (AC) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/asi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> The song's success led to the 1963 release of Anderson's [[Still (Bill Anderson album)|debut studio album of the same name]].<ref name="Still Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Still'' (Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Decca Records]] |date=June 17, 1963 |id=MCAC-20536}}</ref> The LP reached number ten on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums|country albums]] chart in January 1964<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Still'' chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> and the top 40 of the [[Billboard 200]] in late 1963.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Still'' chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref>

{{listen|filename=Bill Anderson--Still--Audio 1963.ogg |title="Still" (1963)|description=Anderson's country-pop crossover hit from 1963 that signified his style as a recording artist and performer|format=[[Ogg]]||pos=right}}
The success of "Still" further elevated Anderson's recording career. This included making national television appearances on shows such as ''[[American Bandstand]],'' where he performed his follow-up crossover hit "[[8×10 (song)|8×10]]". He won awards from several major music publications including ''Billboard,'' ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' and ''[[Record World|Music Reporter]].''{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=84}} He scheduled more concert engagements and made as much as $500 per gig.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=114}} His success led Decca to record and release studio albums with more frequency. These albums were also successful. His second studio LP, ''[[Bill Anderson Sings]]'' (1964), reached the top ten of the country albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Bill Anderson Sings'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> His [[I Love You Drops|1966 studio release]] reached number one on the same chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''I Love You Drops'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> Album releases were fueled by further hit singles, including "[[Bright Lights and Country Music (song)|Bright Lights and Country Music]]", "[[Five Little Fingers]]" and "[[Three A.M.]]"<ref name="whitburn"/> Music writers took notice of Anderson's music success as well. ''Billboard'' magazine called his 1964 album, ''[[Showcase (Bill Anderson album)|Showcase]],'' "a powerful set of performances".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Special Merit Picks |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=December 5, 1964 |volume=76 |issue=49 |page=24}}</ref> Kurt Wolff of the book ''Country Music: The Rough Guide'' credited his success to a "fairly safe and suburban" musical style.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}}

[[File:Bill Anderson - Where Have All Our Heroes Gone, 1970.png|thumb|left|160px|A promotional single for Anderson in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]],'' 1970]]
His chart hits continued through the 1960s and many of these songs were self-composed. His 1966 release, "[[I Love You Drops (song)|I Love You Drops]]", was inspired by the [[Chuck Berry]] hit "[[Memphis, Tennessee (song)|Memphis Tennessee]]".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=91}} His next self-written release also became his third number-one hit, titled "[[I Get the Fever]]".<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> He had further top ten hits with "[[Get While the Gettin's Good (song)|Get While the Gettin's Good]]" and "[[No One's Gonna Hurt You Anymore]]".<ref name="whitburn"/> During this time, Anderson formed his own touring band which he named "The Po' Boys" after his 1961 hit. The band frequently received credit on his studio albums and single releases.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=114–16}} He also started his own television program called ''The Bill Anderson Show,'' which was taped in Canada and Nashville.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=173–74}} In the mid 1960s, he began performing duets with country artist [[Jan Howard]], who was also on Decca Records. Believing they could be a successful recording partnership, the pair approached producer Owen Bradley with the idea of recording together. Bradley agreed and the duo released their first single in 1965.<ref name="Jan Howard">{{cite book |last=Howard |first=Jan |title=Sunshine and Shadow: My Story |date=1987 |publisher=Richardson & Steirman |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-319886-92-1 |url=https://archive.org/details/sunshineshadow00janh}}</ref> In 1968, the pair had their first major hit with the duet "[[For Loving You]]".<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> The song became a number-one hit on the ''Billboard'' country chart and led to several more successful collaborations.<ref name="whitburn"/>

Following several more hits, Anderson reached the number one position for a fifth time in May 1969 with "[[My Life (Throw It Away If I Want To)]]".<ref>{{cite magazine |title="My Life (Throw It Away If I Want To)" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> Both this, and the hit "[[But You Know I Love You]]", were included on his [[My Life/But You Know I Love You|1969 studio album]].<ref name="My Life Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''My Life/But You Know I Love You'' (Liner Notes & Album Information) |journal=[[Decca Records]] |date=June 1969 |id=75142}}</ref> He began diversifying his album releases during this period with the recording of a gospel LP, ''[[I Can Do Nothing Alone]]'', in 1967<ref name="I Can Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''I Can Do Nothing Alone'' (Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Decca Records]] |date=June 1967 |id=Dl-4886}}</ref> and a holiday LP, ''[[Christmas (Bill Anderson album)|Christmas]]'', in 1969.<ref name="Christmas Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Christmas'' (Liner Notes & Album Information) |journal=[[Decca Records]] |date=November 1969 |id=75161}}</ref> A greatest hits package, ''[[Bill Anderson's Greatest Hits]]'', was also issued and it reached number six on the country albums survey.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Bill Anderson's Greatest Hits'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> Anderson continued releasing regular country albums as well, outputting as much as three per year by the early 1970s. His country LP's often included a mix of original material and cover versions. On his 1971 release, ''[[Always Remember]],'' Greg Adams of [[AllMusic]] commented that it "confounds expectations" for delivering original vocal performances of songs first cut by [[Kris Kristofferson]] and [[Kenny Rogers]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Adams |first1=Greg |title=''Always Remember'': Bill Anderson: Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/always-remember-mw0000979544 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref> A series of uninterrupted top ten hits followed his early 1970s albums. During this time frame, he had hits with "[[Love Is a Sometimes Thing (song)|Love Is a Sometimes Thing]]", "[[Where Have All Our Heroes Gone (song)|Where Have All Our Heroes Gone]]", "[[If You Can Live with It (I Can Live Without It)]]" and "[[The Corner of My Life]]".<ref name="whitburn"/> In February 1974, he had his first number one hit in five years with "[[World of Make Believe]]".<ref>{{cite magazine |title="World of Make Believe" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 16, 2020}}</ref>

===1977–1989: Countrypolitan shift and new changes===
By 1977, Anderson experienced several changes in his recording career. His longtime duet partner, Jan Howard, left his record label and road show. According to Howard, it was difficult to keep up with the busy touring schedule.<ref name="Jan Howard"/> She was replaced by [[Mary Lou Turner]]. In 1976, the Turner-Anderson  pairing had a number one hit with the song, "[[Sometimes (Bill Anderson song)|Sometimes]]".<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> Anderson's longtime label was renamed to [[MCA Records]] during the same time frame.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Changes at the label continued when his longtime producer (Owen Bradley) was replaced by [[Buddy Killen]]. Anderson's first assignment with Killen was the 1977 studio release, ''[[Scorpio (Bill Anderson album)|Scorpio]].''<ref name="Scorpio Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Scorpio'' (Liner Notes & Album Information) |journal=[[MCA Records]] |date=April 1977 |id=2264}}</ref> With Killen, Anderson's musical sound shifted from Nashville Sound ballads towards uptempo [[Nashville Sound|Countrypolitan]] tunes.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/>{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} The new sound was reflected in his latest albums and singles. In 1977, Anderson had two major hits with the uptempo "[[Head to Toe (Bill Anderson song)|Head to Toe]]" and "[[Still the One]]".<ref name="whitburn"/> The following year, Anderson had a major hit with the [[Disco music|disco]]-flavored "[[I Can't Wait Any Longer]]". The song peaked at number four on the ''Billboard'' country singles chart<ref>{{cite magazine |title="I Can't Wait Any Longer" chart history (Country Songs) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref> and reached number 80 on the Hot 100.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="I Can't Wait Any Longer" chart history (Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref> Its corresponding studio effort, ''[[Love...& Other Sad Stories]],'' reached number 37 on the ''Billboard'' country albums list.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Love...& Other Sad Stories'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref>
{{listen|filename=Bill Anderson--I Can't Wait Any Longer--Audio 1978.ogg |title="I Can't Wait Any Longer" (1978)|description=Anderson's 1978 uptempo hit that exhibited a new musical shift towards [[Disco music|disco]]. It received mostly criticism from many music writers at the time.|format=[[Ogg]]||pos=right}}

Although successful at first, Anderson's late-1970s music received negative criticism from many writers. Author Kurt Wolff criticized his new image, commenting that his music "flirted dangerously with disco beats".{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Eugene Chadbourne of Allmusic only gave his ''Love...& Other Sad Stories'' album 1.5 out of 5 stars. "This is an album that begins with what sounds like a pervert and ends with an effect described as frightening. Too bad most of it is so boring to listen to", Chadbourne concluded.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Chadbourne |first1=Eugene |title=''Love...& Other Sad Stories'': Bill Anderson: Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/love-other-sad-stories-mw0001481913 |website=[[Allmusic]] |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref> Anderson's sales success began to decline following the release of "I Can't Wait Any Longer". His follow-up album, ''[[Ladies Choice (Bill Anderson album)|Ladies Choice]]'' (1979), only reached number 44 on the country albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Ladies Choice'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/bill-anderson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref> The album's only major hit was the top 20 single "[[This Is a Love Song]]".<ref name="whitburn"/> After the release of his final MCA album in 1980, he was dropped from the label.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}}

In the mid 1980s, Anderson shifted his professional interests. He began a brief television career in California.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> However, he continued recording music sporadically during the decade. On the independent Southern Tracks label, he released ''[[Southern Fried]]'' in 1983. The album was co-produced by Anderson and musician Mike Johnson.<ref name="SF Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Southern Fried'' (Liner Notes) |journal=Southern Tracks Records |date=1983 |id=STL 001}}</ref> The album also spawned four singles that became minor hits on the country songs chart, including the title track.<ref name="whitburn"/> In 1986, Anderson released ''[[A Place in the Country (album)|A Place in the Country]],'' which was also produced by Johnson. The record was also released in the United Kingdom with a different track list.<ref name="UK">{{cite web |title=Bill Anderson – ''A Place in the Country'' (UK version) |date=August 18, 1988 |url=https://www.discogs.com/Bill-Anderson-A-Place-In-The-Country/release/14637325 |publisher=[[discogs]] |access-date=May 1, 2020}}</ref> Four singles were spawned from the album that became minor country hits between 1984 and 1987.<ref name="whitburn"/>

===1990–present: New artistic directions===
Beginning in the early 1990s, Anderson focused more on songwriting. However, he continued recording his own music.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> Anderson's first studio release of the decade was 1992's ''[[Country Music Heaven]],'' issued on [[Curb Records]]. It was a collection of gospel songs that was inspired by his grandfather, a Methodist preacher.<ref name="CMH Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Country Music Heaven'' (Cassette insert) |journal=[[Curb Records]] |date=February 1993}}</ref> The album's title track was issued as a single, but did not chart in any ''Billboard'' music publications. The single was reviewed by ''Billboard'' magazine in 1992 where it received comparisons to music by [[Garth Brooks]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Billboard Single Reviews: 1992 |url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1992/Billboard-1992-12-05.pdf |website=American Radio History |access-date=August 20, 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Anderson was signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] as part of a veterans artists project that included [[Ronnie Milsap]] and [[Connie Smith]].<ref name="Price">{{cite magazine |last1=Evans Price |first1=Deborah |title=Veterans Artists Find New Label Homes |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=September 19, 1998 |volume=110 |issue=38 |page=62}}</ref> That year, his 36th studio offering entitled ''[[Fine Wine (Bill Anderson album)|Fine Wine]]'' was released. The project was produced by [[Steve Wariner]] and his wife Caryn.<ref name="Liner Notes">{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Bill |title=''Fine Wine'' (Liner Notes & Album Information) |journal=[[Warner Bros. Records]] |date=August 25, 1998 |id=46695}}</ref> John Weisberger of ''Country Standard Time'' gave the release a positive response, calling the songs "vintage".<ref name="CST">{{cite web |last1=Weisberger |first1=John |title=Bill Anderson – ''Fine Wine'' |url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=138 |website=Country Standard Time |access-date=August 20, 2020}}</ref> Meanwhile, Allmusic only gave it 2.5 out of 5 stars.<ref name="Fine Wine Allmusic">{{cite web |title=''Fine Wine'' – Bill Anderson – Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/fine-wine-mw0000041370 |website=[[Allmusic]] |access-date=August 20, 2020}}</ref> He began taking new artistic directions with his next studio release, ''[[A Lot of Things Different (album)|A Lot of Things Different]]'' (2001). The album represented a traditional country style, which Anderson called his most traditional effort yet. It was released on [[Varèse Sarabande]], which Anderson distributed music through in conjunction with his own record label, TWI.<ref name="A Lot of Things Different">{{cite magazine |last1=Bessman |first1=Jim |title=Varese Sarabande's Bill Anderson Bridges Old and New Guard |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=August 11, 2001 |volume=113 |issue=32 |page=43}}</ref>

[[File:Bill Anderson-Opry.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Anderson performing at the [[Grand Ole Opry]], 2006]]
Anderson's artistic directions continued expanding into the 2000s. After the release of another holiday album, ''[[No Place Like Home on Christmas]]'',<ref name="Christmas Billboard">{{cite magazine |last1=Bessman |first1=Jim |title=Legendary Bill Anderson Charts with Country Icons on XM |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=November 30, 2002 |volume=114 |issue=48 |page=28}}</ref> he released a third gospel project in 2004, ''[[Softly & Tenderly]].''<ref name="Softly and Tenderly Billboard">{{cite magazine |last1=Evans Price |first1=Deborah |title=Country Vets Get That 'Ol Time Religion |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 31, 2004 |volume=116 |issue=31 |page=35}}</ref> A year later, he released a contemporary country album entitled ''[[The Way I Feel (Bill Anderson album)|The Way I Feel]].'' It included his own version of [[Brad Paisley]]'s "[[Whiskey Lullaby]]", along with his own compositions.<ref name="CMT">{{cite web |last1=Morris |first1=Edward |title=Bill Anderson Bows First Country Album in Four Years |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1501175/bill-anderson-bows-first-country-album-in-four-years/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200720002433/http://www.cmt.com/news/1501175/bill-anderson-bows-first-country-album-in-four-years/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 20, 2020 |website=[[Country Music Television]] |access-date=May 21, 2020}}</ref> It was reviewed positively by Al Campbell, who praised its songwriting quality.<ref name="The Way I Feel Allmusic">{{cite web |title=''The Way I Feel'': Bill Anderson: Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-way-i-feel-mw0000301045 |website=[[Allmusic]] |access-date=August 20, 2020}}</ref> In 2007, Anderson released his first collection of [[bluegrass music]] called ''[[Whisperin' Bluegrass]].'' Released on [[Madacy Entertainment]], it included collaborations with [[Vince Gill]] and [[Dolly Parton]]. Chet Flippo of ''[[Country Music Television]]'' called it "a terrific album of country and gospel songs done up with bluegrass instrumentation".<ref name="Bluegrass CMT">{{cite web |last1=Flippo |first1=Chet |date=December 20, 2007 |title=NASHVILLE SKYLINE: Joe Nichols Leads Highlights of 2007 |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1576964/nashville-skyline-joe-nichols-leads-highlights-of-2007/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200805142041/http://www.cmt.com/news/1576964/nashville-skyline-joe-nichols-leads-highlights-of-2007/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 5, 2020 |access-date=May 22, 2020 |website=[[Country Music Television]]}}</ref>

In 2010 and 2014, respectively, Anderson released two self-produced studio albums: ''[[Songwriter (Bill Anderson album)|Songwriter]]'' and ''[[Life! (album)|Life!]].''<ref name="The Boot">{{cite web |last=Evans Price |first=Deborah |title=Bill Anderson Is Always a Songwriter At-Heart |url=https://theboot.com/bill-anderson-songwriter-interview/ |website=The Boot |date=June 8, 2010 |access-date=May 24, 2020}}</ref><ref name="Williamson Source">{{cite web |last=Hinds |first=Andrea |title="Whispering" Bill Anderson to Perform at Williamson Co Fair |url=https://williamsonsource.com/whispering-bill-anderson-perform-williamson-co-fair/ |website=Williamson Source |date=August 3, 2014 |access-date=May 25, 2020}}</ref> In 2018, his 44th studio effort, ''[[Anderson (album)|Anderson]],'' was issued and featured a collaboration with [[Jamey Johnson]].<ref name="Digital Journal">{{cite web |last=Papadatos |first=Markos |title=Review: Bill Anderson compelling on 72nd career studio album 'Anderson' |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-bill-anderson-compelling-on-72nd-career-studio-album-anderson/article/532092 |website=Digital Journal |date=September 15, 2018 |access-date=June 1, 2020}}</ref> He followed this with his 45th studio recording in 2020 called ''[[The Hits Re-Imagined]].'' The album was a collection of re-recorded hits and songs Anderson had written in his career. ''Billboard'' gave the record a favorable review which stated, "At 82, Anderson brings a gravitas to the heavier songs and a lightheartedness to tunes like "Po Folks" with a low-key production that keeps the focus squarely on Anderson and his delivery. Just as it should be".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''The Hits Re-Imagined'' album review (search album name in the "search" box) |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/bill-anderson |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 2, 2020}}</ref> In June 2022, a compilation titled ''The Best of Bill Anderson: As Far as I Can See'' was released by [[Universal Music Group Nashville|MCA Nashville]] and included a new track featuring [[Dolly Parton]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |title=Bill Anderson To Release New Album 'As Far As I Can See: The Best Of' In June |journal=Music Row |date=April 26, 2022 |url=https://musicrow.com/2022/04/bill-anderson-to-release-new-album-as-far-as-i-can-see-the-best-of-in-june/ |access-date=25 July 2022}}</ref>

==Songwriting career==
===1958–1979: Breakthrough in Nashville===
Anderson's writing career began during the same period as his recording career. His 1958 composition, "City Lights", ultimately led to his songwriting success. In an interview with [[Ken Burns]], Anderson recalled writing the song on a hotel roof: "I was up there one night in 1957 – I was nineteen years old – and I managed to write the 'bright array of city lights as far as I can see'", he recalled.<ref name="PBS"/> After Anderson's own version was released, it was brought to the attention of country artist [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]]. It was picked up by his record label and became a number one hit on the national country charts in 1958.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}}<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> 
[[File:Ray Price publicity portrait cropped.jpg|thumb|right|180px|American country artist [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]] was the first to record an Anderson composition.]]
{{listen|filename=Ray Price--City Lights--Audio 1958.ogg |title="City Lights" by Ray Price (1958)|description=Anderson's 1958 composition was recorded and made a major hit by Ray Price. The song ultimately led to a successful songwriting career in country music.|format=[[Ogg]]||pos=right}}

The success of "City Lights" led Anderson to receive a contract from the [[Tree International Publishing|Tree Writing]] music publishing company in Nashville.<ref name="Music Row Tree">{{cite web |last=Nicholson |first=Jessica |title=Bill Anderson Renews Publishing Deal With Sony/ATV Music Publishing |url=https://musicrow.com/2016/06/bill-anderson-renews-publishing-deal-with-sonyatv-music-publishing/ |website=Music Row |date=June 2, 2016 |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> The Tree contract allowed Anderson to write songs for his own music and others. Among his next hits as a writer was "I Missed Me", which was cut by [[Jim Reeves]].<ref name="whitburn"/> The single became a major country hit after reaching number three in December 1960.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="I Missed Me" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/jim-reeves/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> Another hit was "[[I Don't Love You Anymore]]", which was recorded by [[Charlie Louvin]] in 1964.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=85–110}} Released as a single, the song became Lovin's biggest solo hit, reaching number four on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="I Don't Love Yoy Anymore" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/charlie-louvin/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> That same year, [[Lefty Frizzell]] recorded Anderson's "[[Saginaw, Michigan (song)|Saginaw, Michigan]]".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=85–110}} The single became Frizzell's first number one hit since 1952, topping the charts in March 1964.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Saginaw, Michigan" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lefty-frizzell/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> During this time, he wrote two hits for [[Porter Wagoner]], including 1964's "I'll Go Down Swinging". He was inspired to write the song after hearing the song title at the end of a [[Hank Snow]] record.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=92}} Anderson also wrote solo hits for his duet partner, Jan Howard, in the 1960s. She had major hits with the Anderson-penned "[[Count Your Blessings, Woman]]", "[[I Still Believe in Love]]" and "[[Bad Seed (Jan Howard song)|Bad Seed]]".<ref name="Jan Howard"/> The latter track was a top ten hit for Howard in 1966.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Jan Howard chart history – Country songs |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/jan-howard/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref>

Anderson also wrote several hits for [[Connie Smith]]. He was also responsible for helping Smith sign her first recording contract.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Anderson had discovered Smith after hearing her perform in a talent contest near [[Columbus, Ohio]]. He helped bring her to Nashville, where she recorded several demonstration tapes that were heard by producers at [[RCA Records|RCA Victor Records]]. In 1964, Smith was signed to the label.<ref name="Connie Smith">{{cite journal |last1=Escott |first1=Colin |author-link=Colin Escott |title=''Born to Sing'' (Box Set Liner Notes) |journal=[[Bear Family Records]] |date=2001 |id=BCD 16368}}</ref> Anderson's composition "[[Once a Day]]" was recorded by Smith in 1964. Released as her debut single, it spent a total of eight weeks on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart, becoming his most successful hit as a writer at that point.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|pp=327–28}} Smith's career was further facilitated by Anderson, who wrote many of her follow-up hits such as "[[Then and Only Then]]", "[[Cincinnati, Ohio (song)|Cincinnati, Ohio]]" and "[[I Never Once Stopped Loving You (song)|I Never Once Stopped Loving You]]".<ref name="Connie Smith"/> Anderson further helped her professional career by helping her become a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and make an appearance on ''[[The Lawrence Welk Show]].'' "From the beginning, I liked Connie a lot personally and tried to help her", he recalled in his 2016 autobiography.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=167}}

Anderson also wrote material for pop artists during this time. In the 1960s, [[Brenda Lee]] recorded Anderson's "[[My Whole World Is Falling Down]]".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=85–110}} The single peaked at number 24 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 in August 1963.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="My Whole World Is Falling Down" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/brenda-lee/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> Other pop artists to record Anderson's material included [[James Brown]], [[Aretha Franklin]] and [[Dean Martin]].{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=xiii}} However, his most successful material was recorded by country artists, who continued recording his songs into the next decade. In 1972, [[Cal Smith]] cut Anderson's "[[The Lord Knows I'm Drinking]]", which became a number-one hit on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name="whitburn"/>{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=85–110}} The following year, [[Jean Shepard]] recorded Anderson's "[[Slippin' Away (Jean Shepard song)|Slippin Away]]". The single became Shepard's first top-ten hit in four years and she had further top-twenty hits that decade with Anderson-penned compositions.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Coyne |first1=Kevin John |title=100 Greatest Women, #37: Jean Shepard |url=http://www.countryuniverse.net/2018/07/27/100-greatest-women-37-jean-shepard/ |website=Country Universe |date=July 27, 2018 |access-date=August 22, 2020}}</ref> That same decade, [[Conway Twitty]] also had a number-one hit with the tune "[[I May Never Get to Heaven]]".<ref name="whitburn"/>

===1980–1991: Writing shifts===
Anderson's writing and recording careers slowed down at the same time. In the early 1980s, he began writing music less frequently. Instead, he began focusing on other projects in television. "I just knew that this is what I wanted to do for my life's work, but I do remember telling people I'd stop if it wasn't working out", he said in describing his move away from writing.<ref name="BMI 1">{{cite web |last1=Cooper |first1=Peter |title=Bill Anderson's Career Comes Full Circle |url=https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/bill_andersons_career_comes_full_circle |website=[[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] |date=January 11, 2008 |access-date=August 25, 2020}}</ref> In a 2020 interview with ''American Songwriter,'' Anderson also explained that the country market was shifting towards crossover pop. For that reason, he found it difficult to write material for other artists.<ref name="American Songwriter">{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Rick |title=Bill Anderson Drops 73rd Album, Zoom-Writes With Brad Paisley |url=https://americansongwriter.com/the-hits-reimagined-bill-anderson-album-interview/ |website=American Songwriter |date=July 31, 2020 |access-date=August 25, 2020}}</ref> "Country music was changing and I was wondering if I could still fit in. I don't know how I got in that funk, but it was a tough time", he recalled.<ref>{{cite web |last=Violanti |first=Tony |title=Nashville royalty Bill Anderson to bring impressive song catalog to Savannah Center |url=https://www.villages-news.com/2018/02/25/nashville-royalty-bill-anderson-bring-impressive-song-catalog-savannah-center/ |website=Villages News |date=February 25, 2018 |access-date=August 25, 2020}}</ref>

Anderson did not fully stop writing material for his own albums. On his 1983 studio release, ''Southern Fried,'' he wrote three of the record's tracks.<ref name="SF Liner Notes"/> His 1986 studio album, ''[[A Place in the Country (album)|A Place in the Country]],'' contained two tracks written (or co-written) by Anderson. However, only one album track was self-composed: the song "We May Never Pass This Way Again.' Both of these self-composed tracks were only included on the version of the album released in the United Kingdom.<ref name="UK"/> Anderson turned his writing priorities towards other directions as well. In 1989, he released his first autobiography, ''Whisperin' Bill,'' via Longstreet Press.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thanki |first1=Juli |title=Bill Anderson discusses triumphant return in new autobiography |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/02/12/bill-anderson-discusses-triumphant-return-new-autobiography/79816016/ |website=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=25 August 2020}}</ref> It was reviewed by ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' in August 1989, giving it a mostly positive response: "Despite a measure of hoopla and hyperbole ('I did it . . . I did it all . . . but it wasn't easy'), the author does justice to a powerful story", reviewers commented.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nonfiction Book Review: ''Whisperin' Bill: An Autobiography'' |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-929264-24-0 |website=[[Publishers Weekly]] |access-date=August 25, 2020}}</ref>

===1992–present: Return to songwriting and collaborations with others===
In 1992, country artist [[Steve Wariner]] recorded Anderson's 1960 hit "The Tip of My Fingers". Released as a single, it became a top-five hit on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart that year and inspired Anderson to write again.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> "Steve's version of 'Tips' was some indication that words, melodies and emotions can carry across decades", he commented.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=225}} Among his next compositions was a song co-written with [[Vince Gill]] entitled "[[Which Bridge to Cross (Which Bridge to Burn)]]". The song was written in a "writing appointment", where composers make arrangements to write music and are paid by recording hours in a time clock.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=227–29}} "Which Bridge to Cross" was released as a single by Gill in 1994 and became a major hit, peaking at number four on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name="whitburn"/> According to Anderson, the song's success helped him gain credibility with younger songwriters in Nashville. He began receiving phone calls from other writers and performers to set up more writing appointments.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=229}} Anderson, who was not used to writing with others, decided to make adaptations to his own songwriting style in order to collaborate. "I let a lot of young kids tell me a lot of things, and I benefited from that, greatly", he recounted.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=238}}

{{multiple image
| image1            = Brad Paisley performing at Caesars Windsor, 2022-05-29 05 (cropped).jpg
| image2            = George Strait 2014 1.jpg
| footer            = When Anderson relaunched his songwriting career, his compositions became major hits for artists such as [[Brad Paisley]] (left) and [[George Strait]] (right).
| total_width       = 300
}}
Anderson began co-writing more frequently during the 1990s. Wariner had another hit in 1999 with another Anderson composition titled "[[Two Teardrops]]".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=235–36}} The song became a major hit when it reached number two on the country songs chart in June 1999.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Two Teardrops" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/steve-wariner/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> The song was also nominated for a [[Grammy award]].{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=235–36}} During the same period, he collaborated with [[Skip Ewing]] and Debbie Moore on the song "[[Wish You Were Here (Mark Wills song)|Wish You Were Here]]".{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=237}} The song was released as a single by [[Mark Wills]] and became a number one hit on the ''Billboard'' country chart in 1999.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Wish You Were Here" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/mark-wills/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> Anderson later commented that the song's success helped him resolve financial struggles he had battled during the decade.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=238}} He followed "Wish You Were Here" with the song "[[A Lot of Things Different]]", which was co-written with [[Dean Dillon]]. The song was written during an exchange the pair had while out to breakfast.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=255}} The song was later recorded by [[Kenny Chesney]], whose version reached number six on the country singles chart in 2003.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Kenny Chesney chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/kenny-chesney/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref>

Chesney's song was followed by a track later recorded by [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Alison Krauss]] called "[[Whiskey Lullaby]]". The tune was composed with singer-songwriter [[Jon Randall]]. After writing the song, Randall was reluctant to record a [[demo (music)|demo]] of the record to pitch to other artists. However, Anderson believed the song could be a success and its demo was then recorded at ten o'clock on a weeknight.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=264–65}} Paisley's version was released as a single in 2004 and peaked at number three on the ''Billboard'' country chart that year.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Whiskey Lullaby" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/alison-krauss/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> In 2005, "Whiskey Lullaby" won "Song of the Year" at the [[Country Music Association Awards]].<ref name="CMA Awards">{{cite web |title=Past Winners and Nominees: Bill Anderson |url=https://cmaawards.com/past-winners-and-nominees/?appSession=4T936M34H8LG4N842905B7G4KV6J31SJ27VFOB36J04U7EB1K2I6I27212F7171KJ686J7RV3TOR5DM0SO61TKT6NKV51IE8O7O25QY31N0PRH1FBRS7PXQB31K3HZ42 |website=[[Country Music Association Awards]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> Anderson recalled the excitement of winning the accolade in his autobiography: "I jumped up and hugged Brad and knocked his white western hat from his head."{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=268}}

In 2006, Anderson co-wrote a song with [[Jamey Johnson]] and [[Buddy Cannon]] called "[[Give It Away (George Strait song)|Give It Away]]". The song was later cut by [[George Strait]].{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=271}} The song's concept was inspired by Johnson's divorce at the time and included a spoken narration, a device that was not popular in the country genre during the mid-2000s.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=272}} Strait's version was released as a single in 2006 and reached number one on the country chart that September.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Give It Away" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/george-strait/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> The song later won "Song of the Year" from the CMA Awards, becoming Anderson's third accolade from the awards show in the last three years.<ref name="CMA Awards"/> Later that decade, Anderson collaborated with other writers to compose "[[Joey (Sugarland song)|Joey]]" for the country duo [[Sugarland]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Story Behind the Song "Joey" |url=https://theboot.com/story-behind-the-song-joey-sugarland/ |website=The Boot |date=November 6, 2015 |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> The single reached the top 20 of the country songs chart in 2009.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Joey" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/sugarland/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref> In 2014, Anderson co-wrote [[Mo Pitney]]'s top-30 country hit "[[Country (Mo Pitney song)|Country]]" with Pitney and Bobby Tomberlin.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mo Pitney, 'Country,' TOC Critics Pick |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mo-pitney-country/ |website=Taste of Country |date=December 16, 2014 |access-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref>

On July 22, 2023, Anderson was honored as the [[Grand Ole Opry]]'s longest-serving [[List of Grand Ole Opry members|member]] in the show's history. Anderson's membership has not lapsed in 62 years since his initial induction in 1961.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2023/07/bill-anderson-to-be-honored-as-longest-serving-grand-ole-opry-member/ | title=Bill Anderson to be Honored as Longest-Serving Grand Ole Opry Member | date=July 6, 2023 }}</ref>

==Other career contributions==
===Film and television===
Between 1965 and 1974, Anderson hosted his own national television series called ''The Bill Anderson Show''.<ref name="Nashville Songwriters">{{cite web |title=Bill Anderson |url=http://nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/Site/inductee?entry_id=126 |website=[[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] |access-date=August 27, 2020}}</ref> The program also featured Jan Howard (his duet partner) and The Po' Boys (his touring band).<ref name="Jan Howard"/> The show was first filmed in [[Windsor, Ontario]] and [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. Filming was later moved to the General Electric Broadcasting Facility in Nashville, Tennessee. Broadcasting from Nashville made traveling easier since Anderson lived in the city.<ref name="Jan Howard"/>{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=174}} On an average filming day, Anderson taped two thirty-minute shows in front of a live audience.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=174}} Around this time, he also appeared in several country music vehicle films. This included ''[[The Las Vegas Hillbillys]]'', which featured country artists [[Sonny James]] and [[Connie Smith]].<ref name="Las Vegas Hillbillys">{{cite web |title=Las Vegas Hillbillys |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/las-vegas-hillbillys/Film?oid=1053744 |website=[[Chicago Reader]] |date = October 26, 1985|access-date=August 27, 2020}}</ref> He also made appearances on several national television shows during this time, including ''[[The Today Show]].''{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=174}}

[[File:Krystal.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Anderson became a spokesperson for the [[Po' Folks (restaurant)|Po' Folks]] fast-food company. The company was later bought out by the [[Krystal (restaurant)|Krystal]] hamburger chain (pictured above).]]
Anderson ventured further into television in the late 1970s. Between 1977 and 1978, he and [[Sarah Purcell]] co-hosted the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] game show ''[[The Better Sex]]''.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> In 1980, he appeared on two episodes of the ABC soap opera ''[[One Life to Live]]'', portraying a fictionalized version of himself. In a 1980 interview, then-ABC vice president Jackie Smith called the decision "a first" for a country artist.<ref name="One Life">{{cite web |last1=Hanauer |first1=Joan |title=Soap Opry |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1980/10/19/SOAP-OPRY/3434340776000/ |website=UPI |access-date=August 27, 2020}}</ref> Also in the 1980s, Anderson hosted the program ''Backstage at the Grand Ole Opry'' and the game show ''[[Fandango (game show)|Fandango]]'', which both aired on the former [[The Nashville Network|Nashville Network]] (TNN). ''Fandango'' was brought to Anderson's attention by the program director of [[WSMV-TV|WSM TV]] in Nashville, who believed that a country music trivia show would be successful for the network.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=220}} "I've gotten into a lot of different things. I'm probably in the public eye more right now than I've ever been because of the things that I do on television", he said in 1988.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lynn |first1=Linda |title=Career Full of Opportunities For "Fandango's' Bill Anderson |url=https://oklahoman.com/article/2247737/career-full-of-opportunities-for-fandangos-bill-anderson |access-date=August 27, 2020 |publisher=[[The Oklahoman]] |date=December 2, 1988}}</ref> He remained with ''Fandango'' until 1989.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=220}} Anderson was then invited to join the cast of the TNN competition program ''You Can Be a Star.'' Anderson was involved in the show's inner workings, including helping to develop the scoring system. In addition, his touring band was hired as the show's stage band.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=220}}

Anderson appeared as himself in the February 15, 1965, episode of ''[[To Tell the Truth]]'', receiving two of the four possible votes. [[Major League Baseball]] pitcher [[Tracy Stallard]] appeared as one of the two imposters for Anderson.<ref>{{cite web |title=To Tell the Truth |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VAQdTwP7k3A |website=[[CBS]] | date=November 24, 2013 |access-date=17 July 2022}}</ref>

===Business career===
Anderson also focused on business opportunities, many of which were unsuccessful. In his autobiography, he commented, "I've tried to become a businessman a couple of times when I should have kept right on pickin' and grinnin'."{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=213}} In 1975, he bought a radio station in [[Provo, Utah]], called [[KIXR|KIXX]]. Anderson was unable to have enough advertisers support his radio station, causing it to fail. Six years later, he sold the station and left the radio industry. "I was totally disillusioned by something I love", he wrote in 2016.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=214}}

In the 1980s, Anderson served as a spokesperson for the [[Po' Folks (restaurant)|Po' Folks]] restaurant chain, whose name was taken from his 1961 hit song.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=Bill|title=Whisperin' Bill: An Autobiography|year=1989|publisher=Longstreet Press|page=305}}</ref> Anderson signed a three-year contract with the restaurant company to serve as their national spokesperson, appearing in radio and television commercials. In addition, Anderson signed off on allowing the company to use his photos and signatures to endorse their products.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=216}} He then partnered with the vice president to help franchise the company. Country artist [[Conway Twitty]] was selected as a third partner to also help with franchising. However, several individual restaurants encountered financial struggles, which resulted in legal fees that Anderson had to pay. In addition, the company was being bought out by the larger [[Krystal (restaurant)|Krystal]] fast-food chain. He was forced to pay back fees he owed towards the company, nearly causing Anderson to declare [[bankruptcy]]. However, with the support of Twitty, Anderson helped pay off the company's financial entanglements. "Even as it stood, my little foray into the restaurant business wiped out a large chunk of my life's savings", he later said.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=217–20}}

==Personal life==
Anderson has been married twice and has had two documented long-term relationships. He met his first wife, Bette ({{nee|Rhodes}}), in the late 1950s through a mutual friend. The pair married in December 1959. At the time of their marriage, Bette was 19 and Bill was 22. The couple remained married for ten years. Bette gave birth to two daughters during their relationship together.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|pp=70–71}} Bette also contributed to her husband's writing career when she co-wrote the 1965 song, "[[I Can't Remember]]". It was later recorded by [[Connie Smith]] on her 1965 studio album ''[[Cute 'n' Country]].''<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Smith |first1=Connie |title=''Cute 'n' Country'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[RCA Records|RCA Victor]] |date=October 1965 |id=pm-3444}}</ref> The pair separated in 1968 and officially divorced in 1969. Reflecting on his divorce in 2016, Anderson believed it was difficult for Bette to understand the music business, causing them to drift apart.{{sfn|Anderson, Bill|Cooper, Peter|2016|p=71}} Bette Anderson died in 2010 at the age of 69.<ref>{{cite web |title=June 2, 2010 – Bill Anderson's Journal |url=https://billanderson.com/wired18/june-2-2010/ |website=Bill Anderson.com |date=June 2, 2010 |access-date=August 29, 2020}}</ref>

In 1970, he married his second wife, Becky. Together the couple had one child.<ref name="Becky">{{cite book |last=Oermann |first=Robert K. |title=Behind the Grand Ole Opry Curtain: Tales of Romance and Tragedy |date=2008 |publisher=Hachette Book Group |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-1-599951-84-3}}</ref> In 1984, Becky was involved in a car accident that caused "25 percent brain impairment." The couple filed a lawsuit against the driver who had crashed into Becky's vehicle. The recovery process took several years.<ref>{{cite news |title=The wife of country music singer Bill Anderson suffered... |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1986/10/01/The-wife-of-country-music-singer-Bill-Anderson-suffered/5555528523200/ |access-date=August 29, 2020 |agency=[[UPI]] |date=October 1, 1986}}</ref> The couple separated in the 1990s before officially divorcing in 1997.<ref name="Becky"/> 

Anderson briefly dated Deborah Marlin following his second divorce. In 2003, Anderson was arrested after being accused by Marlin of hitting her with his car door. He was released from jail the same day.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Bill Anderson Charged With Domestic Assault |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/71815/bill-anderson-charged-with-domestic-assault |access-date=August 29, 2020 |date=March 27, 2003 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

Anderson began dating Vickie Salas around 2008. The couple had first met years prior when she was 19 and was romantically involved with Anderson's band member. The two reconnected following Anderson's second divorce. "We never married, we never lived together, but she became my everything", Anderson later remembered.<ref>{{cite web |last=Stefano |first=Angela |title=Vickie Salas, Bill Anderson's 'Longtime Companion', Dies |url=https://theboot.com/vickie-salas-bill-anderson-companion-dead-dies/ |website=The Boot |date=January 16, 2019 |access-date=August 29, 2020}}</ref> In 2016, Salas was diagnosed with cancer. Three years later, the disease intensified and she began receiving hospice care. She died in January 2019.<ref>{{cite web |last=Nicholson |first=Jessica |title=Bill Anderson's Longtime Companion Vickie Salas Dies |url=https://musicrow.com/2019/01/bill-andersons-longtime-companion-vickie-salas-dies/ |website=Music Row |date=January 17, 2019 |access-date=August 29, 2020}}</ref>

==Musical styles==
As a songwriter, Anderson has composed a variety of material. Author Kurt Wolff called his early compositions "cute and sentimental", citing "Po' Folks" and "I Love You Drops" to be examples of this style. Wolff also noted that other songs exemplified "anti-establishment attitudes" while other songs focused on themes that were "desperately bleak".{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Riane Konc of The Boot noted a similar trend in his songwriting style. She highlighted 2004's "Whiskey Lullaby" as an example. In reviewing the song, Konc commented that it was "packed full of unforgettable images" related to "heartbreak, addiction and loss". Konc also praised 2006's "Give It Away", calling it an "instant classic".<ref name="Top 10">{{cite web |last=Konc |first=Riane |title=Top 10 Bill Anderson Songs |url=https://theboot.com/top-bill-anderson-songs/ |website=The Boot |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref> In a 2018 interview with ''American Songwriter,'' Anderson described his songwriting style: "The lyric is what attracted me to country music as a young boy– the story songs that I could listen to and feel some emotion. So yeah, I'd like to have the next generation pull out a few lines I've written and say 'yeah that's pretty clever!'"<ref>{{cite web |last=Dye |first=Robert |title=A Q&A with Songwriters Hall of Fame inductee Bill Anderson |url=https://americansongwriter.com/qa-songwriters-hall-fame-inductee-bill-anderson/ |website=American Songwriter |date=June 11, 2018 |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref>

[[File:Bill Anderson and Rick Crawford - 2017 02.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Anderson and Arkansas Congressman [[Rick Crawford (politician)|Rick Crawford]], 2017]]
Anderson also created a musical style as a recording artist. After signing with Decca Records, he was given the nickname of "Whisperin' Bill Anderson", due to his soft-spoken vocal performance.<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/>{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Writer and critic Kurt Wolff has commented on his "whispering" vocal style. Wolff also noted that many of his recordings included a combination of both "singing and recitation".{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}} Steve Huey of Allmusic called his voice "airy" and "gentle".<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> Stephen L. Betts of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' commented that Anderson continues to demonstrate a whispering quality into his current work. In 2020, Betts stated that Anderson's vocal style "remains subdued in the present".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Bill Anderson to Revisit 60 Years of Hits on Upcoming Album |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/bill-anderson-hit-songs-new-album-1026834/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 10, 2020 |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref>

==Legacy and honors==
Writers and music critics have considered Anderson one of country music's most significant songwriters.{{sfn|Wolff, Kurt|2000|p=292}}<ref name="PBS"/><ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> Steve Huey of [[AllMusic]] called him "one of the most successful songwriters in country music history".<ref name="Allmusic Bio"/> [[Ken Burns]] of [[PBS]] called him an "acclaimed singer-songwriter".<ref name="PBS"/> In 2019, ''The Boot'' further commented on Anderson's legacy: "In fact, one of the most impressive things about Anderson is his versatility: He's the soft voice behind many classic country songs, but he's also the writer or co-writer of plenty of your current favorites."<ref name="Top 10"/> Kevin John Coyne of ''Country Universe'' cited Anderson's songwriting as the center of his legacy: "It's been Bill Anderson's songwriting that's kept him topping the country charts for decades longer than even his most successful contemporaries."<ref name="Country Universe">{{cite web |title=100 Greatest Men of Country Music: Bill Anderson: #27 |url=http://www.countryuniverse.net/2013/06/09/100-greatest-men-27-bill-anderson/ |website=Country Universe |date=June 9, 2013 |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref>

In 1975, Anderson was inducted into the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]].<ref name="Nashville Songwriters"/> In 2001, he was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name="Country Music Hall of Fame">{{cite news |title=Bill Anderson: Country Music Hall of Fame |url=https://countrymusichalloffame.org/artist/bill-anderson/ |website=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]] |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref> In November 2002, [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] named him its first country songwriting icon, placing him alongside R&B artists [[Little Richard]], [[Chuck Berry]], [[Bo Diddley]] and [[James Brown]] as the only recipients of that award.<ref name="BMI">{{cite web|url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/233187 |title=BMI Celebrates Country Music at Awards Ceremony |work=bmi.com |date=November 5, 2002 |access-date=October 4, 2010}}</ref> In 2018, he was inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]], along with [[Alan Jackson]] and [[John Mellencamp]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Holthouse |first=Jerry |title=Bill Anderson Inducted Into The Songwriters Hall Of Fame |url=https://www.nashville.com/bill-anderson-inducted-into-the-songwriters-hall-of-fame/ |website=Nashville |date=June 19, 2018 |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref> Anderson has also been placed on several lists of country music's top writers and performers. In 2008, he was ranked 27th on ''Country Universe''{{'s}} list of the "100 Greatest Men of Country Music".<ref name="Country Universe"/> He was ranked among the "100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time" in a 2017 list compiled by ''[[Rolling Stone]].''<ref>{{cite magazine |title=100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/100-greatest-country-artists-of-all-time-195775/toby-keith-5-195930/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=June 15, 2017 |access-date=September 8, 2020}}</ref>

* 2007: ''[[Whisperin' Bluegrass]]''
* 2010: ''[[Songwriter (Bill Anderson album)|Songwriter]]''
* 2014: ''[[Life! (album)|Life]]''
* 2018: ''[[Anderson (album)|Anderson]]''
* 2020: ''[[The Hits Re-Imagined]]''

'''William G. Evans''' (born September 2, 1956) is an American musician, author, and instructor noted for his banjo proficiency and knowledge of the history of the instrument.

==Biography==
Evans earned a master's degree in Music from [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1992, with a focus on ethnomusicology. He learned banjo in person from masters such as [[Tony Trischka]], [[Alan Munde]], [[Bill Keith (musician)|Bill Keith]], [[Ben Eldridge]], [[Sonny Osborne]], and [[J. D. Crowe]].<ref name=BE-peghead-2017>{{cite web |url=https://pegheadnation.com/string-school/courses/bluegrass-banjo/
|title=Bluegrass Banjo with Bill Evans
|work=Peghead Nation|access-date=July 6, 2017}}</ref>

===Cloud Valley===
Evans' first band was [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]-based Cloud Valley with [[Missy Raines]] (bass), Charlie Rancke (guitar), and Steve Smith (mandolin).<ref name=BE-bgwomen-2013>{{cite book 
|last=Hicks Henry|first=Murphy|date=May 1, 2013|title=Pretty Good for a Girl: Women in Bluegrass|publisher=University of Illinois Press |isbn=9780252095887 |edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=plJvCQfDzyQC&q=bill+evans+cloud+valley|access-date=July 6, 2017}}</ref>  The progressive bluegrass band released two albums: ''A Bluegrass Ensemble'' in 1983 and ''Live In Europe'' in 1985. Their final performance was in Winfield, Kansas in 1985, but Evans still collaborates with individual band members.<ref name=BE-twangin-2017>{{cite web |url=http://www.steamiron.com/who/bevans.html|title=Bill Evans|work=Twangin': Who's Who|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>

===Dry Branch Fire Squad===
For some time, Evans performed and recorded with [[Dry Branch Fire Squad]].<ref name="BE-trischka-2005">{{cite book|author=Tony Trischka|title=Banjo for Beginners: An Easy Beginning Method|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZMpjScS0RcMC&pg=PA45|date=1 April 2005|publisher=Alfred Music Publishing|isbn=978-0-7390-3733-1|pages=45–}}</ref><ref name=BE-nodep-1996>{{cite news|last1=Kasten|first1=Roy|title=Dry Branch Fire Squad - Live At Last!|url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/dry-branch-fire-squad-live-last|access-date=July 7, 2017|work=No Depression|date=December 31, 1996}}{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

===Bluegrass Intentions===
Evans was a member of the bluegrass ensemble Bluegrass Intentions with Suzy Thompson (fiddle, Cajun accordion, vocals), Eric Thompson (mandolin, guitar, vocals), Larry Cohea (bass, vocals),  and [[Alan Senauke]] (guitar, vocals). They released one album ''Old as Dirt'' on Evans's Native and Fine record label in 2002.<ref name=BE-intentions-2017>{{cite web |url=http://www.ericandsuzy.com/bluegrass-intentions.html|title=Bluegrass Intentions|work=Eric & Suzy Thompson|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref><ref name=BE-bgguitar-2005>{{cite book 
|last=Griffin|first=Sid|date=2005|title=Bluegrass Guitar: Know the Players, Play the Music|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation |isbn=9780879308704 |edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x1xhap5xMLsC|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>

===Due West===
Bluegrass group Due West featured Evans, [[Jim Nunally]] (guitar), Erik Thomas (mandolin), Cindy Browne (bass) and Chad Manning (fiddle). Their one album is ''These Boots'' released in 2003.<ref name=BE-northfield-2003>{{cite news|last1=staff writer|title=Bill Evans to present convocation, Due West to perform at Carleton|url=http://www.southernminn.com/northfield_news/archives/article_5a64de73-7af0-5d4b-8282-8cc46151feb3.html|access-date=July 5, 2017|work=Northfield News|date=Feb 12, 2003}}</ref><ref name=BE-jimnunally-2017>{{cite web|url=http://www.jimnunally.com/jimnunally/Bands.html|title=The Bands Past and Present|work=Jim Nunally website|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317140838/http://www.jimnunally.com/jimnunally/Bands.html|archive-date=March 17, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Bill Evans String Summit===
The Bill Evans String Summit is Evans, Scott Nygaard (guitar), Michael Witcher (dobro), Cindy Browne (bass), Tashina Clarridge (violin), and Tristan Clarridge (violin, cello). Group members bring together their influences from their backgrounds in jazz, classical, and world music.<ref name=BE-bgtoday-2006>{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=Bill Evans String Summit makes CA debut|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/bill-evans-string-summit-makes-ca-debut/|access-date=July 5, 2017|work=Bluegrass Today|date=March 18, 2006}}</ref>

===Recent collaborations===
Evans has been touring and holding workshops several weeks each year with [[Alan Munde]] ([[Country Gazette (band)|Country Gazette]]). He has also been recording with long-time bluegrass fiddler Fletcher Bright. Evans tours frequently with mandolin player Steve Smith from Cloud County, and with fiddler Megan Lynch.<ref name=BE-salvage-2009>{{cite web|url=http://thefreight.org/bill-evans-megan-lynch-0|title=Bill Evans & Megan Lynch|work=Freight & Salvage|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150911192624/http://www.thefreight.org/bill-evans-megan-lynch-0|archive-date=September 11, 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also has been touring with [[Dan Crary]] (guitar) and Steve Spurgin (bass).<ref name=BE-cafe-2016>{{cite news|last1=uncredited|title=An Interview with Bill Evans|url=http://www.banjocafe.net/forum/content.php?185-An-Interview-with-Bill-Evans|access-date=July 6, 2017|work=Banjo Cafe|date=April 26, 2016}}</ref>

===Education and teaching===
Evans has taught [[ethnomusicology]] at San Francisco State University, the University of Virginia, and Duke University. Evans gives private banjo lessons at his home in [[Albany, California]]. He also stages banjo workshops at major music festivals all over the country.<ref name=BE-pacifica-2011>{{cite news|last1=Bartlett|first1=Jean|title=Bill Evans mighty banjo breakdown – Saturday in Pacifica|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2011/04/05/bill-evans-mighty-banjo-breakdown-saturday-in-pacifica/|access-date=July 7, 2017|work=Pacifica Tribune|date=April 5, 2011}}</ref>

A [[convocation]] by Evans "The Banjo in America: A Musical and Cultural History" has been presented in various venues across the country. This convocation traces the history of the banjo from West African to the New World, with performances on vintage instruments of music from the 1700s to today.<ref name=BE-carlton-2003>{{cite web |url=https://apps.carleton.edu/events/convocations/audio_video/?item_id=5048|title=Convocation: Bill Evans|work=Carlton College|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>

===Music Instruction Author===
In 2007, [[Wiley Publishing]] published the book ''Banjo for Dummies'' authored by Evans.<ref name=BE-dummies-2007>{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=Bill Evans – Banjo For Dummies|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/bill-evans-banjo-for-dummies/|access-date=July 6, 2017|work=Bluegrass Today|date=December 14, 2006}}</ref> This was followed in 2016 in by ''Bluegrass Banjo for Dummies''.<ref name=VE-bgdummies-2016>{{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Ian|title=Bluegrass Banjo for Dummies by Bill Evans|url=https://banjonews.com/2016-04/bluegrass_banjo_for_dummies_by_bill_evans.html|access-date=July 6, 2017|work=The Banjo Newsletter|date=April 1, 2016}}</ref>

In recent years, Evans has been the author of the "Off the Record" instructional column for Banjo Newsletter magazine.<ref name=BE-newsltr-2016>{{cite web |url=https://banjonews.com/2016-04/bill_evans_in_bnl.html
|title=Bill Evans in Banjo Newsletter|work=Banjo Newsletter|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>

Evans and Dix Bruce co-authored the ''Parking Lot Pickers Songbook'' published by [[Mel Bay#Mel Bay Publications|Mel Bay Publications]].<ref name=BE-pickers-2010>{{cite book |last=Bruce|first=Dix|date=Dec 29, 2010|title=Parking Lot Picker's Songbook|publisher=Mel Bay Publications |isbn=9781610658638 |edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PLfBDWHEOjUC|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>

===Endorsements===
American Made Banjo Company created the Bill Evans Signature Series 5 String Kel Kroydon banjo.<ref name=BE-americanmade-2017>{{cite web |url=https://www.americanmadebanjo.com/billevansbanjo.php|title=Bill Evans Signature Banjo
|work=American Made Banjo Company|access-date=July 6, 2017}}</ref>

===Awards===
In 2024, Evans was inducted into the [[American Banjo Museum Hall of Fame members|American Banjo Hall of Fame]] in the Instruction & Education category.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-02-13 |title=Hall of Fame Celebration |url=https://americanbanjomuseum.com/hall-of-fame-celebration/ |access-date=2024-06-21 |website=American Banjo Museum |language=en-US}}</ref>

Evans was awarded Steve Martin Banjo Prize on November 10, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pegheadnation.com/news-reviews/breaking-news/bill-evans-wins-a-2022-steve-martin-banjo-prize/|title=Bill Evans Wins the 2022 Steve Martin Banjo Prize|website=Peghead Nation}}</ref>

The album "Bill Evans Plays Banjo" was cited by the Chicago Tribune as a Top 10 Bluegrass Recording of 2001.<ref name="BE-northfield-2003" />

In 1997, Evans was awarded a musical composition fellowship by the [[Kentucky Arts Council]].<ref name="BE-kobeshoin-2017">{{cite web|url=http://banjo.shoin.ac.jp/~gauchi/grass/EvansShoin/flyerE.pdf|title=Lecture Concert: Bill Evans - the Banjo in America|work=Kobe Shoin Women's University|access-date=July 7, 2017}}{{Dead link|date=October 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

In 1996, Evan's album ''Native and Fine'' earned an honorable mention in the category of Acoustic Instrumental Recording of the Year from the NAIRD (National Association of Independent Record Retailers and Distributors).
