'''Kathleen Alice Mattea''' (born June 21, 1959){{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}}<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kathy-mattea-mn0000362437/biography|title=Kathy Mattea biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer. Active since 1984 as a recording artist, she has charted more than 30 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including four that reached No.&nbsp;1: "[[Goin' Gone]]", "[[Eighteen Wheels and a Dozen Roses]]", "[[Come from the Heart]]", and "[[Burnin' Old Memories]]", plus 12 more that charted within the top ten. She has released 14 studio albums, two Christmas albums, and one greatest hits album. Most of her material was recorded for [[Universal Music Group Nashville]]'s [[Mercury Records]] Nashville 8division between 1984 and 2000, with later albums being issued on [[Narada Productions]], her own Captain Potato label, and [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. Among her albums, she has received five gold certifications and one platinum certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). She has collaborated with [[Dolly Parton]], [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], and her husband, [[Jon Vezner]]. Mattea is also a two-time [[Grammy Award]] winner: in 1990 for "[[Where've You Been]]", and in 1993 for her Christmas album ''[[Good News (Kathy Mattea album)|Good News]]''. Her style is defined by traditional country, bluegrass, [[folk music|folk]], and [[Celtic music]] influences.

==Early life==
Kathleen Alice Mattea was born June 21, 1959, in [[South Charleston, West Virginia]]. She and her two brothers grew up in nearby [[Cross Lanes, West Virginia|Cross Lanes]].{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Their father worked in a chemical plant and her mother was a homemaker.<ref name="gold">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/archive/down-home-diva-kathy-mattea-spins-tears-into-country-gold-vol-34-no-12/|title=Down-Home Diva Kathy Mattea Spins Tears into Country Gold|last=Sanz|first=Cynthia|date=September 24, 1990|work=People|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> During her childhood, Mattea's mother would have her perform informal piano recitals for family and friends.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=415}} She also sang in her parents' church as a child, and in high school she performed at school shows and family gatherings.<ref name="encyclopedia">{{cite book|last1=Stambler|first1=Irwin|last2=Landon|first2=Grelun|title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d18K8QWcEo8C&q=%22kathy+mattea%22&pg=PA592|date=July 15, 2000|pages=285–287|publisher=Macmillan |isbn=9780312264871}}</ref> Mattea also began playing guitar in her teen years after discovering [[folk music]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=415}} In addition to folk, Mattea also took an interest in bluegrass, which she would later say "formed [her] roots" as an artist.<ref name="encyclopedia"/> In 1976, while attending [[West Virginia University]], she joined a bluegrass band.<ref name="gold"/> After a songwriter friend graduated and chose to pursue a career in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Mattea decided to drop out of school and go with him. Her friend soon left Nashville in hopes of pursuing medical school, but Mattea chose to stay behind.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=415}} She worked as a tour guide at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]], and then as a secretary and a waitress, to support herself while working as a demo singer. Songwriter, publisher, and record producer [[Byron Hill]] discovered her and helped her sign to [[Mercury Records]] in 1983.<ref name="definitive">{{Cite AV media notes |title=The Definitive Collection |others=Kathy Mattea |year=2006 |first=Robyn |last=Flans |type=CD booklet |publisher=Mercury Records |id=B0007233-02}}</ref><ref name="bend">{{cite news|url=http://www.southbendtribune.com/entertainment/inthebend/eventnews/coal-miner-s-granddaughter-defies-labels/article_e270f345-7cc5-5b1f-ad13-12f26db2faac.html|title=Coal miner's granddaughter defies labels|last=Harrell|first=Jeff|date=December 11, 2014|work=South Bend Tribune|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

==Career==
===1984–1986: First two albums===
Mattea's [[Kathy Mattea (album)|self-titled debut album]] came out in 1984,<ref name="allmusic"/> with Hill and Rick Peoples as the album's producers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1984/07/21/page/14/article/italian-american-mattea-moves-into-hit-country|title=Italian-American Mattea moves into hit country|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=July 21, 1984|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|pages=14, 16|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Mattea later noted that "there were no budgets" when she was recording the album, as she was unable to afford a $75 makeup session, and the front cover featured her wearing a jacket which she had purchased at [[Kmart (United States)|Kmart]].<ref name="definitive"/> In addition, Mattea was given advice from image consultants on her musical persona. According to Mattea, she did not have an "artistic vision" at the time, which accounted for a lack of artistic identity.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=415-416}}

Four of its singles made the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, starting with "[[Street Talk (song)|Street Talk]]", which charted at number 25.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Mattea had originally recorded a demo of the song with the intent of having [[Terri Gibbs]] record it, but Mattea kept it for herself when Gibbs declined the song.<ref name="definitive"/> Followup "[[Someone Is Falling in Love]]" (written by [[Pebe Sebert]]) made it to number 26 on the same chart, while "You've Got a Soft Place to Fall" and "That's Easy for You to Say" fell short of the top 40.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Other notable cuts on the album included "God Ain't No Stained Glass Window", which was released as a 12" promotional single for the Christmas season;<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Kirby|first=Kip|date=December 22, 1984|title=Nashville Scene|magazine=Billboard|page=47|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1984/BB-1984-12-22.pdf}}</ref> a cover version of [[Barry Manilow]]'s 1981 hit "[[Somewhere Down the Road (Barry Manilow song)|Somewhere Down the Road]]";<ref name="mattea people">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/archive/picks-and-pans-review-kathy-mattea-vol-21-no-14/|title=Picks and Pans Review: Kathy Mattea|last=Novak|first=Ralph|date=April 9, 1984|work=People|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> and "[[(Back to the) Heartbreak Kid]]", which later became a Top 10 hit on the country charts for [[Restless Heart]] in late 1985 to early 1986.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=279}} [[Allmusic]] reviewer William Ruhlmann wrote of the album that it was "a fairly representative sampling of Nashville formula country writing", while praising the "feisty" nature of "Street Talk" and Mattea's vocals on "Heartbreak Kid".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/kathy-mattea-mw0000197442|title=''Kathy Mattea'' review|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' reviewer Ralph Novak compared Mattea's voice favorably to [[Anne Murray]] and said that "Mattea may not have the most revolutionary sound around, but her material is especially good."<ref name="mattea people"/>

Her second album, ''[[From My Heart]]'', was also her first under the production of [[Allen Reynolds]],<ref name="heart billboard"/><ref name="heart">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/from-my-heart-mw0000315603|title=''From My Heart''|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> who is best known for his work with [[Crystal Gayle]] and [[Garth Brooks]]. Released in 1985, it produced the chart singles "[[It's Your Reputation Talkin']]", "[[He Won't Give In]]", and "Heart of the Country", which peaked at numbers 34, 22, and 46 respectively on Hot Country Songs.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} It also featured a cover of [[Elton John]]'s "[[Ball and Chain (Elton John song)|Ball and Chain]]", from his 1982 album ''[[Jump Up! (Elton John album)|Jump Up!]]''<ref name="heart"/> Ruhlmann found this album superior to its predecessor, stating that Reynolds "seems to have shaped the song selections to the singer's talents and given her the opportunity to sing in a more individual manner."<ref name="heart"/> A review of the album in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' was also positive, noting the "more focused direction and a simpler, purer sound".<ref name="heart billboard">{{cite magazine|date=March 30, 1985|title=Reviews|magazine=Billboard|page=72|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5yMEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22kathy+mattea%22+%22From+my+heart%22&pg=PT149}}</ref>

===1986–1990: Breakthrough===
Mattea's artistic vision developed with the making of her third album, which brought in folk and acoustic sounds (inspired by her childhood).{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=416}} Her third album, ''[[Walk the Way the Wind Blows]]'' (1986) was (according to AllMusic) "her breakthrough both critically and commercially".<ref name="allmusic"/> Four singles were released from the album. First was "[[Love at the Five and Dime]]",<ref name="allmusic"/> written and originally recorded by [[Nanci Griffith]] on her 1986 album ''[[The Last of the True Believers]]''.<ref name="believers">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-last-of-the-true-believers-mw0000194038|title=''The Last of the True Believers''|last=Planer|first=Lindsay|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Following it was the [[Walk the Way the Wind Blows|title track]], "[[You're the Power]]", and "[[Train of Memories]]". All four of these songs reached the top ten of the country music charts between 1986 and 1987.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Contributing musicians on ''Walk the Way the Wind Blows'' included [[Béla Fleck]], [[Don Williams]] (who sang background vocals on "Love at the Five and Dime"), [[Wendy Waldman]], and [[Vince Gill]].<ref name="walk">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/walk-the-way-the-wind-blows-mw0000650473|title=''Walk the Way the Wind Blows''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> ''Billboard'' praised ''Walk the Way the Wind Blows'' as "Mattea's most country effort to date".<ref>{{cite magazine|date=October 18, 1986|title=Reviews|magazine=Billboard|page=94|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1986/BB-1986-10-18.pdf}}</ref> An un-credited review in ''Stereo Review'' (now [[Sound & Vision (magazine)|''Sound & Vision'']]) stated that "if every country album were as tasteful and well executed as ''Walk the Way the Wind Blows''...the reviewer's life would be a happy one indeed", while rating the performance and recording as "perfection".<ref>{{cite journal|title=''Walk the Way the Wind Blows''|journal=Stereo Review|volume=52|page=190|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X_AOAQAAMAAJ&q=%22walk+the+way+the+wind+blows%22|year=1987}}</ref> Thom Jurek felt that the album's uptempo cuts were stronger than its ballads, noting that "Her ballad singing hadn't gotten to the place it did just three years later" while praising her performances on the more upbeat tracks and on "Love at the Five and Dime".<ref name="walk"/>

[[File:WIKI K MATTEA 0289B.jpg|thumb|left|An autographed photo of Mattea live in concert, 1989.|alt=An autographed photo of singer Kathy Mattea, playing a red guitar and singing into a microphone]]
Mattea had her first number one single in late 1987 to early 1988 with "[[Goin' Gone]]".{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Co-written by [[Pat Alger]] and [[Fred Koller]],{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} this song was also previously recorded by Griffith on the same album as "Love at the Five and Dime".<ref name="believers"/> Mattea's version was the lead single to her fourth album ''[[Untasted Honey]]''. Following it was "[[Eighteen Wheels and a Dozen Roses]]", which became her longest-tenured number one single when it spent two weeks in that position.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} "[[Untold Stories (Kathy Mattea song)|Untold Stories]]" and "[[Life as We Knew It (song)|Life as We Knew It]]" were also released from the album, with both reaching the number four position of the country charts.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} The album also featured bluegrass musician [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], who wrote both "Walk the Way the Wind Blows" and "Untold Stories", as a duet partner on the track "[[The Battle Hymn of Love]]".<ref name="people honey"/>{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Jurek noted the album's bluegrass influences with favor, while comparing "Untold Stories" to the work of [[Bill Monroe]] and praising the lyrics of "Eighteen Wheels and a Dozen Roses".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/untasted-honey-mw0000193250|title=''Untasted Honey''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> ''People'' magazine's review of the album stated that "it’s just Mattea, sounding warm, strong, smart and generally splendid," also commending the lyrical storytelling of "Life as We Knew It" and "Eighteen Wheels and a Dozen Roses".<ref name="people honey">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/archive/picks-and-pans-review-untasted-honey-vol-28-no-20/|title=''Untasted Honey''|date=November 16, 1987|work=People|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

In 1989, she released ''[[Willow in the Wind]]''. This album's first two singles, "[[Come from the Heart]]" (previously recorded by Don Williams on his 1987 album ''Traces''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.don-williams.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/1987DonWilliamsAlbumListWithArtWorkTraces.pdf|title=''Traces''|work=Don Williams official website|access-date=August 10, 2017|archive-date=September 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905150121/http://www.don-williams.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/1987DonWilliamsAlbumListWithArtWorkTraces.pdf|url-status=dead}}</ref>) and "[[Burnin' Old Memories]]", also topped the country charts. After it came the top-ten Hot Country Songs songs "[[Where've You Been]]" (co-written by Mattea's husband, [[Jon Vezner]]) and "[[She Came from Fort Worth]]",{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} the latter of which was a number one single on the ''[[Radio & Records]]'' and ''[[Gavin Report]]'' country music charts.<ref name="encyclopedia"/><ref>{{cite journal|date=May 25, 1990|title=Country|journal=Gavin Report|page=30|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Gavin-Report/90/90/Gavin-1990-05-25.pdf}}</ref> This album featured backing vocals from [[Craig Bickhardt]], [[Riders in the Sky (band)|Riders in the Sky]], [[Jim Photoglo]], and [[Claire Lynch]], with musical contributions from [[Mark O'Connor]], [[Charlie McCoy]], [[Jerry Douglas]], and [[Ray Flacke]].<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Willow in the Wind |others=Kathy Mattea |year=1989 |type=CD insert |publisher=Mercury Records |id=836 950-2}}</ref> Jurek called it "the first completely realized project of her career", and highlighted [[Laurie Lewis]]'s "Love Chooses You" as its strongest cut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/willow-in-the-wind-mw0000199553|title=''Willow in the Wind''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> An uncredited review from ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' was positive, stating that "she’s still not one to rock and roll, but this album has a fair share of swingy, blue-newgrass tracks", and that "Mattea sounds warm and relaxed".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/archive/picks-and-pans-review-willow-in-the-wind-vol-31-no-17/|title=Picks and Pans Review: Willow in the Wind|date=May 1, 1989|work=People|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Comparing Mattea's vocals to [[Linda Ronstadt]] and [[Jennifer Warnes]], Randy Lewis of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that "she treats the songs, most of which are about lives in transition, with the requisite humility and honesty so their simple charms are not inflated into stentorian Author's Messages".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1989-04-30-ca-2809-story.html|title=KATHY MATTEA "Willow in the Wind."|last=Lewis|first=Randy|date=April 30, 1989|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Mattea won the [[Country Music Association]]'s Female Vocalist of the Year award in both 1989 and 1990, and a [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance]] in 1990 for "Where've You Been".<ref name="encyclopedia"/>

===1990{{ndash}}1993: Continued success===
Later in 1990, Mattea released her first greatest hits album, ''[[A Collection of Hits]]''. The album included eight of her previous singles, plus "The Battle Hymn of Love" from ''Untasted Honey'' and the new recording "[[A Few Good Things Remain]]". Both were released as singles in 1990 and reached the Top 10 of Hot Country Songs, with "The Battle Hymn of Love" representing O'Brien's only chart entry to date.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} "A Few Good Things Remain" was also featured on her next studio album, 1991's ''[[Time Passes By]]''. This project produced three singles: the [[Time Passes By (song)|title track]] reached the top ten, but "[[Whole Lotta Holes]]" and "[[Asking Us to Dance]]" were less successful.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} The album included [[Celtic music]] influences and was partially recorded in Scotland.<ref name="larkin"/> Reynolds continued to serve as producer for this album except for the closing track, a cover of "[[From a Distance]]", which Mattea and Vezner produced with [[Dougie MacLean]].<ref name="larkin">{{cite book|last=Larkin|first=Colin|title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Country Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wi_aAAAAMAAJ&q=%22kathy+mattea%22+%22dougie+maclean%22+%22From+a+distance%22|year=1998|page=269|publisher=Virgin |isbn=9780753502365}}</ref> Contributors on backing vocals included [[Trisha Yearwood]] (on "Time Passes By"), [[The Roches]] (on "Whole Lotta Holes"), [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Craig Bickhardt]], and [[Ashley Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Time Passes By |others=Kathy Mattea |year=1991 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Mercury Records |id=846 975-2}}</ref> Rating it "A", [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' called the album "a quiet, reflective acoustic collection."<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://ew.com/article/1991/04/05/time-passes/|title=''Time Passes By'' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|date=April 5, 1991|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> [[Brian Mansfield]] noted in Allmusic that it was "her most ambitious album" and had "impeccably chosen songs".<ref name="passes">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/time-passes-by-mw0000674386|title=''Time Passes By'' review|last=Mansfield|first=Brian|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

[[File:Tim O'Brien at Knicely's Big Winter Concert Franklin Park Round Hill VA February 2012.jpg|150px|thumb|right|[[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]] sang duet vocals on Mattea's 1990 single "[[The Battle Hymn of Love]]".|alt=Bluegrass singer Tim O'Brien, singing into a microphone while holding a mandolin]]
Her 1992 album, ''[[Lonesome Standard Time]]'', produced a number 11 country hit in its [[Lonesome Standard Time (song)|title track]], plus the Top 20 "[[Standing Knee Deep in a River (Dying of Thirst)]]". Yet its followups ("Seeds" and "Listen to the Radio") failed to enter the country top 40.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} This was also her first album to be produced by [[Brent Maher]], best known for his work with [[The Judds]].<ref name="cd">{{cite journal|title=Lonesome Standard Time|journal=CD Review|volume=9|issue=1–6|page=92|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZSU9AQAAIAAJ&q=%22kathy+mattea%22+%22Lonesome+standard+time%22+%22maher%22|year=1992}}</ref> Nash rated it "B", saying that "not even the driving bluegrass of the title tune is enough to transcend the album’s ultrareflective mood. Mattea’s husky mezzo-soprano remains a thrilling instrument, however".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://ew.com/article/1992/10/30/lonesome-standard-time/|title=Lonesome Standard Time|last=Nash|first=Alanna|date=October 30, 1992|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> ''CD Review'' noted that the album seemed "familiar" despite the change in producers and session musicians: "a couple of whimsical numbers, a couple of bluesy laments for love gone wrong, a let's-get-away-from-it-all love song" while praising the lyrical content of "Standing Knee Deep in a River" and "Seeds".<ref name="cd"/> In June 1992, Mattea experienced a burst blood vessel on her vocals.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=417}} She was required to undergo vocal rest and surgery to "repair years of overuse" on her vocal cords.<ref name="encyclopedia"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/1992/12/25/kathy-mattea-worked-voice-back-into-shape/|title=Kathy Mattea Worked Voice Back Into Shape|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=December 25, 1992|work=Orlando Sentinel|access-date=August 11, 2017}}</ref>

After recovering, she issued her first Christmas album, ''[[Good News (Kathy Mattea album)|Good News]]'', in September 1993. It featured largely original compositions, plus renditions of the hymn "[[Brightest and Best]]" and the contemporary Christian tune "[[Mary, Did You Know?]]" Thom Jurek wrote of its sound, "This doesn't feel like any Christmas record you've ever heard before...It sounds like a well-crafted, gorgeously wrought folk/country/Celtic-flavored Kathy Mattea record."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/good-news-mw0000103930|title=''Good News''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> This album won that year's [[Grammy Award for Best Southern, Country or Bluegrass Gospel Album]].<ref name="Grammy">{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/kathy-mattea|title=Grammy results for Kathy Mattea|work=grammy.com|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Maher again served as producer, with further production from Reynolds on one track.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Good News |others=Kathy Mattea |year=1993 |publisher=Mercury Records |id=314 518 059 2}}</ref>

===1994{{ndash}}2000: Later years with Mercury===
Mattea released ''[[Walking Away a Winner]]'' in 1994. Produced by [[Josh Leo]], the album was more rock and pop influenced than its predecessors,<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://ew.com/article/1994/05/20/walking-away-winner/|title=''Walking Away a Winner'' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|date=May 20, 1994|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=August 10, 2017|archive-date=August 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811055209/http://ew.com/article/1994/05/20/walking-away-winner/|url-status=dead}}</ref> with Thom Jurek of Allmusic comparing its sound to [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] and [[Bonnie Raitt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/walking-away-a-winner-mw0000113913|title=''Walking Away a Winner''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Nash noted the "bigger" sound of the album, but praised its "style and substance".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://ew.com/article/1994/05/20/walking-away-winner/|title=''Walking Away a Winner'' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|date=May 20, 1994|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=August 22, 2017|archive-date=August 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811055209/http://ew.com/article/1994/05/20/walking-away-winner/|url-status=dead}}</ref> The [[Walking Away a Winner (song)|title track]] charted at number three on the country charts in 1994. It was followed by "[[Nobody's Gonna Rain on Our Parade]]", "[[Maybe She's Human]]", and "[[Clown in Your Rodeo]]".{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} The album featured backing vocals from [[Lisa Angelle]], [[Karla Bonoff]], [[Andrew Gold]], and [[Hal Ketchum]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Walking Away a Winner |others=Kathy Mattea |year=1994 |type=CD liner notes |publisher=Mercury Records |id= 518852}}</ref> Also in 1994, Mattea had a cameo in the movie ''[[Maverick (film)|Maverick]]'',<ref name="cameo">{{cite web|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/1994/02/04/maverick-cameo-made-matteas-year/|title='Maverick' Cameo Made Mattea's Year|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=February 4, 1994|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=October 16, 2017}}</ref> whose [[Maverick (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] also featured her as one of several lead vocalists on a multi-artist rendition of "[[Amazing Grace]]".<ref name="liner">{{Cite AV media notes |title=Maverick |others=Various artists |year=1994 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Atlantic Records |id=82595}}</ref>

Mattea spent the entirety of 1996 off the charts before returning with ''[[Love Travels]]'' in 1997. Its lead single was "[[455 Rocket]]", which reached number 21. It was followed by the [[Love Travels (song)|title track]], which reached the top 40.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} Mattea noted that in the process of recording "455 Rocket," the band recorded multiple takes but chose to keep the first one because "no one thought they were being recorded, and everyone was just playing with abandon."<ref name="definitive"/> Musicians on this album included bassist [[Hutch Hutchinson]], drummers [[Abe Laboriel Jr.]] and [[Jim Keltner]], and guitarist [[Duke Levine]]; contributing backing vocalists included [[Kim Richey]], [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], [[Jonatha Brooke]], and [[Mary Ann Kennedy (American singer)|Mary Ann Kennedy]]. [[Lionel Cartwright]] wrote "If That's What You Call Love", which also featured him on piano and background vocals, and [[Phil Keaggy]] played guitar on the closing track "Beautiful Fool".<ref name="travels liner">{{cite AV media notes |title=Love Travels |others=Kathy Mattea |year=1997 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Mercury Nashville |id=314 532 899 2}}</ref> Thom Owens of Allmusic stated that "though the glossy production may put off some of her old country-folk fans, ''Love Travels'' is a typically tasteful and compelling record".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/love-travels-mw0000080698|title=''Love Travels''|last=Owens|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Bob Cannon of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised the inclusion of [[Gillian Welch]] and [[Cheryl Wheeler]] songs, calling it "her most mature and focused work yet."<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://ew.com/article/1997/02/14/love-travels/|title=''Love Travels''|last=Cannon|first=Bob|date=February 14, 1997|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

Her last Mercury album was ''[[The Innocent Years]]'' in 2000. Before the album's release, Mattea returned to West Virginia to care for her father, who had been diagnosed with colon cancer. She said that this resulted in a very intermittent recording process, but also informed the album's content; she told ''[[Country Standard Time]]'', "I spent a lot of time thinking about what's important to me. I think this is an album about those things."<ref name="cst"/> Although Mattea rarely writes her material, she wrote two songs on the album with Vezner.<ref name="cst"/> The album's final track, a novelty song called "BFD", was included as a bonus track because it was popular with fans, but she was unsure of how to sequence it with the rest of the album.<ref name="cst">{{cite journal|title=Kathy Mattea lives through the innocent years|last=Remz|first=Jeffrey B.|journal=Country Standard Time}} [http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=587 Page 1], [http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/articlex.asp?xid=587&p=2 page 2], [http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/articlex.asp?xid=587&p=3 page 3]</ref> "The Trouble with Angels" and "BFD" made the Hot Country Songs charts in 2000, although neither made Top 40.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} ''Country Standard Time'' reviewer Eli Messinger wrote that "though the smooth sound and heart-on-her-sleeve lyrics may not be for the country roots fan...Mattea's superb voice and mature readings are clearly the work of an accomplished artist chasing her musical muse."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1616|title=''The Innocent Years''|last=Messinger|first=Eli|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

===2002–present: Music transition and bluegrass===
For 2002's ''[[Roses (Kathy Mattea album)|Roses]]'', Mattea moved to [[Narada Productions]]. She said that she chose to work with this label after leaving Mercury because she felt that the label would "give [her] alternative marketing ideas" and "didn't see [her] musical restlessness as a liability". She said that she wanted to keep a contemporary folk and Celtic influence. Mattea supported the album with a tour largely focused on performing arts centers. Narada serviced "They Are the Roses" to [[Adult Contemporary]] and country stations, and "I'm Alright" to [[Adult album alternative]] and [[Americana music]] formats.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Stark|first=Phyllis|date=July 27, 2002|title=Mattea blooms on Narada debut 'Roses'|magazine=Billboard|page=9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AAwEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22kathy+mattea%22+%22Roses%22&pg=PA9}}</ref> Maria Konicki Dinoia wrote in Allmusic that "she pushes the envelope, bringing to the forefront the blending of the Scottish/Irish music found in small doses on her last few albums."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/roses-mw0000226669|title=''Roses''|last=Dinoia|first=Maria Konicki|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> One year later, she released her second Christmas disc, ''[[Joy for Christmas Day]]'', which continued in her Celtic music influences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/joy-for-christmas-day-mw0000039421|title=''Joy for Christmas Day''|last=Widran|first=Jonathan|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> This album was inspired by her annual Christmas tours that she had done ever since the release of ''Good News''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nodepression.com/article/kathy-matteas-musical-journey-brings-her-closer-home|title=Kathy Mattea's Musical Journey Brings Her Closer to Home|last=Bonfiglio|first=Jeremy|date=December 13, 2014|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|access-date=August 11, 2017}}</ref>

[[File:Kathy Mattea - Cambridge Festivals 2001-2014 (4854618114).jpg|thumb|Mattea at the 2010 [[Cambridge Folk Festival]] in England|alt=Country music singer Kathy Mattea singing into a microphone while strumming a guitar.]]
Her third overall album for Narada was 2005's ''[[Right Out of Nowhere]]''. Produced entirely by Mattea, the album included covers of [[The Rolling Stones]]' "[[Gimme Shelter]]" and [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]]'s "[[Down on the Corner]]",<ref name="right allmusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/right-out-of-nowhere-mw0000642247|title=''Right Out of Nowhere''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> along with a rendition of the spiritual "[[Wade in the Water]]".<ref name="right country">{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1614|title=''Right Out of Nowhere''|last=MacIntosh|first=Dan|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Allmusic and ''Country Standard Time'' both reviewed these covers in particular with favor, with the latter's Dan MacIntosh also noting that "Mattea chooses songs that are mostly optimistic, even though hers is a kind of hard-won optimism."<ref name="right country"/>

The bluegrass album ''[[Coal (Kathy Mattea album)|Coal]]'' followed in 2008. Mattea released this album independently on her own Captain Potato Records. Mattea said that she chose to do an album themed to coal mining after the [[Sago Mine disaster]], and worked with country and bluegrass singer [[Marty Stuart]] as her producer.<ref name=today>{{cite web | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2008-04-06-mattea-coal_N.htm | title=Kathy Mattea's 'Coal' fueled by an emotional kinship | work=[[USA Today]] | date=April 6, 2008 | access-date=August 1, 2014 | author=Mansfield, Brian}}</ref> She said that she was unsure about recording the song "Black Lung" until Stuart noted that the recording engineer on the session had gotten emotional and begun to cry during her take on the song.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2008/04/18/matteas-spare-approach-reveals-coal-minings-core/ | title=Mattea's spare approach reveals coal mining's core | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=April 18, 2008 | access-date=August 1, 2014 | author=Dickinson, Chrissie}}</ref> A second album of bluegrass-influenced and primiarly coal mining-themed songs, ''[[Calling Me Home (Kathy Mattea album)|Calling Me Home]]'', followed in 2014 on [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/calling-me-home-mw0002410618|title=''Calling Me Home''|last=Jurek|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

In the mid 2010s, Mattea began having problems with gaining control of her singing voice. The problems (which stemmed from the effects of [[menopause]]), caused her to question whether she should continue performing altogether. She began working with a [[vocal coach]] who helped her find her singing voice again. This resulted in her next studio album.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Dauphin |first1=Chuck |title=After Almost Losing Control of Her Voice, Kathy Mattea Returns With 'Pretty Bird'|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/kathy-mattea-pretty-bird-interview-8478359/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=24 November 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Edes |first1=Alyssa |last2=Louise Kelly |first2=Mary |title=How Kathy Mattea Got Her Voice Back With 'Pretty Bird' |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/09/19/649318596/how-kathy-mattea-got-back-her-voice-with-pretty-bird |access-date=24 November 2022 |work=[[NPR]] |date=September 19, 2018}}</ref> In 2018, ''[[Pretty Bird (album)|Pretty Bird]]'', was released independently with Tim O'Brien serving as producer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2018/07/kathy-mattea-releases-track-from-first-album-in-six-years/|title=Kathy Mattea Releases Track From First Album In Six Years|last=Parker|first=Eric T.|date=July 13, 2018|work=MusicRow|access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref> The album's first single is a cover of [[Martha Carson]]'s "I Can't Stand Up Alone", recorded as a tribute to [[Jesse Winchester]]. Also included on the album are covers of [[The Wood Brothers]]' "Chocolate on My Tongue", [[Bobbie Gentry]]'s "[[Ode to Billie Joe]]", and [[Joan Osborne]]'s "St. Teresa",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hear-kathy-matteas-sing-martha-carsons-i-cant-stand-up-alone-698554/|title=Hear Kathy Mattea's Cover of Martha Carson's 'I Can't Stand Up Alone'|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=July 12, 2018|work=Rolling Stone Country|access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref> the last of which is the album's second single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/kathy-mattea-shares-heavy-rendition-of-st-teresa-listen/|title=KATHY MATTEA SHARES HEAVY RENDITION OF 'ST. TERESA' [LISTEN]|last=Liptak|first=Carena|date=August 14, 2018|work=The Boot|access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref>

In 2021, Mattea became the new host of the ''[[Mountain Stage]]'', a program that is aired by West Virginia's [[NPR]] network.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Miller |first1=Jan N. |title=Grammy-winning country music queen Kathy Mattea is 'happy to play music again' in Plymouth |url=https://www.patriotledger.com/story/entertainment/2021/10/26/grammy-winning-country-music-queen-kathy-mattea-perform-plymouth/6121850001/ |access-date=24 November 2022 |work=[[The Patriot Ledger]] |date=October 26, 2021}}</ref> The program broadcasts once a week in two hour-long episodes that are aired on 280 stations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Get to Know Mountain Stage |url=https://mountainstage.org/ |website=[[Mountain Stage]] |access-date=24 November 2022}}</ref>

==Artistry==
===Musical styles===
Mattea's music was categorized as country during her years as a commercial recording artist.<ref name="allmusic"/> During her peak success, Mattea also included elements of [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Celtic music|Celtic]] and [[Folk music|folk]] into her artistry.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lauer-Williams |first1=Kathy |title=Train and Mattea coming to Musikfest |url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-2006-03-17-3648293-story.html |access-date=25 November 2022 |work=[[The Morning Call]] |date=March 17, 2006}}</ref> Authors Mary A. Bufwack and [[Robert K. Oermann]] noted that Mattea was part of a group of country artists that took inspiration from the [[American folk music revival|American folk revival]] by incorporating "modern sensibilities to create powerfully appealing images". Bufwack and Oermann found her counterparts to be [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], and [[Wynonna Judd]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=415}} Writer Thomas Harrison found that Mattea also had elements of "Southern California Rock" that mixed in "mountain elements" because she often incorporated the acoustic guitar.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Harrison |first1=Thomas |title=Pop Goes the Decade: The Eighties |date=2017 |publisher=[[ABC-Clio]] |isbn=9781440836671 |page=97}}</ref> After recording 2008's ''Coal'', Mattea's musical identity shifted towards [[Appalachian music]] and has since made it a part of her artistry.<ref name="Billboard">{{cite magazine |last1=Dauphin |first1=Chuck |title=Kathy Mattea Strips Away Old Habits on ''Calling Me Home'' |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=September 13, 2012 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/kathy-mattea-strips-away-old-habits-on-calling-me-home-475124/ |access-date=25 November 2022}}</ref>

===Collaborations===
Mattea participated in several collaborative works, primarily in the 1990s. In March 1991, Mattea was one of several artists on "[[Voices That Care]]", a charity single to help boost the morale of U.S. troops involved in [[Operation Desert Storm]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332494/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|title=Voices That Care cast|work=IMDb|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> [[Dolly Parton]]'s 1993 single "[[Romeo (Dolly Parton song)|Romeo]]" featured guest vocals from Mattea, [[Tanya Tucker]], [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]], [[Pam Tillis]], and [[Billy Ray Cyrus]].{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|pp=254–255}} Mattea appeared on two tracks from the 1994 ''[[Red Hot + Country]]'' compilation, put out by the [[AIDS]] activism group [[Red Hot Organization]]. The first of these was a cover of "[[Teach Your Children]]" which also featured [[Suzy Bogguss]], [[Alison Krauss]], and [[Crosby, Stills & Nash]], and the second was a duet with [[Jackson Browne]] titled "Rock Me on the Water".<ref name="encyclopedia"/> The former, credited to "The Red Hots", charted at No.&nbsp;75 on Hot Country Songs dated for October 22, 1994.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|pp=274}} Also in 1994, Mattea sang duet vocals on [[Johnny Hallyday]]'s "Love Affair",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rough-town-mw0000672648|title=''Rough Town''|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> which made No.&nbsp;35 on the French [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique]] (SNEP) charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lescharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Johnny+Hallyday|title=Johnny Hallyday|work=lescharts.com|access-date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> In 1998, Mattea recorded a duet with [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]] titled "Among the Missing", a charity single to help benefit the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] (NCMEC). It was written by [[Peter McCann]] and produced by [[George Massenburg]], and a video of the performance was also issued on DVD.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Verna|first=Paul|date=December 12, 1998|title=Emerald, Masterfonics confirm negotiations for buyout|magazine=Billboard|page=47|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KwoEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22michael+mcdonald%22+%22among+the+missing%22&pg=PA65-IA2}}</ref> The song charted for a single week at No.&nbsp;73 on Hot Country Songs dated for March 27, 1999.{{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}}

==Personal life==
[[File:Sellersville Theatre 2019.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Mattea has been married to [[Jon Vezner]] since 1988; he has also written several of her singles.|alt=Country music singer Jon Vezner, singing while playing an acoustic guitar]]
Mattea has been married to songwriter [[Jon Vezner]] since February 14, 1988.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|2003|p=416}} He started a publishing company underneath the apartment in which Mattea lived in the 1980s, and the two met after he jump-started her car. Vezner wrote four of Mattea's singles: "Where've You Been", "Whole Lotta Holes", "Time Passes By", and "A Few Good Things Remain", along with singles by [[Diamond Rio]] and [[Clay Walker]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yamaha.com/artists/jonvezner.html|title=Jon Vezner biography|work=Yamaha.com|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref> The couple briefly separated in the early 2000s, but later reconciled.<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news |last1=Harrington |first1=Richard |title=Hard Times Can't Keep Mattea Down |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2005/11/04/hard-times-cant-keep-mattea-down/6da21192-cae2-4677-b751-ccb55dd3f815/ |access-date=21 November 2022 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 4, 2005}}</ref> "All marriages have their moments when things don't run smoothly," Vezner stated, "but neither of us walks away when things get difficult. We challenge each other and learn from each other."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Evans Price |first1=Deborah |last2=Stefano |first2=Angela |title=Kathy Mattea + Jon Vezner -- Country's Greatest Love Stories |url=https://theboot.com/kathy-mattea-jon-vezner-love-stories/ |website=The Boot |date=February 12, 2021 |access-date=24 November 2022}}</ref> Mattea and Vezner do not have children but have had both cats and dogs.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Burns |first1=Mark |title=NBT Interview:Kathy Mattea Musically Restless Kathy Mattea |journal=Bay Weekly |date=September 3–9, 1998 |url=https://bayweekly.com/old-site/year98/leadII6_35.html |access-date=25 November 2022}}</ref> The couple currently resides in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Havighurst |first1=Craig |title=Kathy Mattea Takes Over The Host Mic At WV's Mountain Stage |url=https://www.wmot.org/roots-radio-news/2021-09-09/kathy-mattea-takes-over-the-host-mic-at-wvs-mountain-stage |website=[[WMOT]] |date=September 9, 2021 |access-date=24 November 2022}}</ref> In 2003, Mattea's father died following a long battle with [[colon cancer]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Kathy Mattea on New Album, Voice Struggles, Grappling With Loss |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=October 1, 2018 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kathy-mattea-interview-pretty-bird-voice-trouble-731403/ |access-date=24 November 2022}}</ref> In 2005, Mattea's mother died due to complications of [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Funeral Services Scheduled for Kathy Mattea's Mother |url=https://www.cmt.com/news/ascfs8/funeral-services-scheduled-for-kathy-matteas-mother |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221124013130/https://www.cmt.com/news/ascfs8/funeral-services-scheduled-for-kathy-matteas-mother |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 24, 2022 |access-date=24 November 2022 |work=[[Country Music Television]] |date=August 12, 2005}}</ref>

Mattea is known for her roles in AIDS activism. In 1992, many televised awards shows were handing out red ribbons to participants in honor of AIDS awareness, but the [[Country Music Association]] chose to hand out green ribbons promoting environmental awareness instead. Mattea chose to wear three red ribbons that night, each one honoring a friend of hers who had died of the disease, along with the green ribbon.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2006/7/23/229961/-|title=Liberal Country Artist of the Week: Kathy Mattea|date=July 23, 2006|work=Daily KOS|access-date=October 16, 2017}}</ref> A 1994 article in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' noted that a Nashville newspaper interpreted a comment she had made on wearing both color ribbons as a confrontation, and that Mattea was often questioned as to whether her activism had a negative impact on sales of her then-current album.<ref name="cameo"/> Besides her participation in the ''Red Hot + Country'' charity album series, Mattea also participated in charity concerts and made public appearances in activism campaigns. She was also the recipient of the inaugural [[Harvard AIDS Initiative]] award in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1994/12/15/taking-notice-3/|title=Taking Notice Kathy Mattea Earns Honors For Her Aids Work|date=December 15, 1994|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=October 16, 2017}}</ref>
{{Clear}}

{{main|List of awards and nominations received by Kathy Mattea}}

'''Jackie Keith Whitley''' (July 1, 1954 – May 9, 1989) was an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. During his career, he released only two albums but charted 12 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, and 7 more after his death.

Born in [[Ashland, Kentucky]], Whitley grew up in nearby [[Sandy Hook, Kentucky]]. He began his career there in 1970, performing in [[Ralph Stanley]]'s band. Establishing himself as a lead singer in bluegrass music, Whitley moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 1983 and began his recording career there. His first Top 20 Country Hit single, "[[Miami, My Amy]]", was released in 1986. In 1988, his first three singles from his studio album ''[[Don't Close Your Eyes (album)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]'', the [[Don't Close Your Eyes (Keith Whitley song)|title song]], "[[When You Say Nothing at All]]" and "[[I'm No Stranger to the Rain]]" were number one hits. Years of alcoholism severely compromised his health and he died of alcohol intoxication in 1989 at his Goodlettsville home at the age of 34. His later singles, "[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me (song)|I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]",  "[[It Ain't Nothin']]", and "[[I'm Over You (Keith Whitley song)|I'm Over You]]", were released after his death.

In 2022, Whitley was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name="cmhof">{{cite web | url=https://eu.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2022/05/17/country-music-hall-fame-class-2022-inductees/9805843002/ | title=Keith Whitley, Jerry Lee Lewis and Joe Galante are headed to the Country Music Hall of Fame }}</ref>

==Early life==
Whitley was born to Faye Ferguson (editor of ''The Elliott County News'') and Elmer Whitley (an electrician) in [[Ashland, Kentucky]], but was raised 46 miles away in [[Sandy Hook, Kentucky|Sandy Hook]], and attended Sandy Hook High School.<ref name=HicksJ-TKP-1991-09-25>Hicks, Jack. – "Singer Keith Whitley's Memory Alive Through Songs, Love in Home Town". – ''[[The Cincinnati Post|The Kentucky Post]]''. – September 25, 1991.</ref><ref name=LH-L-1989-05-10>"Country Music Star Keith Whitley Dead at 33". – ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''. – May 10, 1989.</ref> He had two brothers, Randy and Dwight, and a sister, Mary.<ref name=LockwoodFE-LH-L-1998-06-27>Lockwood, Frank E. – "Bikers, Sandy Hook Pay Tribute to Favorite Son". – Lexington Herald-Leader (KY) – Saturday, June 27, 1998.</ref><ref name=LockwoodFE-LH-L-1999-06-28>Lockwood, Frank E. – "Singing in Rain". – Lexington Herald-Leader (KY) – Saturday, June 28, 1999.</ref> The Whitley family is of [[English Americans|English]] and [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Scots-Irish]] descent and has lived in the [[Elliott County, Kentucky|Elliott County]] area since the 1840s.

While Whitley was a teenager in Sandy Hook, he and his friends would pass the time drinking [[Rum-running|bootleg]] [[Bourbon whiskey|bourbon]] and racing their cars down mountain roads at dangerous speeds. Whitley was once in a car whose driver attempted to round a curve at {{convert|120|mph|kph}}. The car wrecked, killing his friend and almost breaking Whitley's neck. In another incident, he drove his car off a {{convert|120|ft|m|adj=on}} cliff into a frozen river, escaping with only a broken [[collar bone]].<ref name=AP>Associated Press – "Whitley Just Getting Started Despite 18-Year Music Career". – Salina Journal (KS) – Thursday, October 27, 1988.</ref>

Whitley's older brother Randy was killed in an October 1983 motorcycle accident.<ref name="HicksJ-TKP-1991-09-25" /><ref name="LockwoodFE-LH-L-1998-06-27" />

==Musical career==
Whitley is known for his neotraditional brand of country popularized by hit artists such as [[George Strait]] and [[Randy Travis]].

In 1969, he performed in a musical contest in [[Ezel, Kentucky]], with brother Dwight on five-string banjo. [[Ricky Skaggs]] was also in the contest. Skaggs and Whitley instantly bonded and subsequently became close friends.<ref name=RoweN-RT-D-1986-04-20>Rowe, Norman. – Album Echoes Country Classics". – ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''. – April 20, 1986</ref>

Whitley and Skaggs, both sixteen years old, were discovered in Ft. Gay, West Virginia, by [[Ralph Stanley]], who was 45 minutes late for a gig due to a flat tire.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Stanley opened the door of the club and heard what he thought was the [[Stanley Brothers]] playing on a jukebox. However, it was Whitley and Skaggs, who "sounded just like me and Carter in the early days".{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} The two soon joined Stanley's band. Whitley became lead singer for Stanley in 1974.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}  Whitley also played with [[J.D. Crowe & the New South]] in the mid-1970s.<ref name=AP/> During this period, he established himself as one of the most versatile and talented lead singers in bluegrass. His singing was heavily influenced by [[Carter Stanley]] and [[Lefty Frizzell]]. He moved to [[Nashville]] in 1983 to pursue a country music career and soon signed a record deal with [[RCA Records]].<ref name=AP/>

Whitley's first solo album, ''A Hard Act to Follow'', was released in 1984, and featured a more mainstream country style. While Whitley was working hard to achieve his own style, the songs he produced were inconsistent. Critics regarded the album as too erratic. Whitley honed his sound within the next few years for his next album, ''L.A. to Miami''.

''L.A. to Miami'', released in 1985, would give him his first Top 20 country hit single, "Miami, My Amy". The song was followed by three more hit songs: "Ten Feet Away", "Homecoming '63", and "Hard Livin'", The album also included "[[On the Other Hand]]" and "[[Nobody in His Right Mind Would've Left Her]]". "On the Other Hand" was pitched to Whitley before [[Randy Travis]] released the song as a single and when Whitley's version wasn't released as a single, Travis released his in 1986, as did [[George Strait]] with "Nobody in His Right Mind Would've Left Her".

During his tour to promote ''L.A. to Miami'', he met and began a romantic relationship with country singer [[Lorrie Morgan]]. They were married in November 1986 and  had their only child, a son, Jesse Keith Whitley in June 1987. Whitley also adopted Lorrie's daughter, Morgan, from her first marriage.

During the new recording sessions in 1987, Whitley began feeling that the songs he was  were not up to his standards, so he approached RCA and asked if the project of 15 songs could be shelved. He also asked if he could take a major role in creating the songs and in production. The new album, titled ''[[Don't Close Your Eyes (album)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]'', was released in 1988, and the album sold extremely well. The album contained one of the many songs that Whitley had a hand in writing in his years at Tree Publishing, "It's All Coming Back to Me Now". On the album was a remake of [[Lefty Frizzell]]'s classic standard "I Never Go Around Mirrors," and the song became a huge hit at Whitley's concerts. The first three singles from the album—"When You Say Nothing at All," "I'm No Stranger to the Rain," and the title cut—all reached No. 1 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s country charts during the autumn of 1988 and the winter of 1989, with the title track "Don't Close Your Eyes" being ranked as ''Billboard''’s No. 1 Country song of 1988. Shortly thereafter, "I'm No Stranger to the Rain" also earned Whitley his first and only [[Country Music Association]] award as a solo artist and a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance|Best Country Vocal Performance, Male]].

In early 1989, Whitley approached RCA chairman [[Joe Galante]] with the intention of releasing "I Never Go Around Mirrors" as a single. Galante approved of the musical flexibility that Whitley achieved with the song; however, he suggested that Whitley record something new and more upbeat. The result was a song Whitley had optioned for his previous album called ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]'', and was to result in his next album release.

Whitley was scheduled to be invited to join the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]'' in late May 1989. He was posthumously inducted as a former member on October 14, 2023, in a tribute concert held during that night's ''Opry'' broadcast.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Keith Whitley to be celebrated by Garth Brooks, more, at October Opry event |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/09/15/keith-whitley-to-be-celebrated-by-garth-brooks-more-at-october-opry-event/70863977007/ |access-date=2023-10-15 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}}</ref>

==Death==
On May 9, 1989, Whitley had a brief phone call with his mother and was later visited by his brother-in-law, Lane Palmer.  The two had coffee and were planning a day of golf and lunch, after which Whitley planned to start writing songs for him and Lorrie Morgan to record when she returned from her concert tour. Palmer left at approximately {{nowrap|8:30 a.m.}},<ref name=JinkinsS-FWST-1997-10-14>Jinkins, Shirley. – "A country music love story of death, drinking and devotion". – ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''. – October 14, 1997.</ref> asking Whitley to be ready to leave within an hour. Upon returning, Palmer found Whitley unresponsive on his bed and called an ambulance. Whitley was taken to the hospital where he was pronounced dead. He was 34.

The official cause of death was acute ethanolism ([[alcohol poisoning]]).<ref name=LH-L-1989-05-10 /> [[Davidson County, Tennessee|Davidson County]] Medical Examiner Charles Harlan stated that Whitley's blood alcohol level was 0.47 (the equivalent of 20 one-ounce shots of 100-[[proof (alcohol)|proof]] whiskey).<ref>"Alcohol Cuts Short a promising career". – [[Associated Press]]. – (c/o ''[[Salina Journal]]''). – August 10, 1989.</ref><ref>Edwards, Joe. – "Keith Whitley discovered dead – Alcohol overdose cause of death". – ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]''. – May 10, 1989.</ref><ref name=AP-CT-1989-05-10>"Country Singer Keith Whitley, 33". – [[Associated Press]]. – (c/o ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''). – May 10, 1989.</ref><ref>Hurst, Jack. – "Whitley's Last Days". – ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. – May 14, 1989.</ref><ref>Green, Barbara. – "Whitley Fans Hate 'To See a Good Man Go To Waste". – ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''. – May 17, 1989.</ref> He was born in 1954 per his birth certificate and passport, but RCA and his [[Headstone|grave marker]] erroneously recorded his birth year as 1955.<ref name=WhitburnJ-TBBofT40CH-p382>Whitburn, Joel (2006). – ''The Billboard Book of Top 40 Country Hits''. – Second Edition. – New York: Billboard Books. – p.382. – {{ISBN|978-0-8230-8291-9}}.</ref><ref name="Birth-Year">Stambler, Irwin, and Grelun Landon (2000). – ''Country Music: The Encyclopedia''. – New York: St. Martin's Press. – p.533. – {{ISBN|978-0-312-26487-1}}.<br />—Carlin, Richard (2003). – ''Country Music: A Biographical Dictionary''. – New York: Routledge – p.427. – {{ISBN|978-0-415-93802-0}}.<br />—Larkin, Colin (1995). – ''The Guinness Encyclopedia of Popular Music''. – New York: Stockton Press – P.4462. – {{ISBN|978-0-85112-662-3}}.<br />—Stanton, Scott (2003). – ''The Tombstone Tourist: Musicians''. – New York: Pocket Books. – p.395. – {{ISBN|978-0-7434-6330-0}}.<br />—Hicks, Jack. – "Singer Keith Whitley's Memory Alive Through Songs, Love in Home Town". – ''[[The Cincinnati Post|The Kentucky Post]]''. – September 25, 1991.<br />—"Country Music Star Keith Whitley Dead at 33". – ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''. – May 10, 1989.<br />—Hurst, Jack. – "Whitley's Last Days". – ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. – May 14, 1989.<br />—"Alcohol Kills Country Singer Keith Whitley". – [[United Press International]]. – (c/o ''[[The San Francisco Chronicle]]''). – May 10, 1989.</ref>

The day after his death, [[Music Row]] was lined with black ribbons in memory of Whitley. He is buried in the [[Spring Hill Cemetery (Nashville)|Spring Hill Cemetery]] outside [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]. His gravestone reads, "Forever yours faithfully" (part one) and "His being was my reason" (part two).

==Posthumous releases==
At the time of his death, Whitley had just finished work on his third and final studio album, ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]''. The album was released three months after his death, on August 1, 1989. The album produced two more No.&nbsp;1 hits, with the title track and "It Ain't Nothin'." "I'm Over You" also was in the Top 5 in early 1990, reaching No. 3.

Two new songs were added to "Greatest Hits": The first, "Tell Lorrie I Love Her" was written and recorded at home by Whitley for Morgan, originally intended as a work tape for Whitley's friend Curtis 'Mr. Harmony' Young to sing at Whitley's wedding. The second was "'Til a Tear Becomes a Rose", a 1987 demo taken from Tree that originally featured harmony vocals by childhood friend Ricky Skaggs. Lorrie Morgan, with creative control and license to Whitley's namesake, recorded her voice alongside Whitley's, and released it as a single, which rose to No. 13 and won them 1990's CMA award for Best Vocal Collaboration as well as a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].

RCA also released a compilation of performance clips (from his days in the Ralph Stanley-Fronted Clinch Mountain Boys), interviews, and some previously unreleased material under the title "Kentucky Bluebird". The album produced hits for Whitley as well, including a duet with [[Earl Thomas Conley]], named "Brotherly Love," which peaked at No. 2 in late 1991 and gave Whitley his second consecutive posthumous Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].

In 1994, Whitley's widow, Lorrie Morgan, organized several of Whitley's friends in bluegrass and some of the big names in country at the time to record a [[tribute]] album to Whitley. The album, ''[[Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album]]'', was released in September 1994 via BNA. It included covers of Whitley's songs from artists such as [[Alan Jackson]], [[Diamond Rio]], and Ricky Skaggs. The album also included four previously unreleased tracks recorded by Whitley in 1987, one of which had Morgan dubbed in as a duet partner. The album also included two original songs: "Little Boy Lost", co-written and sung by [[Daron Norwood]], and "A Voice Still Rings True", a multi-artist song.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1994/08/11/crowning-touch-3/|title=Crowning Touch 'Red Hot + Country' Album Delayed To Include Crosby, Stills And Nash|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=August 11, 1994|work=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=February 17, 2014}}</ref> [[Alison Krauss]]'s rendition of "When You Say Nothing at All" was released as a single from the album, reaching number 3 on the country charts in 1995.

In 1995, the album ''Wherever You Are Tonight'' was released, produced by Lorrie Morgan, featuring restored demos of 1986–1988, with crisper 1990s recording techniques and a full orchestra. The album and single of the same name both did very well on the Billboard and R&R charts and "Super Hits" and "The Essential Keith Whitley" followed in 1996. "The Essential" contained the remastered and long since unavailable LP and Whitley's debut, the 6-Track "A Hard Act to Follow", and a scrapped song from 1986's "LA to Miami", "I Wonder Where You Are Tonight".

==Legacy==
Several film projects depicting Whitley's life were slated, but none have come to fruition. One idea was a film version of the George Vescey-Lorrie Morgan-penned ''Forever Yours, Faithfully''. While Morgan's book was a benchmark in piecing together Whitley's final moments, perhaps the most research went into a project titled ''Kentucky Bluebird'', which was to star writer/actor/director [[David L. Keith|David Keith]]. This project was in [[development hell]] for several years, and was halted in late 2006 after difficulties with casting and funding. Another film project, started in 2004 by songwriter Jeff Swope, was a biopic chronicling Whitley's life and passing. The last information about the project came in 2010, when he announced that pre-production was set to begin, pending investors.<ref>Mirrors, The Keith Whitley Story – [[WordPress]], April 13, 2010</ref>

Despite his brief moment in the spotlight, Whitley's legacy remains.<ref name="Watts 2019 m180">{{cite web | last=Watts | first=Cindy | title=Keith Whitley's family remembers him on 30th anniversary of his death | website=The Tennessean | date=May 8, 2019 | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2019/05/08/keith-whitley-country-music-hall-of-fame-exhibit-lorrie-morgan/1141495001/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref><ref name="Morris 2009 u881">{{cite web | last=Morris | first=<!-- -->Edward | title=Keith Whitley's Musical Legacy Endures Two Decades After His Death | website=CMT | date=May 8, 2009 | url=https://www.cmt.com/news/ijbw6b/keith-whitleys-musical-legacy-endures-two-decades-after-his-death | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221206210924/https://www.cmt.com/news/ijbw6b/keith-whitleys-musical-legacy-endures-two-decades-after-his-death | url-status=dead | archive-date=December 6, 2022 | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> He was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2022;<ref name="cmhof"/> prior to that, he was the subject of an exhibit detailing his life and legacy.<ref name="Hall 2019 z408">{{cite web | last=Hall | first=Kristin M. | title=New exhibit shows Keith Whitley's tragic, but lasting legacy | website=The Seattle Times | date=May 3, 2019 | url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/new-exhibit-shows-keith-whitleys-tragic-but-lasting-legacy/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> Whitley retains a persistent influence on country artists, including [[Tim McGraw]], [[Ronnie Dunn]], and [[Dierks Bentley]].<ref name="Roland Roland 2014 w795">{{cite magazine | last=Roland | first=Tom | title=How Keith Whitley's Conflicted Legacy Spawned an 'Authentic' Country Revival | magazine=Billboard | date=May 6, 2014 | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/keith-whitley-jake-worthington-the-voice-country-authentic-6077549/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> Newer artists like [[Morgan Wallen]] are among his progenitors; a song named after Whitley features on Wallen's 2023 double album, ''[[One Thing at a Time]]'',<ref name="Nicholson Nicholson 2023 p810">{{cite magazine | last=Nicholson | first=Jessica | title=Morgan Wallen Celebrates New Album 'One Thing at a Time' For a Packed House in Nashville | magazine=Billboard | date=March 4, 2023 | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/morgan-wallen-one-thing-at-a-time-album-nashville-concert-review-1235279928/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> which won the approval of Whitley's widow and son.<ref name="Country Now 2023 r033">{{cite web | title=Lorrie Morgan and Jesse Keith Whitley React To Morgan Wallen's New Song That Tributes Keith Whitley | website=Country Now | date=January 12, 2023 | url=https://countrynow.com/lorrie-morgan-and-jesse-keith-whitley-react-to-morgan-wallens-new-song-that-tributes-keith-whitley/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref>

Whitley is the only person to be posthumously recognized as a former member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], without ever being an active member. Management had scheduled Whitley for an appearance in late May 1989, where he was to be invited to join, but his death on May 9 interrupted those plans. As the Opry has a policy only inducting living artists as members, Whitley's induction was scrapped. During a Keith Whitley tribute show at the Opry on October 14, 2023, [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Lorrie Morgan]] announced that Whitley's name would be engraved on a plaque and included in the Opry's Member Gallery backstage, alongside every act who has held Opry membership at some point in the show's history, dating to 1925.

'''Larry Cordle''' (born November 16, 1948) is an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter
.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/larry-cordle-mn0000124925/biography |title=Artist Biography |author=Linda Seida |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015}}</ref> Cordle is most famous for his song "[[Murder on Music Row]]",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/murder-on-music-row-mw0000625171 |author=William Ruhlmann |title=AllMusic Review |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015 }}</ref> which was recorded by [[George Strait]] and [[Alan Jackson]] and received the [[Country Music Association]] Award for Vocal Event of the Year, and CMA nomination for Song of the Year, in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114055357/http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 14, 2014 |title=CMA Awards, Archive 2000 |publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |access-date=September 7, 2015}}</ref>

==Career==
Cordle has written songs for [[Garth Brooks]] ("Alabama Clay" and "Against the Grain", the latter of which was also recorded by [[The Oak Ridge Boys]]), [[Mountain Heart]] ("Bitter Harvest"), [[Ricky Skaggs]] ("Callin' Your Name", "Highway 40 Blues",  "[[Heartbreak Hurricane]]"), [[Loretta Lynn]] ("Country In My Genes"), [[George Strait]] ("Hollywood Squares"), [[Trisha Yearwood]] ("Lonesome Dove"), [[Kathy Mattea]] ("Lonesome Standard Time"), [[Diamond Rio]] ("Mama, Don't Forget To Pray For Me") and [[Bradley Walker]] ("When I'm Hurtin'") .

Cordle also has a career of his own, with his band Lonesome Standard Time. He founded the band in 1990 with his friend Glen Duncan. He received a Grammy nomination for the group's debut album, self-titled, in 1992. In 2005, Cordle's band played at the Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival. On his album 2007 "Took Up and Put Down", he sings "The First Train Robbery"; a song about the [[Reno Gang]] written from brother William Reno's perspective. The Song was written by Chris Stuart<ref>"Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival", ''Strings'', newsletter of the [[Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society]], October 2005.</ref>

Cordle performed on two bluegrass tribute albums for the British rock band [[the Moody Blues]]: ''[[Moody Bluegrass (musical project)|Moody Bluegrass]]: A Nashville Tribute to the Moody Blues'' (2004), and ''Moody Bluegrass TWO... Much Love'' (2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4247134 |title=Moody Bluegrass: Rocking Through the Hills |publisher=NPR.org |date=December 3, 2004|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/moody-bluegrass-two%E2%80%A6much-love/ |title=Moody Bluegrass Two…Much Love |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>

Along with friends [[Carl Jackson]] and [[Jerry Salley]], the trio (Cordle, Jackson & Salley) recorded the song "You’re Running Wild" on the [[Louvin Brothers]] tribute on [[Universal South Records]], which features numerous country music stars singing songs made famous by the legendary duo. Entitled ''[[Livin', Lovin', Losin': Songs of the Louvin Brothers]]'', this project won the [[2004 Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Country Album of the Year]]. The trio tours across the country and performs the hits they wrote for others.

'''Leslie Winn Satcher''' (born 1962) is a singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]]. She has recorded two albums of her own, and has additionally co-written several singles for such artists as [[George Strait]], [[Martina McBride]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Patty Loveless]], and [[Vince Gill]].

==Biography and career==
Leslie grew up in her birthplace of [[Paris, Texas|Paris]], Texas, United States, where she sang in local churches and schools – an experience which she lists as one of her biggest influences.<ref>{{cite web| title = Letters From Leslie| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]| year = 2001| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040721/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| url-status = dead| archive-date = September 30, 2007| accessdate = June 21, 2007  }}</ref> In 1989, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue her dream of being a country music singer, but found a niche writing the songs for which she is most well known – including many by notable country music acts like [[Patty Loveless]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Reba McEntire]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Tarradell| first = Mario| title = This train is bound for glory| publisher = [[Dallas Morning News]]| date = April 2, 2002}}</ref><ref name="leg">{{cite web| title = H.C.R. No. 106| publisher = [[Texas State Legislature]]| date = February 2, 2007| url = http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/html/HC00106I.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }}</ref> [[Pam Tillis]] reached No.&nbsp;12 on the country charts in 1998 with Satcher's "I Said a Prayer". In 2002, [[Martina McBride]]'s performance of her song "[[When God-Fearin' Women Get the Blues]]" reached No.&nbsp;8 in the United States, while her 2006 song "Politically Uncorrect", performed by [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Gretchen Wilson]], reached No.&nbsp;23 and was nominated for a Grammy award.<ref>{{cite web| title = Students to perform at Country Music Hall of Fame| publisher = [[Country Music Hall of Fame]]| date = April 2, 2006| url = http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| accessdate = June 21, 2007| url-status = dead| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070501201911/http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| archivedate = May 1, 2007}}</ref>

At the same time, her singing career also began to take off, following her signing with [[Warner Bros. Records]], and the release of her first album ''[[Love Letters (Leslie Satcher album)|Love Letters]]'' in 2002.<ref name="leg"/> This was followed by the independent release of ''[[Creation (Leslie Satcher album)|Creation]]'' in 2005, which she has been touring to promote.<ref name="abc">{{cite web|last=Mackay |first=Jacquie |title=Who writes the songs for the Nashville greats? |publisher=[[ABC Records|ABC]] |date=April 3, 2006 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |accessdate=June 21, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819124152/http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2006 }}</ref> Her work has met with critical acclaim, with the [[Texas State Legislature]] calling her:

<blockquote>[Able] to craft songs that capture the ears and hearts of music lovers and honoring her [...] for bringing further acclaim to the illustrious musical reputation of the Lone Star State; and, be it further [..] an expression of high regard by the Texas House of Representatives and Senate.<ref name="leg"/></blockquote>

[[USA Today]] listed her as part of a "groundswell" in traditional country and bluegrass music.<ref>{{cite web| last = Mansfield| first = Brian| title = O country music, where art thou?| publisher = [[USA Today]]| date = July 9, 2007| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2001-07-09-country-usat.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }}</ref> Leslie Satcher continues to write and sing, after taking some time off in 2006.<ref name="abc"/>

In 2008, two songs she co-wrote with [[Monty Holmes]], "[[Troubadour (song)|Troubadour]]" and "House Of Cash" were recorded by [[George Strait]].

In 2017, Leslie and The Electric Honey Badgers released the single "This Won't Take Long", featuring [[Vince Gill]] and [[Sheryl Crow]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://musicrow.com/2017/09/leslie-satcher-joined-by-vince-gill-sheryl-crow-on-new-single-out-today/|title=Leslie Satcher Joined By Vince Gill, Sheryl Crow On New Single, Out Today|date=September 2, 2017|work=MusicRow – Nashville's Music Industry Publication – News, Songs From Music City|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>

'''Lester Raymond Flatt''' (June 19, 1914 – May 11, 1979)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Lester-Flatt|title=Lester Flatt &#124; American musician|website=[[Encyclopedia Britannica]]|access-date=August 28, 2021}}</ref> was an American [[bluegrass (music)|bluegrass]] guitarist and mandolinist, best known for his collaboration with banjo picker [[Earl Scruggs]] in the duo [[Flatt and Scruggs]].

Flatt's career spanned multiple decades, breaking out as a member of [[Bill Monroe]]'s band during the 1940s and including multiple solo and collaboration works exclusive of Scruggs. He first reached a mainstream audience through his performance on "[[The Ballad of Jed Clampett]]", the theme for the network television series ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]'', in the early 1960s.

==Biography==
[[File:Earl Scruggs and Lester Flatt.jpg|thumb|left|Lester Flatt (right) with [[Earl Scruggs]] (left) as part of [[Flatt and Scruggs]] in 1949]]
Flatt was born in Duncan's Chapel, [[Overton County, Tennessee]], United States,<ref name=browne>{{cite book |editor1-last=Browne |editor1-first=Ray B. |editor2-last=Browne |editor2-first=Pat |url={{Google books|U3rJxPYT32MC|page=284|plainurl=yes}} |chapter=Flatt and Scruggs |title=The Guide to United States Popular Culture |publisher=[[Popular Press]] |year=2001 |page=284 |isbn=978-0879728212}}</ref> to Nannie Mae Haney and Isaac Columbus Flatt. In 1943, he played [[mandolin]] and sang [[tenor]] in The Kentucky Pardners, the band of [[Bill Monroe]]'s older brother [[Charlie Monroe|Charlie]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flatt-and-scruggs.com/lesterbio.html |title=Biography: Lester Flatt |website=Flatt-and-scruggs.com |access-date=June 6, 2020}}</ref> He first came to prominence as a member of [[Bill Monroe]]'s Blue Grass Boys in 1945 and played a thumb-and-index guitar style that was in part derived from the playing of Charlie Monroe and Clyde Moody. In 1948, he started a band with fellow Monroe alumnus [[Earl Scruggs]], and for the next 20 years, [[Flatt and Scruggs]] and the Foggy Mountain Boys were one of the most successful bands in bluegrass.<ref name=ecm>{{cite book |last=Rosenberg |first=Neil V. |year=1998 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PT504 |chapter=Flatt & Scruggs and the Foggy Mountain Boys |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=173–4 |isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref> When they parted ways in 1969, Flatt formed a new group, the [[Nashville Grass]], hiring many of the Foggy Mountain Boys. He continued to record and perform with that group until his death in 1979.<ref name=ecm2>{{cite book |last=Samuelson |first=Dave |year=1998 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PT504 |chapter=Lester Flatt & the Nashville Grass |title= The Encyclopedia of Country Music |editor-first=Paul |editor-last=Kingsbury |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=173 |isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref> His role as rhythm guitarist and vocalist in each of these seminal ensembles helped define the sound of traditional bluegrass music. His solid guitar playing and rich lead voice are unmistakable in hundreds of bluegrass standards. He is also remembered for his library of compositions.

==Death and legacy==
Flatt died of heart failure in Nashville, Tennessee, at the age of 64.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/05/12/archives/lester-flatt-singer-and-guitarist-in-duo-with-earl-scruggs-dies.html |title=Lester Flatt, Singer and Guitarist in Duo With Earl Scruggs, Dies |first=John |last=Rockwell |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=26 |date=May 12, 1979}}</ref>

He was posthumously inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1985 along with Scruggs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/flatt-and-scruggs |title=Flatt and Scruggs |website=[[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] |access-date=August 15, 2016}}</ref> Flatt was also posthumously inducted as an inaugural member of the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Honor]] in 1991.

Lester's hometown of [[Sparta, Tennessee]], held a bluegrass festival in his honor for a number of years, before being discontinued a few years prior to the death of the traditional host, resident Everette Paul England; Lester Flatt Memorial Bluegrass Day remains part of the annual Liberty Square Celebration held in Sparta.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eastpublicrelations.com/lester_flatt_memorial_bluegrass.htm |title=Lester Flatt Memorial Bluegrass Day |website=East Public Relations |date=September 29, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205192520/http://www.eastpublicrelations.com/lester_flatt_memorial_bluegrass.htm |archive-date=December 5, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

Flatt and Scruggs were ranked No. 24 on [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s 40 Greatest Men of Country Music in 2003.
