'''Rhonda Lea Vincent''' (born July 13, 1962) is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/artist.jhtml|title=CMT.com : Rhonda Vincent : Artist Main|date=April 6, 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406132753/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/artist.jhtml |archive-date=April 6, 2004 }}</ref> 

Vincent's music career began when she was a child in her family's band The Sally Mountain Show, and it has spanned more than four decades. Vincent first achieved success in the bluegrass genre in the 1970s and 1980s, earning the respect of her mostly male peers for her mastery of the progressive chord structures and multi-range, fast-paced vocals intrinsic to bluegrass music. In media, Vincent has been dubbed the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Bluegrass]]" by several sources.<ref name='old-bio'>{{cite web | url = http://www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/rhondavincentbio.html | title = Biography | access-date = January 15, 2012 | publisher = Rhonda Vincent | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120207113834/http://www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/rhondavincentbio.html | archive-date = February 7, 2012 | url-status = dead }}</ref> Vincent is an in-demand guest vocalist for other bluegrass and country music performers, appearing on recordings by [[Dolly Parton]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Tanya Tucker]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Faith Hill]] and other notables.<ref name="Rhonda Vincent fact sheet">{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:4rOkOJ4ILPUJ:www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/2010RVFactSheet.doc+&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShmgW6Btg4gqkiIk5fNpLu0o7pvfpaVgJ2fDU_XKU94-zgsvZ6ogu8yWV617OE1zZaZfVRy25UEqXdd8Tp4cCMzNDxvk4WApwkd_9HQFJMNYwGu_Sqzx1TUlU_uJ6bsco8WcLjS&sig=AHIEtbSmvsCkQUnyahzKBQl1Yhg367XmsQ&pli=1|title=Rhonda Vincent fact sheet|access-date=June 20, 2012}}</ref>

Vincent is an eight-time [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nominee, winning the [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/winners-nominees/122 |title=Awards Winners & Nominees Best Bluegrass Album |website=Grammy.com |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref> In 2020, she was inducted as a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theboot.com/rhonda-vincent-grand-ole-opry-membership/ |title=WATCH: Rhonda Vincent Invited to Join the Grand Ole Opry |website=Theboot.com |date=February 29, 2020 |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref>

==Early years==
Vincent was born in [[Kirksville, Missouri]], on July 13, 1962, and raised in nearby [[Greentop, Missouri]]. She is the oldest of three children, and the only daughter of Johnny and Carolyn Vincent. Her brother Darrin is a member of the  Award-winning bluegrass group [[Dailey & Vincent]]. Her youngest brother Brian played with the family group, but is now a top executive with the Bimeda Corporation. A fifth-generation musician, Rhonda's musical career started at age five when she sang gospel songs with her family's band, which was later known as the "Sally Mountain Show".<ref>Craig Morrison, "Vincent, Rhonda" in Kristin N Burns, ed. ''Women and Music in America since 1900: an Encyclopedia''. Westport, Ct .& London: Greenwood. 2002 {{ISBN|978-1573563093}} vol.2 p. 661</ref> Her father bought her a [[snare drum]] for her sixth birthday. At age eight, Vincent started playing [[mandolin]]. She later added [[fiddle]] to her list of instruments at 12. In an interview with ''Ingrams'' magazine, she said, "Dad used to pick me up after school, and Grandpa would come over and we played until after dinner almost every night. There wasn’t a lot going on in Greentop, but it was always hopping at the Vincent house."<ref name="Boone">{{cite web|last=Boone|first=Dennis|url=http://www.ingramsonline.com/Apr_2012/50Missourians/Missouriansnew13.php|title=50 Missourians you should know|publisher=Ingrams magazine. Volume 38, No.&nbsp;4|date=April 2012|access-date=June 21, 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512231421/http://www.ingramsonline.com/Apr_2012/50Missourians/Missouriansnew13.php|archive-date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> Vincent recorded her first single, a version of "[[Mule Skinner Blues]]", in 1970. The family, including the younger brothers when they were old enough to play instruments, traveled and performed extensively across the [[Midwest]] in the 1970s and early 1980s. Except for living in [[Texas]] for a short time in 1974, and two summers (1977, 1978) spent employed as musicians at [[Silver Dollar City]] in [[Branson, Missouri]], the Vincent family used the Greentop area as home base.<ref>Janie Shriver & Jennie Higgins, ''It's a Family Affair''. Published in ''[[The Chariton Collector]]'' magazine, Spring 1982. Pg. 30–31</ref> The Vincent children all attended [[Schuyler County, Missouri|Schuyler County R-1]] schools, and following high school Vincent later attended [[Truman State University|Northeast Missouri State University]], majoring in accounting.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}

==Solo career==
Vincent’s life of music evolved into a successful career in bluegrass music after being discovered by Grand Ole Opry Star Jim Ed Brown, and later spending what she calls her musical college years recording for Giant Record. She learned about the music business from Nashville’s best like James Stroud, Jack McFadden, and Stan Barnett. Even while Vincent was still performing regularly with the Sally Mountain Show, she released her first solo album ''New Dreams and Sunshine'' in 1988. In 1985, Vincent had competed in the TV series ''You Can Be a Star'' on the original version of [[The Nashville Network]]. After winning the competition, she was signed to a recording contract; her first professional performance was with country singer and [[Grand Ole Opry]] star [[Jim Ed Brown]]. In the 1990s Vincent branched out into mainstream country music, releasing a pair of albums on the [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] label, but did not have success there.
[[File:Rhondavincent-fls.jpg|thumb|left|Rhonda Vincent on the Watson Stage, MerleFest, 2010]]

With the release of her album ''Back Home Again'' in 2000, Vincent returned to bluegrass with the goal of expanding both the musical reach and the accessibility of the genre. The [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (IBMA) accorded her its Female Vocalist of the Year award for the years 2000 – 2006, plus IBMA Entertainer of the Year in 2001. The Society for Preservation of Bluegrass Music in America (SPBGMA) designated her its Entertainer of the Year for 2002 – 2006 inclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/bio.jhtml|title=Rhonda Vincent|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030818170009/http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/bio.jhtml |access-date=July 13, 2024|archive-date=August 18, 2003 }}</ref> She also performs with her band, Rhonda Vincent & the Rage.

On February 19, 2010, Vincent parted from [[Rounder Records]], after ten years with the label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1632264/rhonda-vincent-leaves-rounder-records.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100222122732/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1632264/rhonda-vincent-leaves-rounder-records.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 22, 2010|title=CMT : News : Rhonda Vincent leaves Rounder Records|publisher=CMT News|access-date=February 19, 2010}}</ref> Vincent released "Taken", her debut album on her own label Upper Management Music on September 21, 2010. Featuring special guests like long-time friend [[Dolly Parton]], [[Richard Marx]] and [[The Lewis Family|Little Roy Lewis]], the album entered the [[Top Bluegrass Albums]] chart at No.&nbsp;1.<ref name="Rhonda Vincent biography">{{cite web|url=http://www.rhondavincent.com/|title=Rhonda Vincent biography|publisher=Vincent official website|access-date=June 19, 2012}}</ref>

On June 7, 2011, Vincent and [[Gene Watson]] released a duet album on Upper Management entitled ''Your Money and My Good Looks''. The album entered the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Billboard charts|Top Country Albums]] chart at number 71.

''Sunday Mornin' Singin''', an album of old-time gospel standards, was released on July 10, 2012.

On April 1, 2017, Vincent's duet with a fellow country singer [[Richard Lynch (musician)|Richard Lynch]] was released as a track on Lynch's album "Mending Fences".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Papadatos|first1=Marcos|title=Review: Richard Lynch back with new country single 'Cut And Paste' |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-richard-lynch-back-with-new-country-single-cut-and-paste/article/489310|website=Digital Journal|date=April 2017 |access-date=April 2, 2017}}</ref>

During an appearance at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] on April 27, Vincent announced that she and [[Daryle Singletary]] had spent the previous months recording a duets album, with further details to follow during [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA week]]. She then introduced Singletary and the two performed a couple of [[George Jones]] and [[Tammy Wynette]] songs – "[[Golden Ring (song)|Golden Ring]]" and "[[One (George Jones and Tammy Wynette album)|One]]".

It was her pivotal bluegrass album, “Back Home Again” on Rounder Records, that transformed Vincent into the All American Bluegrass Girl. She was crowned the New Queen of Bluegrass by “The Wall Street Journal” in 2000. She is a multi-award winner, with a 2017 Grammy for Best Bluegrass Album, an Entertainer of the Year 2001, Song of the Year 2004, and unprecedented seven consecutive Female Vocalist of the Year awards from the International Bluegrass Music Association 2000 – 2006.

Her powerful vocal style transcends the boundaries of bluegrass music, as evidenced in her collaboration with Dolly Parton on the Elton John / Bernie Taupin Tribute Project “Restoration” 2018. She was invited to become a member of the Grand Ole Opry on February 28, 2020.

===Touring===
In 2008, Vincent's band performed at Centennial Hall in [[London, Ontario]], at a concert organized by the Thames Valley Bluegrass Association.<ref>''Strings'', newsletter of the Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society, June 2008</ref>

===Gospel DVD===
In a 2011 interview with television station [[KTVO]] Vincent announced that she and her band had recently filmed a live all-gospel DVD at a church in her hometown of Greentop, Missouri.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heartlandconnection.com/news/story.aspx?id=686151|title=Bluegrass Queen performs for the Heartland|publisher= KTVO-TV website|date=November 1, 2011|access-date=November 14, 2011}}</ref> The DVD was expected to be released sometime in 2012.

==Family life==
Vincent married Herb Sandker on Christmas Eve 1983.<ref name="Rhonda Vincent fact sheet"/> While it might have been more convenient to be based out of someplace like [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Vincent chose to remain close to her Missouri roots: "My husband and I made the decision early on. I loved being in my home area. My parents are there, our relatives are there. We wanted to raise our children there. So I made the decision to commute."<ref name="Boone"/> For a period of time in the late 1990s and early 2000s, they owned, and Sandker managed, a popular restaurant in Kirksville, Missouri, called Bogies.  <ref>{{cite web|last=Righi |first=Len |url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-2000-06-09-3304169-story.html |title=Home on the Web: Rhonda Vincent Turns to the Internet to Bond With Traditional Bluegrass Fans |website=MCall.com |date=June 9, 2000 |access-date=May 29, 2022}}</ref>

Vincent's elder daughter Sally wed her mother's fiddle player, Hunter Berry, in Greentop, Missouri, in 2010. Younger daughter Tensel married her mother's dobro player, Brent Burke, in 2013. Sally and Tensel have since performed with their mother, and have begun their own group with their husbands named Next Best Thing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lawless |first=John |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-next-best-thing/ |title=The Next Best Thing |website=Bluegrasstoday.com |date=August 4, 2008 |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref>

Since 1987, Rhonda and the entire Vincent family have hosted a large yearly bluegrass festival on land just west of [[Queen City, Missouri]]. The Sally Mountain Bluegrass Festival is traditionally held around July 4, and attracts music fans from across the U.S. and the world. 
[[File:QueenCityMo4.jpg|thumb|A highway sign in Queen City, Missouri directing attendees to the annual Sally Mountain Bluegrass Festival]]

==Awards==
To date, Vincent and her band, The Rage, have won one [[Grammy Award|Grammy]], nineteen [[International Bluegrass Music Association|IBMA Awards]] (including the top Entertainer of the Year honor in 2001 and consecutive Female Vocalist of the year wins between 2000 and 2006) and eighty nine SPBGMA Awards.

'''Rickie Lee Skaggs'''<ref name="KT" /><ref name="Excerpt from KT">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1712490/read-from-ricky-skaggs-memoir-kentucky-traveler/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150422020630/http://www.cmt.com/news/1712490/read-from-ricky-skaggs-memoir-kentucky-traveler/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 22, 2015 |title=Read From Ricky Skaggs' Memoir, Kentucky Traveler |last=Skaggs |first=Ricky |date=August 16, 2013 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]}}</ref> (born July 18, 1954),<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2019/07/18/Famous-birthdays-for-July-18-Vin-Diesel-Kristen-Bell/8771563155558/|title=Famous birthdays for July 18: Vin Diesel, Kristen Bell|work=[[United Press International]]|date=July 18, 2019|access-date=August 7, 2019|archive-date=July 19, 2019|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190719181941/https://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2019/07/18/Famous-birthdays-for-July-18-Vin-Diesel-Kristen-Bell/8771563155558/|url-status=live|quote=Country singer Ricky Skaggs in 1954 (age 65)}}</ref> known professionally as '''Ricky Skaggs''', is an American [[neotraditional country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer, musician, producer, and [[composer]]. He primarily plays [[mandolin]]; however, he also plays [[fiddle]], guitar, [[mandocaster]], and [[banjo]].<ref name = zane>{{cite web | url = https://www.zanesvilletimesrecorder.com/story/news/local/2018/11/28/ricky-skaggs-headlining-christmas-shows/2125007002/ | publisher = Zanesville Recorder | title = Ricky Skaggs headlining Christmas shows| access-date = 2 March 2021}}</ref>

Skaggs was inducted into the [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2016 and both the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame]] and the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1792529/country-music-hall-of-fame-elects-ricky-skaggs-dottie-west-johnny-gimble/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327223726/http://www.cmt.com/news/1792529/country-music-hall-of-fame-elects-ricky-skaggs-dottie-west-johnny-gimble/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 27, 2018|title=Country Music Hall of Fame Elects Ricky Skaggs, Dottie West, Johnny Gimble|access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> On January 13, 2021, it was announced Skaggs had been awarded the [[National Medal of Arts]] by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]], alongside fellow country musician [[Toby Keith]].

==Biography==
===Early career===
Skaggs was born in [[Cordell, Kentucky]].<ref name="Inc.">{{cite book|title=American Cowboy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--oCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32|date=May–June 2000|publisher=Active Interest Media, Inc.|page=32|issn=1079-3690}}</ref> He started playing music at age 5 after he was given a [[mandolin]] by his father, Hobert Skaggs. At age 6, he played mandolin and sang on stage with [[Bill Monroe]]. At age 7, he appeared on television's [[Martha White]] country music variety show, playing with [[Lester Flatt]] and [[Earl Scruggs]]. He also wanted to audition for the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at that time, but was told he was too young.

In his mid-teens, Skaggs met a fellow teen guitarist, [[Keith Whitley]], and the two started playing together with Whitley's banjo playing brother, Dwight, on radio shows. By 1970, they had earned a spot opening for [[Ralph Stanley]], and Skaggs and Keith Whitley were thereafter invited to join Stanley's band, the [[Ralph Stanley#Clinch Mountain Boys|Clinch Mountain Boys]].<ref name = pbs>{{cite web | url = https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/ricky-skaggs-biography/ | publisher = PBS | title = Ricky Skaggs Biography| access-date = 2 March 2021}}</ref>

Skaggs later joined [[The Country Gentlemen]] in Washington, DC, [[J. D. Crowe]]'s [[New South (band)|New South]]. In 1976, Skaggs formed progressive bluegrass band Boone Creek, including members [[Vince Gill]] and [[Jerry Douglas]]. For a few years, Skaggs was a member of [[Emmylou Harris]]'s Hot Band. He wrote the arrangements for Harris's 1980 bluegrass-roots album, ''[[Roses in the Snow]]''. In addition to arranging for Harris, Skaggs sang harmony and played mandolin and fiddle in the Hot Band.

==Country career==
Skaggs launched his own career in 1980, achieving 12 No. 1 hits, 8 CMA awards, and 8 ACM awards. In 1982, he became a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], the youngest musician ever to be inducted at that time. Guitarist and producer [[Chet Atkins]] credited Skaggs with "single-handedly" saving country music.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/bio |title=The Story |publisher=Ricky Skaggs |date=July 1, 1954 |access-date=January 1, 2016 |archive-date=August 19, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819020842/http://www.rickyskaggs.com/bio |url-status=dead }}</ref> Skaggs is considered one of the pioneers of the [[Neotraditional country]] sub-genre.

In 1981, he debuted on [[Epic Records]] with the album ''Waitin for the Sun to Shine'', which brought him to both the country and pop charts and produced two No. 1 hits.

In 1982, he released ''[[Highways & Heartaches (Ricky Skaggs album)|Highways & Heartaches]]'', his only platinum album, featuring the instrumental heavy "[[Highway 40 Blues]]".

Keeping with his instrumental heavy themes, he released "[[Country Boy (Ricky Skaggs song)|Country Boy]]" on the album of the same name. He also had [[Bill Monroe]] as a guest on this album.

Exploring a role as producer, Skaggs produced [[Dolly Parton]]'s album ''[[White Limozeen]]'', which started her comeback in country music.

Skaggs also guested on other albums. In 1995, he sang with [[Vince Gill]] on "[[Go Rest High on That Mountain]]", which later won CMA's Song of the Year and was determined by [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] to be the Most-Performed Song in 1997.

==Later career==

In 1996, Skaggs went back to his [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] roots, and also experimented with new sounds. With his band, [[Kentucky Thunder]], he is a perennial winner of Grammy Awards and International Bluegrass Music Association for best bluegrass album.
[[File:Ricky Skaggs in May 2016 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Ricky Skaggs in May 2016]]

In 2000, he shared the stage with Vermont-based [[jam band]], [[Phish]].<ref>{{cite web|title=June 22, 2000 Setlist :: Phish|url=http://phish.net/setlists/?d=2000-06-22|publisher=The Mockingbird Foundation, Inc.|access-date=September 6, 2012}}</ref> On March 20, 2007, Skaggs released an album with rock musician [[Bruce Hornsby]].

In 2008, Skaggs released an album he recorded with [[The Whites]] on his Skaggs Family Records label.

In 2008, Skaggs recorded a bluegrass version of "Old Enough" by the [[Raconteurs]] with [[Ashley Monroe]] and the [[Raconteurs]]. He played the [[mandolin]] on the track as well as sharing vocals with [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]], [[Brendan Benson]], and [[Ashley Monroe]].

In 2011, Skaggs, along with other musicians including the Irish band [[The Brock McGuire Band]], released their album 'Green Grass Blue Grass", an exploration of the connection between [[Folk music of Ireland|Irish Traditional Music]] and American [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]] and [[Appalachian music]].

[[File:Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White 19Aug2015.jpg|thumb|Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White, McGlohon Theater, Charlotte, NC, August 19, 2015]]

Also in 2011, Skaggs contributed to ''[[Moody Bluegrass]] TWO...Much Love'', a bluegrass [[tribute album]] to the British [[Progressive Rock]] band [[the Moody Blues]]. Skaggs sang lead vocal on the song "[[You and Me (Moody Blues song)|You And Me]]".<ref>
{{cite web|title=Moody Bluegrass TWO...Much Love|url=http://www.twomuchlove.com/two-much-love-story-2/|publisher=Moody Bluegrass project website|access-date=September 6, 2015|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706091533/http://www.twomuchlove.com/two-much-love-story-2/|archive-date=July 6, 2015}}</ref>

In 2012, Skaggs collaborated with [[Barry Gibb]] on the song, "Soldier's Son" which was released on ''Music to My Ears''.

In 2015, Skaggs toured with [[Ry Cooder]], Sharon White and other members of [[The Whites]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Cozy Up To Warm Sounds for Fall with 'Cooder White Skaggs' Tour |url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/news/09-09-15/cozy-warm-sounds-fall-cooder-white-skaggs-tour/|publisher=Ricky Skaggs website|access-date=September 9, 2015}}</ref>

In 2016, he produced the Grammy-winning album [[Love Remains (Hillary Scott album)|Love Remains]] for [[Lady Antebellum]] member [[Hillary Scott]].

In 2019, he collaborated with [[Steven Curtis Chapman]] for Chapman's album ''Deeper Roots: Where the Bluegrass Grows''

In 2019, Skaggs performed at the 6th [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] Concert and Induction Ceremony.

As of recent years, Skaggs continues performing at the historic Grand Ole Opry house in Nashville, Tennessee.

In 2021 Skaggs was nominated for the SOTE award which was delayed by the Covid pandemic.

==Personal life==
Ricky Skaggs was previously married to Brenda Stanley and has two children, Andrew and Mandy, from that marriage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Skaggs|first1=Ricky|title=Kentucky Traveler: My Life in Music|date=2014|publisher=Dey Street Books|isbn=978-0061917349}}</ref> Skaggs has been married to Sharon White of [[The Whites]] since August 1981.<ref name="wrightforyou.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.wrightforyou.com/offstage2.html |title=Offstage |website=Wrightforyou.com |access-date=January 1, 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306020610/http://www.wrightforyou.com/offstage2.html |archive-date=March 6, 2016 }}</ref> They have two children; a daughter, Molly, and a son, Lucas.<ref name="wrightforyou.com"/> Molly Skaggs is a Christian/Gospel singer.<ref name="Hallels">{{cite web |url= http://www.hallels.com/articles/20572/20190103/listen-to-bethel-musics-new-rootsy-aint-no-grave-here.htm |title= Listen to Bethel Music's New Rootsy "Ain't No Grave" Here : News : Hallels |last= Yap |first= Timothy |date= January 3, 2019 |website= Hallels |access-date= December 16, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Molly Skaggs |url=https://www.cagelessbirds.com/artist-molly-skaggs |access-date=2023-08-29 |website=CAGELESS BIRDS |language=en-US}}</ref> Lucas is a multi-instrumentalist and session musician.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Luke Skaggs |url=https://www.cagelessbirds.com/artist-luke-skaggs |access-date=2023-08-29 |website=CAGELESS BIRDS |language=en-US}}</ref>

In June 2020, Skaggs underwent quadruple [[coronary artery bypass graft|bypass surgery]] in Nashville.

Skaggs in 2021 was awarded the National Medal of the Arts by President [[Donald Trump]].

===Grammy Awards===

}}

'''Rita Corinne Hosking''' is an American composer and musician based in [[Davis, California]].  She plays [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] styles of music with both standards and original songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>  Since the release of ''Are You Ready?'', she has been performing around the country at concerts, festivals, and other venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |title=Rita Hosking homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304104821/http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |archive-date=2012-03-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.napavalleyregister.com/articles/2008/05/28/arts/doc483ccce3003cb396119897.txt |title=Article about benefit performance in Napa by Rita Hosking & Cousin Jack |publisher=Napavalleyregister.com |date=2008-05-28 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

"Hosking's music isn't like the polished, over-produced music found in pop culture. Hers is a minimalist sound that reflects a simpler time and place: a little country town, rather than a big city."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:DVEB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1106562C5F3184F8&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FCEDEB95BD4D563 |title=Channeling simpler times - Folksinger records her own life and upbringing in old-style ballads by Landon Christensen |publisher=Docs.newsbank.com |date=2006-03-14 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

Leading up to her 2010 performance tour of Great Britain, she received increasing attention on the "East Side" of the pond.   Reviewer Paul Kerr of Americana-UK remarked that she is ". . . a very talented artist with the ability to step up to that pantheon of great female country folk singers and writers."  <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |title=Review by Paul Kerr in Americana-UK, ''Superb country folk from a brilliant singer/songwriter'' 2010 |publisher=Americana-uk.com |date=2010-01-11 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929220958/http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |archive-date=2011-09-29 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  In the summer of 2010, Hosking played to packed venues in England, Wales, and Cornwall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mythankyoupage.com/2010/07/28/rita-hosking-at-no8-cafe-in-launceston/ |title=Review of Hosking and Feder's performance on July 22, 2010, at No8 Cafe in Launceston, Cornwall |publisher=Mythankyoupage.com |date= 28 July 2010|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Influences and inspirations==
Hosking grew up in a rural area in [[Shasta County, California]].  Her father worked the night shift at a sawmill as part of the area's logging industry. Her great-grandfather, from [[Cornwall]], southwest of England, was an underground coal miner in the region. Her grandmother's family had headed there in a covered wagon on the Oregon Trail, from Virginia.

Hosking says old-time music was strong in her mountain area, as well as country. She grew up hearing neighbors play their simple instruments by ear, as a group called the Mountaineers. And the school cook took several girls from the school, taught them songs and they performed as the Farmerettes; with the Farmerettes, Hosking played washboard and sang her first solo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |title=Article by Patrick S. Pemberton, The Tribune, San Luis Obispo, California. Friday, June 18, 2010. |publisher=Californiachronicle.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312055628/http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |archive-date=March 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

''"I'm no expert on the Appalachians at all, but I figure there are similarities -- the economy and some traditions, logging and mining. So, as a songwriter, you focus on that. You take the human struggle to survive, particularly in a beautiful place they love, and you've pinned down a lot of artistic inspiration."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginawnews/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-1/1217654410164730.xml&coll=9 |title=California singer understands folk roots |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-02 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Performances==

By invitation, she has appeared at the White Crow Conservatory of Music in Saginaw, Michigan,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginaw/index.ssf/2008/08/on_stage_rita_hosking_white.html |title=Rita Hosking brings mountain music, California style, to Saginaw's White Crow by Janet I. Martineau, The Saginaw News |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-01 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> the 17th Annual [https://archive.today/20110715002124/http://www.onemorebluegrassshow.com/Home_Page.html/ “Midsummer in the Northwoods” Bluegrass Festival] in Wisconsin, high in the Colorado Rockies at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090531084110/http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/index.html Telluride Bluegrass Festival], and many other locations.

On July 16, 2010, she performed at the [[Larmer Tree Festival]] in England, at the famed Victorian pleasure garden on the Wiltshire/Dorset border.  On July 22, she was the featured guest on the BBC radio show ''Bob Harris Country''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00t38hp/Bob_Harris_Country_Rita_Hosking_in_session/ |title=Bob Harris Country on BBC Radio |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-07-22 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> On November 3, 2010, she performed at [[The Freight and Salvage]] Coffeehouse in Berkeley, California.<ref>{{cite web|date=|title=Announcement of Freight & Salvage performance of November 3, 2010|url=http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928054652/http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|archive-date=September 28, 2011|accessdate=2011-11-04|publisher=Thefreight.org}}</ref>

Hosking has also performed at many popular festivals including the Strawberry Music Festival, Live Oak Music Festival, Kate Wolf Music Festival and [[Sisters Folk Festival]].

==Recognition and awards==
Rita was the ''2007 Emerging Artist Winner'' at the Bluegrassin' In The Foothills festival in [[Plymouth, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.landspromotions.com/plymouthhome.htm |title=Homepage of the annual music festival in Plymouth, California ''Bluegrassin' in the Foothills'' |publisher=Landspromotions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

On September 6, 2008, Rita was selected the winner of the nationally respected ''Dave Carter Memorial Songwriting Contest'' at the [[Sisters Folk Festival]] in [[Sisters, Oregon]].<ref>[http://www.sistersfolkfestival.org Sisters Folk Festival homepage]</ref>

On June 18, 2009, Rita performed as a finalist at the acclaimed Telluride Troubadour Competition, held in conjunction with the [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]].  The Competition judges songs based on composition, vocal delivery, and overall performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/contests.html |title=Telluride Bluegrass competitions |publisher=Bluegrass.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

"Come Sunrise" was nominated in November 2009 as one of the five finalists for Album of the Year in the category of "country music" by the 9th annual Independent Music Awards.<ref>[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/rita-hosking-9th-ima-country-album-nominee/ Artist Spotlight, nominee for Country Music ''album of the year'', 9th Annual Independent Music Awards.]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref>  Hosking won the 9th annual Independent Music Awards Vox Pop / Peoples Choice / Best Country Album award for "Come Sunrise".

==Soloist and with groups==
Rita is versatile, performing either as a soloist, or in duos, trios or quartets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ritahosking.com/about.html |title=Overview of Rita Hosking and her music on the Rita Hosking Homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

Rita is sometimes supported by a back-up group named Cousin Jack<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Article about Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack in ''Sacramento News & Review'' |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7oQAuE8BHG8  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/7oQAuE8BHG8 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=video of Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack performing in Berkeley, California |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}{{cbignore}}</ref> that includes:
* Sean Feder - banjo, [[dobro]], bass, percussion, vocals
* Bill Dakin - bass, guitar, vocals
* Andy Lentz - fiddle
* Kora Feder - mandolin, banjo, guitar, vocals

==Songs written by Rita Hosking==

The following singles were written by Rita Hosking and performed by others:

*Kati Penn – "I'm Going Home" on the album "My Turn to Cry" produced by [[Rob Ickes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/katipenn2 |title=Page showing Kati Penn's album "My Turn to Cry" |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Come Sunrise==
During the spring of 2008 at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090428021851/http://www.strawberrymusic.com/home.asp Strawberry Music Festival] Rita heard a performance of Mississippi native [[Caroline Herring]].  Hosking bought Herring's album and discovered that [http://www.richbrotherton.com/ Rich Brotherton], longtime mandolin and guitar player in [[Robert Earl Keen]]'s band, had produced it.  "I loved it," says Hosking, "so I 'My Spaced' him and said, 'Hi, my name is Rita. Would you be interested in producing my next album?' He wrote right back and said, 'Sure.'"   In addition to Brotherton, she was backed by such musicians as [[Lloyd Maines]] (father of [[Dixie Chicks]] lead singer Natalie Maines and a well-known musician and record producer), Warren Hood of the Waybacks,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waybacks.com/ |title=Homepage of the Waybacks |publisher=Waybacks.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> and Tom Van Schaik and Marty Muse from Keen's band.<ref>[https://archive.today/20130815204617/http://www.sacbee.com/music/story/1509681.html Pop Music: Rita Hosking: Down from the mountains, Davis singer-songwriter's sound mines a rich, generations-old vein, By Dixie Reid, Published: Friday, Jan. 02, 2009]</ref>

This collaboration evolved into "Come Sunrise", which was released in June 2009 and is available through CD Baby, Digstation, and iTunes.   It was recorded and produced at Ace Recording <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acerecording.net/ |title=Ace Recording homepage |publisher=Acerecording.net |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> in Austin, Texas.

As described by Stuart Mason:    "''On her new release Come Sunrise, singer-songwriter Rita Hosking reflects her upbringing in rural Shasta County. Her breed of Nor Cal country folk ain’t quite old-timey, and it ain’t quite bluegrass, but damn it’s sweet. For fans of Emmylou and Gillian, this one’s a safe bet. The songs of Rita Hoskings are as fragile as a newborn baby, and defiant as a West Virginia coal miner''."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fiddlefreak.com/2009/10/21/rita-hosking/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' on the Fiddlefreak Folk Music Blog, October 21, 2009 |publisher=Fiddlefreak.com |date=2009-10-26 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

As described by Neil Spencer of the Guardian (UK):   "''Hosking . . . hits impressive form on this album.  Her songs are compassionate tales about ordinary folk from her north Californian background – loggers, miners, the mothers of lost sons – but there is anger as well as warmth in her voice. "Montgomery Creek Blues" and "Promise Land" in particular meld the personal and political to become state-of-the-nation songs''."<ref>{{cite news|author=Neil Spencer |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jan/03/rita-hosking-come-sunrise-review/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' in the Music Section of the Guardian (UK), January 3, 2010 |publisher=Guardian |date= 2010-01-03|accessdate=2011-11-04 |location=London}}</ref>

In July 2009 "Come Sunrise" placed Number 12 on the national Freeform American Roots Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |title=Freeform American Roots Chart of July 2009 |publisher=Tcmnradio.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126065540/http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |archive-date=2013-11-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

"Come Sunrise" was selected as one of five contenders for the country music "album of the year" of the 9th annual Independent Music Awards, announced in November 2009 (see description under ''Recognition and Awards'').

Rita Hosking, Reviewed by: B Hough |publisher=Cbaontheweb.org |date=2005-07-27 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004000120/http://www.cbaontheweb.org/reviews_read2.asp?messageID=601&curPage=1&search |archive-date=2011-10-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>[http://www.theshywriter.com/Country/Bluegrass/RITA_HOSKING_Are_You_Ready.html Review of "Are you Ready" on website "The Shy Writer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717025845/http://www.theshywriter.com/Country/Bluegrass/RITA_HOSKING_Are_You_Ready.html |date=2011-07-17 }}</ref>

'''Rob Ickes''' ({{IPAc-en|aɪ|k|s}}; born 1967) is an American dobro ([[resonator guitar]]) player in [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. Ickes moved to [[Nashville]] in 1992 and joined the contemporary [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band [[Blue Highway]] as a founding member in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|author=Blue Highway |url=http://www.bluehighwayband.com |title=Blue Highway |website=Bluehighwayband.com |access-date=2020-03-02}}</ref> He currently collaborates with guitarist [[Trey Hensley]], with whom he has released three albums. Ickes has been nominated for numerous [[Grammy Award]]s, winning two in 1994 for bluegrass and gospel albums he contributed to.

==Biography==
After spending 21 years as [[Blue Highway]]'s dobro player, Ickes left the band in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/rob-ickes-leaving-blue-highway/ |title=Rob Ickes leaving Blue Highway |website=Bluegrass Today |date=18 November 2015 |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref> Currently, he records and performs with guitarist [[Trey Hensley]]. The duo has released three albums with Compass Records: ''World Full of Blues'' (2019), ''The Country Blues'' (2016), and ''Before the Sun Goes Down'' (2014).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/4467646-Trey-Hensley |title=Trey Hensley |website=Discogs |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref> ''Before the Sun Goes Down'' was nominated for a Grammy in 2016. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/rob-ickes/16866 |title=Rob Ickes |website=Recording Academy Grammy Awards |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref> As a duo, Ickes and Hensley have performed and recorded with Taj Mahal, Tommy Emmanuel, David Grisman, Molly Tuttle, and Jorma Kaukonen & Hot Tuna. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.robandtrey.com/about-the-band/ |title=About the Band |website=Rob Ickes and Trey Hensley |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref>

In 2013, he was named Dobro Player of the Year for the fifteenth time by the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]]. IBMA notes that he is the most awarded instrumentalist in the history of the IBMA Awards. He was also named the USA Peter Cummings Fellow in 2010 by [[United States Artists]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/user/RIckes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102225340/http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/user/RIckes |url-status=dead |archive-date=2011-11-02 |title=Rob Ickes - Profile - United States Artists - Great art forms here |access-date=2020-03-02}}</ref> an organization that annually honors 50 of America's finest artists across eight disciplines.

In 2014, Ickes released an album with fellow dobro greats [[Jerry Douglas]] and [[Mike Auldridge]], titled ''Three Bells''. This album was nominated for a Grammy in 2015. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2015-nominees-winners-list-story.html |title=Grammys 2015: Complete list of winners and nominees |newspaper=LA Times |date=9 February 2015 |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref> His other solo projects include ''Road Song'', a jazz project with [[pianist]] Michael Alvey and vocalist [[Robinella]] (ResoRevolution), <ref>{{cite web|url=http://resorevolution.com/music-info.html |title=Music-Track Lists, Sound Clips+more |website=Resorevolution.com |access-date=2020-03-02}}</ref> and four solo albums on Rounder Records: ''Big Time'' (2004), What It Is (2002), ''Slide City'' (1999) and ''Hard Times'' (1997). Ickes has also performed and recorded with a "jamgrass acoustic power trio", Three Ring Circle, with [[Andy Leftwich]] and [[Dave Pomeroy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.threeringcircle.com |title=threeringcircle Resources and Information |website=Threeringcircle.com |access-date=2020-03-02}}</ref> Three Ring Circle released a self-titled CD in 2006, (Earwave Records), followed by Brothership in 2010 (ResoRevolution).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.resorevolution.com/trc |title=Three Ring Circle: Brothership |website=Resorevolution.com |access-date=2020-03-02}}</ref> Ickes has also released a studio performance DVD+CD, Rob Ickes: Contemporary ''Dobro Artistry'' (2008, Mel Bay), featuring duos with [[mandolinist]] Andy Leftwich, solo performances, and duos with jazz pianist Michael Alvey.

Ickes was the youngest dobro player on ''[[The Great Dobro Sessions]]'', produced by [[Jerry Douglas]] and [[Tut Taylor]], which won the 1994 [[Grammy]] for Best Bluegrass Album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-great-dobro-sessions-mw0000120203/awards |title= The Great Dobro Sessions |website=AllMusic |access-date=2021-08-08}}</ref> He was also on the Alison Krauss & The Cox Family album, ''[[I Know Who Holds Tomorrow]]'', which won the 1994 [[Grammy]] for Best Southern Gospel.

He has also collaborated with a wide range of musicians, including [[Merle Haggard]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Tony Rice]], [[Charlie Haden]], [[David Grisman]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[David Lee Roth]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Patty Loveless]], [[Peter Rowan]], [[Niall Toner]], Claire Lynch, and [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] and the southern gospel group The Dunaways.  His work with Merle Haggard includes Haggard's 2007 release, "The Bluegrass Sessions" (McCoury Music). Other notable collaborations include the CD ''[[Earl Scruggs with Family & Friends, The Ultimate Collection: Live at the Ryman]]'' (2008, Rounder), nominated for the 2009 Grammy for Best Bluegrass Album; and "Earl Scruggs, Doc Watson, Ricky Skaggs, The Three Pickers" (2003, Rounder DVD & CD), which appeared on the Billboard Bluegrass Chart for 138 weeks. Ickes also played on [[Mark Twain: Words & Music]] in 2011, a benefit CD for the [[Mark Twain Boyhood Home & Museum]] produced by [[Carl Jackson]]. The project featured [[Clint Eastwood]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Garrison Keillor]], [[Brad Paisley]], [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Emmylou Harris]], and others.

Active in dobro workshops and instruction, Ickes is the founder and producer of [http://resosummit.com Resosummit], a 3-day educational event held in Nashville annually since 2007, with 100 students, 10+ faculty, and key luthiers, with workshops, master classes, and performances.  He frequently serves as an instructor at music workshops and camps, including NashCamp, Sore Fingers Week (UK), Rockygrass Academy (CO), Wintergrass Academy (WA), and [[Jorma Kaukonen]]'s Fur Peace Ranch Guitar Camp (OH).

In 2019, Ickes began offering video instruction on [https://bigmusictent.com Big Music Tent], an online music lessons platform. He uploads regular videos and interacts with dobro students on his dedicated learning page, "Rob's Reso Room."

'''Robert William "Robbie" Fulks''' (born March 25, 1963) is an American [[alternative country]] singer-songwriter, instrumentalist and long-time resident of [[Chicago, Illinois]].<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001>{{cite journal|last1=Margasak|first1=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks: Country Without Borders|journal=Journal of Country Music|date=5 June 2003|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]]|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160503175907/http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=HuffPo-GoneAwayBackward-2013>{{cite news|last1=Bellware|first1=Kim|title=Robbie Fulks Talks Dinner Guests, Baseball Bullies And Making Country Music As A City-Dweller|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=6 September 2013|access-date=27 December 2013|archive-date=28 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228061723/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|url-status=live}}</ref> He has released 15 albums over a career spanning more than 30 years.<ref name=LastCall-GoneAwayBackward-2013>{{cite news|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|work=[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]|date=12 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122202334/http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|archive-date=22 January 2014}}</ref> His 2016 record ''[[Upland Stories]]'' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] and the song "Alabama at Night" was nominated for a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]].<ref name=LATimes-GrammyAwardNominees-2016>{{cite news|title=2017 Grammy Awards: Complete list of nominees|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=6 December 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=14 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170114165448/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Early life ==
Fulks was born in [[York, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Pennsylvania]], the son of a school teacher father. He grew up in small towns in southeastern [[Pennsylvania]], the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] area of [[Virginia]], and the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] region of [[North Carolina]]. Fulks's family moved often when he was young, eventually settling in North Carolina when he was 12, and Fulks considers North Carolina his childhood home.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Shannon|title=A Chat with Robbie Fulks: Country's Kingpin of Clever|url=http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|work=Outlaw Magazine|date=24 June 2012|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220131127/http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|url-status=live}}</ref> He has a younger brother named Jubal.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 />

Fulks was exposed to music through his family in which everyone played a different musical instrument, from his Aunt Stella on banjo, his Aunt Mildred on violin and his mother on autoharp, to his father playing guitar.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /><ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012 /><ref name=ChiTonight-2014>{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|work=WTTW Chicago Tonight|format=TV interview|date=9 January 2014|access-date=10 January 2014|archive-date=10 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110214253/http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|url-status=live}}</ref>  Fulks picked up his aunt's banjo when he was six and started playing guitar at age 11.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /><ref name=IndyWeek-UplandStories-2016>{{cite news|last1=Schram|first1=Dan|title=Video: Robbie Fulks Returns to Durham with New Autobiographical Songs|url=http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|work=[[Indy Week]]|date=23 June 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220113134/http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|url-status=live}}</ref>

He graduated from [[Carolina Friends School]]<ref name=IndyWeek-UplandStories-2016 /> in 1980 at the age of 17 and moved to New York City, where he attended [[Columbia College, Columbia University]] with the class of 1984.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012/><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2020-08-06 |title=Take Five with Adam Van Doren '84, GSAPP'89 |url=https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |access-date=2022-06-01 |website=Columbia College Today |language=en |archive-date=2022-06-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601091632/https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Career ==
While at [[Columbia University]], Fulks often played at [[Gerdes Folk City]] and other places in [[Greenwich Village]].<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012/> He also performed on campus in places such as the [[Postcrypt Coffeehouse]].<ref name=":0" /> He eventually dropped out of college after two years to pursue music full time.<ref name=NYT-2000 />

=== Chicago ===
Fulks moved to Chicago in 1983 and started teaching at Chicago's [[Old Town School of Folk Music]].<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /> In 1987, he joined [[The Special Consensus]] Bluegrass Band, where he showcased his unique guitar flatpicking style. In the early 1990s he performed in the musical ''Woody Guthrie's American Song''.<ref name=allmusic-bio>{{cite web|last=Huey|first=Steve|title=Robbie Fulks – Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|work=All Music|publisher=All Media Network, LLC.|access-date=December 28, 2013|archive-date=November 23, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123013204/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|url-status=live}}</ref>

He also recorded his original compositions. Many of his early tracks were engineered by [[Steve Albini]], and the Chicago punk-country label [[Bloodshot Records]] began releasing them in 1993.<ref name=Outlaw-GoneAwayBackward-2012 /><ref name=Trib-2011-Honest /><ref name=NoDep-LindaRay1997>{{cite journal|last=Ray|first=Linda|title=The Long Way Around – Feature: Robbie Fulks|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606041414/http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-date=June 6, 2013|journal=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|issue=11|date=September–October 1997}}</ref>

=== Nashville ===
While living in Chicago, Fulks worked for four years as a country songwriter, mainly for Music Row publisher API.<ref name=CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001 /> His solo debut album, ''Country Love Songs'', engineered by [[Steve Albini]],<ref name="allmusic-bio" /> was released on Bloodshot Records in 1996 and received positive reviews. The Skeletons, members of whom later formed the band [[The Morells]], played on most of the tracks<ref name="NoDep-LindaRay1997" /> and [[Tom Brumley]] and [[Buck Owens]] also featured. ''Country Love Songs'' was followed in 1997 by ''South Mouth'', which confirmed Fulks's retro-alternative image.

Fans had grown used to his rough and sparse sound, but his third album, 1998's ''Let's Kill Saturday Night'', on [[Geffen Records]],<ref name="Soundbite-2000">{{cite web|last=Walker|first=Jesse|title=Soundbite: Music Man|url=http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|work=Reason.com|publisher=Reason Foundation|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=May 2000|archive-date=November 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111103225/http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NYT-Dresden">{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Neil|title=A Major Merger Shakes Up the World of Rock|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 21, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116152111/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}}</ref> was different. Fulks recorded it during the spring of 1998 in Nashville with producer Rick Will, and the album included performances by [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Bill Lloyd (country musician)|Bill Lloyd]], and [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]], as well as guitarist Rob Gjersoe ([[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]), bassist Lorne Rall, and drummer Dan Massey.<ref name="CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001" />

Geffen Records disbanded shortly after the release of the record and Fulks, finding himself without a label, started his own company, Boondoggle Records, and released an album of previously unreleased material called ''The Very Best of Robbie Fulks''. He also licenses his music for distribution by Bloodshot.<ref name="CMHoF-13HillbillyGiants-2001" />

== Output ==
{{Quote box
 |quote  = I called it ''Gone Away Backward'' because it's a phrase from the Bible… I stumbled on the phrase later in the evolution of the record when I was looking around for a title. I think it's a nice piquant phrase that has three good, strong, mellifluous words in it. As far as the backwardness of the record, I think it goes backward in terms of nostalgia for the past – bittersweet nostalgia for the past – as well as the recession having knocked everything backwards for people. In that sense, it's not an album about the past, it's an album about now.
 |source = "Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'"<br/>by Kim Ruehl, ''No Depression Magazine'' (September 18, 2013)
 |width  = 30%
 |align  = right
}}
In 2001 he released ''Couples in Trouble'', a dark, brooding, and decidedly non-country album, and ''13 Hillbilly Giants'', a collection of covers of classic country numbers, both obscure and well known. Both records were released by Bloodshot Records. Also in 2001, Fulks was an inaugural member of the judging panel for the Independent Music Awards, which supported independent artists.<ref name=IMA-judges>{{cite web|title=Past Judges for the Independent Music Awards|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|work=Independent Music Awards|access-date=December 27, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|archive-date=July 13, 2011}}</ref>

Fulks did not release another album until 2005. ''Georgia Hard'' on [[Yep Roc Records]] was a return to his county roots, and was notable for its use of long-time Nashville talent such as [[Lloyd Green]], Hank Singer, [[Dennis Crouch (bassist)|Dennis Crouch]], and [[Dallas Wayne]].<ref name=Pure2005 /> He also released a novelty single called "Fountains of Wayne Hotline," in which he imagined the power pop band [[Fountains of Wayne]] having a hotline that struggling songwriters could call for help with their song structure.

In April 2007, Fulks released a 2-CD album, ''Revenge!'' (also on Yep Roc Records), which consisted mainly of live concert recordings of older songs and included some new material. One disc, labeled ''Standing'', featured a full-band sound, while the second disc, ''Sitting,'' consisted of Fulks solo with little or no musical accompaniment. ''Standing'' opens with the tongue-in-cheek studio track "We're on the Road", which describes life on tour and simulates a telephone call to Fulks from Yep Roc Records President Glenn Dicker, demanding a new record and denigrating the sales performance of the "path-breaking, not chart-breaking" album ''Georgia Hard.''

In 2009, Fulks released an alphabetically organized collection of 50 songs via his website, a compilation called ''50-Vc. Doberman.''<ref name="NYTimes-50">{{cite news|last=Ratliff|first=Ben|title=Playlist: Expansive Pop, Hypnotic Jazz, Surprising Metal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 4, 2009|archive-date=April 13, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230413203308/https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|url-status=live}}</ref> He noted that this method, and electronic-only release in general, was not typical of musicians who worked in his genre.<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014" /> In 2010, Fulks released his next album, ''Happy: Robbie Fulks Plays the Music of Michael Jackson,'' on Yep Roc Records, in which he covered some of Jackson's songs as a tribute. He had been working on the album since 2005.<ref name="ChicagoMag-Happy">{{cite web|last=Guarino|first=Mark|title=Robbie Fulks Reinterprets Michael Jackson's Music in New Album, "Happy"|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|work=Chicago Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=May 28, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235756/http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NoDep-Happy">{{cite web|last=Fontenot|first=Elvis|title=Robbie Fulks – "Happy"|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=April 8, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234311/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2013, Fulks released ''Gone Away Backward,'' an acoustic album recorded and mixed by [[Steve Albini]] and released on Bloodshot Records. It was his first release on that label since 2001's ''13 Hillbilly Giants.'' The album featured banjo, mandolin, fiddle, and upright bass.<ref name="Spin-2013stream">{{cite web|last=McGovern|first=Kyle|title=Stream Robbie Fulks' Small-Town Folk Epic 'Gone Away Backward':Newest full-length from 50-year-old tunesmith arrives August 27|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|work=Spin magazine|publisher=Spin Music, a division of SpinMedia|access-date=December 27, 2013|format=audio stream|date=August 20, 2013|archive-date=April 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405042017/http://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|url-status=live}}</ref> He said one of the songs, "That's Where I'm From", was autobiographical.<ref name="NoDep-GoneAway">{{cite web|last=Ruehl|first=Kim|title=Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|work=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=September 18, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235818/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}}</ref> Four songs from ''50-Vc Doberman'' were the genesis of ''Gone Away Backward:''<ref name="NoDep-Dec2013-int">{{cite web|last=Mateer|first=Chris|title=Robbie Fulks Spins His Tale Of "Gone Away Backward" (Interview)|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|archive-url=https://archive.today/20131228182602/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 28, 2013|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=December 4, 2013}}</ref> the title came from the [[Book of Isaiah]].<ref name="Bible-Isaiah-GAB">{{cite web|title=Isaiah: Isa.1|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|work=Bible, King James Version|access-date=January 10, 2014|archive-date=November 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127171900/http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|url-status=live}}</ref> Fulks said that ''Gone Away Backward'' went back to his roots as a musician.<ref name="ChiTonight-2014" /> The stylistic choice was a good fit with the other musicians who appeared on the recording, Robbie Gjersoe, Jenny Scheinman, and Mike Bub. They recorded live without any overdubbing or elaborate production and laid down around 25 songs in three days.<ref name="NPR-WorldCafe-2014">{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks on World Cafe|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|work=WXPN|publisher=NPR|access-date=January 23, 2014|date=January 21, 2014|archive-date=January 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122060318/http://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2014, Fulks joined members of [[The Mekons]], dubbed "mini-Mekons", on a trip to write and record on the island of [[Jura, Scotland|Jura]] in Scotland. The resulting record, ''Jura'', was released in November 2015 and consisted of traditional songs and original songs written on the trip.<ref name="RStone-Jura-2015">{{cite news|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=Hear Robbie Fulks and Cowpunkers the Mekons' Wild 'Beaten and Broken'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|access-date=November 21, 2015|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=November 5, 2015|archive-date=November 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107194607/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|url-status=live}}</ref> In April 2016, he released ''[[Upland Stories]],''<ref name="FunnyOrDie-Odenkirk-2016">{{cite web|last1=Odenkirk|first1=Bob|title=The First Bob Odenkirk Interview Quiz Challenge Show: Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|website=[[Funny or Die]]|access-date=March 10, 2016|date=March 9, 2016|archive-date=March 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311064656/http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|url-status=live}}</ref>  and the album was nominated for a 2017 Grammy Award for best folk album. The opening track, "Alabama at Night", was nominated for best American roots song.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|title=Wilmette's Robbie Fulks up for first two Grammy Awards on Sunday|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en-US|archive-date=2017-03-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316113742/http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Musical style ==
[[File:Robbie Fulks - December 2013.jpg|thumb|Robbie Fulks playing a house concert on December 14, 2013]]
As a songwriter, Fulks is difficult to categorize.<ref name=NPR-FA-2013>{{cite web|last=Tucker|first=Ken|title=Robbie Fulks: Exhilarating And Bitter On 'Gone Away Backward'|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|work=NPR (Fresh Air)|publisher=National Public Radio|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=September 19, 2013|archive-date=December 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226205410/http://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}}</ref> Nathan Rabin of A.V. Club says he "has a genius for twisting and subverting country tropes," and "there's more to Fulks than tomfoolery and glibly satirical lyrics."<ref name=AV-2010genius>{{cite web|last=Rabin|first=Nathan|title=Week 37: Robbie Fulks, The Alternative|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|work=AV Club|publisher=The Onion|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=June 29, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232858/http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|url-status=live}}</ref> Many of his compositions are silly, funny or spoof songs, such as "Godfrey" ("the sickly, unemployed, amateur children's magician") on the compilation children's album ''The Bottle Let Me Down'', while others are serious country songs.<ref name=MemeFirst-Godfrey>{{cite web|title=Godfrey, the sickly unemployed amateur children's magician|url=http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|work=MemeFirst|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=January 13, 2006|archive-date=March 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302090138/http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

His music is widely described as either alternative country or folk. Fulks's songwriting often includes humor.<ref name=AltC-funny-RegGuard2013>{{cite web|last=Varriano|first=Jackie|title=Alt country is funny for Fulks: The longtime musician finally got some recognition with a hard jab at Nashville|url=http://www.registerguard.com/rg/entertainment/30837292-67/fulks-song-music-songs-really.html.csp|work=The Register Guard (Eugene, OR)|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=December 13, 2013}}</ref> Peter Applebome of ''The New York Times'' describes his work as "one part artful country, one part artful sendup of country, and one part a little of everything else."<ref name=NYT-2000>{{cite news|last=Applebome|first=Peter|title=MUSIC; It's Off the Map, but It's His Country, Right or Wrong|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 15, 2000|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144852/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}}</ref>

Fulks has an encyclopedic knowledge of country and pop music<ref name=ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014 /> and has produced a critically lauded tribute to [[Johnny Paycheck]] called ''Touch My Heart: A Tribute to Johnny Paycheck,'' which was released by [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] in 2004.<ref name=Billboard-Paycheck>{{cite magazine|title=Tributes rarely get better than this, a country music masterpiece.|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=August 21, 2004|archive-date=September 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921102403/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|url-status=live}}</ref> He considers himself adventurous, and is always willing to try new things and experiment. "Why not push the envelope and see what you are capable of doing rather than recycle the same old ideas over and over again," he said.<ref name=ChiTonight-2014 /> His musicianship has been called "impeccable".<ref name="NYT-impeccable">{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|title=POP REVIEW; Heartbreak and Wordplay|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 5, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144708/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Jim Fusilli of the ''Wall Street Journal'' suggested that "a world in which Fulks isn't a household name is somehow upside down."<ref name="WSJ-Artistry">{{cite news|last=Fusilli|first=Jim|title=Robbie Fulks Goes Back to His Acoustic Roots|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 27, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232003/http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Fulks often plays at [[The Hideout Inn|The Hideout]], a bar and club in Chicago, and has worked long-term residencies there,<ref name="Trib-2011-Honest">{{cite news|last=Gendron|first=Bob|title=Fulks honest, unpredictable|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2011/07/01/fulks-honest-unpredictable/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=July 1, 2011|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228015028/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-07-01/entertainment/ct-ott-0701-in-the-works-20110701_1_robbie-fulks-folk-music-irish-fare|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="UBee-2010-Hideout">{{cite web|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|title=Robbie Fulks at the Hideout|url=http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|work=Underground Bee|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=February 9, 2010|archive-date=December 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227175711/http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Reader-Margasak2013">{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks revisits a scorned gem by Bob Dylan|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=May 16, 2013|archive-date=December 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229074626/http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|url-status=live}}</ref> performing anything from current popular hits to jazz to obscure country masterpieces. He says he rarely performs his own compositions at these shows, preferring to explore other contemporary music that has caught his attention.<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014" /> His live performances feature improvised rearrangements of his own songs, off-the-cuff musical humor, and covers of songs by [[Michael Jackson]], [[Cher]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[The Bangles]], among others.

Fulks has co-written with [[Dallas Wayne]] and [[NRBQ]]'s [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]] and others.<ref name="Pure2005" /> He has a long-time association with engineer [[Steve Albini]] ([[Big Black]], [[Shellac (band)|Shellac]]).<ref name="ChiReader-AlbiniFulks-2014">{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Artist on Artist: Robbie Fulks talks to Steve Albini|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|access-date=January 10, 2014|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=January 6, 2014|archive-date=January 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109020636/http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Fulks has three children, sons Nicolas, Preston, and Tennessee; and two grandsons, Logan and Miles.<ref name=ChiTonight-2014 /><ref name=Pure2005>{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Frank|title=A Conversation with Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|work=PureMusic.com|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=July 2005|archive-date=May 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511153127/http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> His wife is actress [[Donna Jay Fulks]]. Fulks's oldest son, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Nicolas Fulks]], and father-in-law, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Donald Jerousek]], were contestants on [[The Amazing Race 12|season 12]] of ''[[The Amazing Race (American TV series)|The Amazing Race]]'' and were placed third.<ref name=Trib-AmazingRace2008>{{cite news|last=Pang|first=Kevin|title=Amazing relatives: Locals on 'Race' related to alt-country's Fulks|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2008/01/10/amazing-relatives/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=January 10, 2008|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228031015/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-01-10/features/0801080316_1_robbie-fulks-amazing-race-video|url-status=live}}</ref>

'''Ronald Franklin Block''' (born July 30, 1964) is an American banjo player, guitarist, and singer-songwriter, best known as a member of the [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band [[Union Station (band)|Alison Krauss & Union Station]]. He has won 14 [[Grammy Award]]s, 6 [[International Bluegrass Music Awards]], a [[Country Music Association Awards|Country Music Association Award]], and a [[GMA Dove Award|Gospel Music Association Dove Award]].<ref name="Official Site">{{cite web|title=Ron Block Bio|url=http://ronblock.com/|website=Ron Block|access-date=2 June 2016}}</ref>

==Biography==
Ron Block heard a variety of music at an early age because his father owned a music store, Hogan's House of Music, in southern California. At home he was drawn to the bluegrass music of [[Bill Monroe]], [[J. D. Crowe]], and [[The Stanley Brothers]]. At the age of 13, after seeing [[Earl Scruggs]] on TV, he learned to play the banjo. In his teens he also learned acoustic and electric guitar. Later in his career, he recorded a solo album of instrumentals, titled ''Hogan's House of Music'' (2015), dedicated to the music store where he spent much of his youth.<ref name="Hogan's">{{cite web|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=Hogan's House Of Music – Ron Block|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/hogans-house-of-music-ron-block/|website=Bluegrass Today|date=14 October 2015|access-date=2 June 2016}}</ref>

In the 1980s, he co-founded the band Weary Hearts, which included [[Eric Uglum]], [[Butch Baldassari]], and Mike Bub, then played with the [[Lynn Morris (musician)|Lynn Morris Band]] before joining Union Station in October 1991. During his career, he has also recorded solo albums, produced, and performed on albums by [[Dolly Parton]], [[Clint Black]], [[Brad Paisley]], and [[Bill Frisell]].<ref name="AllMusic">{{cite web|last1=Seida|first1=Linda|title=Artist Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/ron-block-mn0000276118/biography|website=AllMusic|access-date=2 June 2016}}</ref>

Block has written songs for Union Station and for his own solo albums. His songs have been recorded by [[Randy Travis]], [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Michael W. Smith]], and [[The Cox Family]].<ref name="AllMusic" /> Block names as two of his favorites "A Living Prayer" and "There is a Reason," both recorded with Alison Krauss & Union Station, both dealing with his [[Christianity|Christian faith]].<ref name="Having a Coffee">{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Richard|title=Having a Coffee with...Ron Block|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/having-a-coffee-with-ron-block/|website=Bluegrass Today|date=25 November 2015|access-date=3 June 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name            = Roscoe Holcomb
| image           = Roscoe Holcomb 1960s LOC.jpg
| caption         = Roscoe Holcomb in 1962
| image_size      = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels -->
| background      = solo_singer
| birth_name      = Roscoe Halcomb
| alias           =
| birth_date      = {{birth date|1912|9|5}}
| birth_place     = [[Daisy, Kentucky]], U.S.
| death_date      = {{death date and age|1981|2|1|1912|9|5}}
| death_place     = [[Perry County, Kentucky]], U.S.
| origin          = 
| instrument      = [[Banjo]], [[guitar]], [[harmonica]]
| genre           = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]|[[Old-time music|old-time]]|[[blues]]}}
| occupation      = [[Miner]], [[construction worker]], [[farmer]], musician
| years_active    = 1958–1978
