'''Roscoe Holcomb''' (born '''Roscoe Halcomb''';<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://southernspaces.org/2008/john-cohen-eastern-kentucky-documentary-expression-and-image-roscoe-halcomb-during-folk-revival|title=John Cohen in Eastern Kentucky: Documentary Expression and the Image of Roscoe Halcomb During the Folk Revival|first=Scott L.|last=Matthews|date=July 27, 2008|volume=2008|journal=Southern Spaces|doi=10.18737/M74W3W|doi-access=free}}</ref> September 5, 1912 – February 1, 1981) was an American singer, [[banjo]] player, and [[guitarist]] from [[Daisy, Kentucky]]. A prominent figure in [[Appalachian folk music]],<ref name="PetrusCohen2015">{{cite book|author1=Stephen Petrus|author2=Ronald D. Cohen|title=Folk City: New York and the American Folk Music Revival|url=https://archive.org/details/folkcitynewyorka0000petr|url-access=registration|date=8 June 2015|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-023103-3|pages=[https://archive.org/details/folkcitynewyorka0000petr/page/183 183]–}}</ref> Holcomb was the inspiration for the term "high, lonesome sound", coined by folklorist and friend [[John Cohen (musician)|John Cohen]]. The "high lonesome sound" term is now used to describe [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singing, although Holcomb was not, strictly speaking, a bluegrass performer.{{cn|date=July 2024}}

==Performance style==
Holcomb's repertoire included [[old-time music]], [[hymns]], [[traditional music]] and [[blues]] ballads. In addition to playing the banjo and guitar, he was a competent [[harmonica]] and [[fiddle]] player, and sang many of his most memorable songs [[a cappella]]. Holcomb stated: "Up till then the blues were only inside me; [[Blind Lemon]] was the first to 'let out' the blues."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Devil's Music|author=Giles Oakley|publisher=[[Da Capo Press]]|page=[https://archive.org/details/devilsmusichisto00oakl_0/page/116 116]|isbn=978-0-306-80743-5|date=1997|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/devilsmusichisto00oakl_0/page/116}}</ref>

Holcomb sang in a nasal style informed by the [[Old Regular Baptist]] vocal tradition. [[Bob Dylan]], a fan of Holcomb, described his singing as possessing "an untamed sense of control".<ref name="AllMusic_Untamed">{{AllMusic|album|mw0000019275|''An Untamed Sense of Control''}}</ref> He was also admired by the [[Stanley Brothers]] and [[Eric Clapton]], who cited Holcomb as his favorite country musician.<ref name="AllMusic_Untamed" />

==Life and career ==
A [[coal miner]], construction laborer and farmer for much of his life,<ref name="Wolfe2015">{{cite book|author=Charles K. Wolfe|title=Kentucky Country: Folk and Country Music of Kentucky|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZJIfBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA154|date=5 February 2015|publisher=[[University Press of Kentucky]]|isbn=978-0-8131-4960-8|pages=154–}}</ref> Holcomb was not recorded until 1958, after which his career as a professional musician was bolstered by the [[folk revival]] in the 1960s. Holcomb gave his last live performance in 1978. Due to what he described as injuries he sustained during his long career as a laborer, Holcomb was eventually unable to work for more than short periods, and his later income came primarily from his music. Suffering from asthma and [[emphysema]] as a result of working in coal mines, he died in a nursing home in 1981, at the age of 68.<ref name="cohen2">{{cite book|author=John Cohen|title=The High & Lonesome Sound: The Legacy of Roscoe Holcomb|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9KpPYgEACAAJ|year=2012|publisher=Steidl|isbn=978-3-86930-254-6}}</ref>

==Discography==
Holcomb's discography includes the following albums released on LP during his lifetime:<ref name="discogs-artist">{{Discogs artist}}</ref>
* ''The Music of Roscoe Holcomb and Wade Ward'', [[Folkways Records]], 1962
* ''The High Lonesome Sound'', Folkways Records, 1965
* ''Close to Home'', Folkways Records, 1975

The following single-artist compilations have been released since his death:<ref name="discogs-artist" />
* ''The High Lonesome Sound'', [[Smithsonian Folkways]], 1998
* ''An Untamed Sense of Control'', Smithsonian Folkways, 2003

Holcomb's work appears on many multiple-artist compilations, including the following released during his lifetime:<!-- note: multiple-artist compilations released after Holcomb's death are likely not notable enough to list -->
* ''Mountain Music of Kentucky'', Folkways Records, 1960 (6 of 29 tracks)<ref>{{Discogs master|592027|Mountain Music of Kentucky|type=album}}</ref>
* ''FOTM – Friends of Old Time Music'', Folkways Records, 1964 (2 of 16 tracks)<ref>{{Discogs master|568901|FOTM – Friends of Old Time Music|type=album}}</ref>
* ''[[Zabriskie Point (album)|Zabriskie Point (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)]]'', [[MGM Records]], 1970 (1 of 11 tracks)<ref>{{Discogs master|78667|Zabriskie Point (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)|type=album}}</ref>
* ''3rd Annual Brandywine Mountain Music Convention – '76 Music of Kentucky'', Heritage Records [Virginia]<!-- do not link -- as of March 2018, [[Heritage Records]] lists: [[Heritage Records (United States)]], [[Heritage Records (England)]], and [[BMG Heritage Records]], none of which refer to this label! -->, 1977 (2 of 14 tracks)<ref>{{Discogs release|8109578|3rd Annual Brandywine Mountain Music Convention – '76 Music of Kentucky|type=album}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = Run C&W
| image                 = 
| caption            = 
| image_size            = 
| background          = group_or_band
| origin              = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], USA
| genre               = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]
| years_active        = 1992–1995
| label               = [[MCA Records|MCA]]
| past_members        = [[Bernie Leadon]]<ref>{{cite news|title= A Gathering of Eagles |work= The Charlotte Observer |place= Charlotte, North Carolina |date= 26 Aug 1994 |page= 57|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/62488202/the-charlotte-observer/}}</ref><br />[[Vince Melamed]]<ref name=run>{{cite news |work= The Tennessean |place= Nashville, Tennessee |date= 23 Aug 1994 |page= 45 |title= Run for the hills |url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91275323/run-cw/}}</ref><br />[[Jim Photoglo]]<ref name=run/><br />[[Russell Smith (singer)|Russell Smith]]<ref name=run/>
}}
'''Run C&W''' was an American [[novelty music|novelty]]  [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] group that was active in the early 1990s, playing mostly [[cover song|cover renditions]] of classic [[soul music|soul]] and [[R&B]] songs in a [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] or [[Americana (music)|roots country]] style, including banjo, harmonica, [[washboard (musical instrument)|washboard]], and [[vocal harmony|multi-part vocal harmonies]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p22566/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Run C&W Biography |accessdate=2008-03-24 |last=Huey |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= What's going on?|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/91232548/run-cw/ |work= Record-Journal |place= Meriden, Connecticut |date=25 Nov 1994 |page= 49 |quote= ...as the opening act, Run C&W, which performs countrified remakes of r&b classics. }}</ref> They also played a handful of original parody songs. The band's name is a mix of the abbreviation for the "country & western" music genre ([[Country music|C&W]]), and [[Run DMC]], a popular hip-hop group of the time.

The band was composed of veteran musicians including [[lead vocals|lead vocalist]] [[Russell Smith (singer)|Russell Smith]], formerly of the [[Amazing Rhythm Aces]]; [[banjo]]ist [[Bernie Leadon]], formerly of the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] and the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]; along with [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] songwriters [[Jim Photoglo]] and [[Vince Melamed]], both of whom played various instruments.<ref name="allmusic"/> In performance and in the album artwork and liner notes, the members portrayed fictitious non-identical quadruplets The Burns Brothers, each with [[pun]] names: [[wikt:crash and burn|Crash'n Burns]], G.W. "Wash" Burns, [[sideburns|Side Burns]], and [[rug burn|Rug Burns]].<ref name="allmusic"/> Their father was known as "[[wikt:dadburn|Dad Burns]]" and their mother as [[auburn hair|Augusta "Au" Burns]].

Run C&W recorded two albums, both on [[MCA Records]]: 1993's ''Into the Twangy-First Century'', followed by 1994's ''Row vs. Wade'', and filmed at least one [[music video]].

'''Sara Ullrika Watkins''' (born June 8, 1981) is an American singer-songwriter and [[fiddle]]r. Watkins debuted in 1989 as the fiddler of [[Nickel Creek]], the [[progressive bluegrass]] group  she formed with her brother [[Sean Watkins|Sean]] and [[mandolin]]ist [[Chris Thile]]. In addition to singing and fiddling, Watkins also plays the [[ukulele]] and the guitar, and also played percussion while touring with [[the Decemberists]].  In 2012, she and her brother played with [[Jackson Browne]] during his "I'll Do Anything" acoustic tour.

With Nickel Creek, Watkins released five studio albums, one [[compilation album]], and seven [[single (music)|singles]]. During the band's seven-year hiatus, she released three solo albums: ''[[Sara Watkins (album)|Sara Watkins]]'' and ''[[Sun Midnight Sun]]'' on [[Nonesuch Records]] and ''[[Young in All the Wrong Ways]]'' on [[New West Records]].<ref name="nonesuch">[http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-signs-sara-watkins-2008-11-25 "Nonesuch Signs Sara Watkins"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200821224601/https://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-signs-sara-watkins-2008-11-25 |date=August 21, 2020 }}. [[Nonesuch Records]]. November 25, 2008. Retrieved November 29, 2008.</ref>

==Biography==

===1989–2007, 2014–present: Nickel Creek===
{{main|Nickel Creek}}

===2007–present: Solo career===
In late 2005, Watkins stated in a [[PopMatters]] interview when discussing her first solo-written recorded song, "Anthony", that she "definitely [makes] the effort [to write more], but it's something that doesn't come too easy for me. Nor does it come really easy for the guys, I think they've just been doing it for a very long time."<ref name="popmatters">Tranter, Nikki. [https://www.popmatters.com/music/interviews/nickel-creek-051118.shtml "Understanding and Ability"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525042539/http://www.popmatters.com/music/interviews/nickel-creek-051118.shtml |date=May 25, 2011 }}. ''[[PopMatters]]''. November 18, 2005. Retrieved March 27, 2008.</ref>

[[File:SaraWatkinsACL.jpg|thumb|left|Watkins performing at [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]] in 2009]]
Watkins signed as a solo artist with [[Nonesuch Records]] in fall 2008<ref name="nonesuch"/> and released her self-titled debut solo album on April 7, 2009. Watkins started recording the album in February 2008, and it was jointly recorded in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and Los Angeles.<ref name="endoftheroad"/> ''Sara Watkins'' was produced by bassist [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] of [[Led Zeppelin]] fame, who first performed with Watkins on a [[Mutual Admiration Society (album)|Mutual Admiration Society]] tour in 2004.<ref name="endoftheroad">Dickens, Tad. [http://www.roanoke.com/webmin/podcasts/end-of-the-road-for-nickel-creek/article_489db2a0-342d-573e-acd2-2d01dfa1db84.html "End of the road for Nickel Creek?"]. ''[[The Roanoke Times]]''. November 2, 2007. Retrieved March 1, 2008.</ref>

Watkins toured the United States as an opening act in 2008.<ref name="endoftheroad"/> She performed short tours as an opening act for singer-songwriter [[Tift Merritt]] along the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] in March and April<ref name="tiftmerritt">[http://trianglemusic.blogspot.com/2008/01/nickel-creek-members-tours-stop-in-nc.html "Nickel Creek members' tours stop in NC"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708071101/http://trianglemusic.blogspot.com/2008/01/nickel-creek-members-tours-stop-in-nc.html |date=July 8, 2011 }}. ''Triangle Music''. January 24, 2008. Retrieved March 1, 2008.</ref> and with [[Robert Earl Keen]] around [[New England]] in September,<ref name="northampton"/> as well as doing a 17-date tour with [[Donavon Frankenreiter]] in October. On April 14, 2009, she appeared on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'', with Jones on bass, [[Questlove]] of [[The Roots]] on drums, and her brother [[Sean Watkins]] on guitar. On August 28, 2011, she made her debut with ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]],'' at the [[Minnesota State Fair]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hubbard |first=Rob |url=http://www.twincities.com/ci_15989751?nclick_check=1 |title='Prairie Home Companion' hits its stride at Fair |date=September 3, 2010 |publisher=TwinCities.com |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=August 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819083610/http://www.twincities.com/ci_15989751?nclick_check=1 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/2010/10/23/ |title=A Prairie Home Companion for October 23, 2010 &#124; American Public Media |publisher=Origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=August 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084937/http://origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/2010/10/23/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2012, she toured with [[Jackson Browne]] as the opening act for his acoustic winter tour.

In September 2011, Watkins indicated via Twitter that she would begin work on a second album in the fall of 2011. In May 2012, Watkins released her second solo album, ''[[Sun Midnight Sun]]'', again on [[Nonesuch Records]].<ref name="NonesuchRelease">{{cite web|title=Sun Midnight Sun|date=March 14, 2012|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/sun-midnight-sun|publisher=Nonesuch Records|access-date=June 5, 2013|archive-date=September 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927105600/http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/sun-midnight-sun|url-status=live}}</ref> Produced by former [[Simon Dawes]] guitarist [[Blake Mills]], it features guest appearances from [[Fiona Apple]] and Jackson Browne.<ref name="NonesuchRelease" />

In 2016, Watkins won "Instrumentalist of the Year" at the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]].

===Other projects===
[[File:2014APHCstreetdanceSaraWatkins.jpg|thumb|right|Watkins performing at the season opening of ''A Prairie Home Companion'', 2014]]
In 2002, Watkins starred in an advertisement for cell phone provider [[Cingular Wireless]] alongside her former fiddle teacher Dennis Caplinger, as well as other prominent bluegrass artists.<ref name="cingular">[http://www.wrightforyou.com/bgetc.html "A Most Cingular Sensation"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010031149/http://www.wrightforyou.com/bgetc.html |date=October 10, 2007 }}. ''Wright For You''. June 2002. Retrieved June 21, 2008.</ref><ref name="johnmoore">[http://www.wvfest.com/performers/showperformer.html?artid=430 "Brad Davis, Tim May & John Moore"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412171014/http://www.wvfest.com/performers/showperformer.html?artid=430 |date=April 12, 2009 }}.</ref> Between 2000 and 2004, Watkins and the other members of [[Nickel Creek]] ([[Chris Thile]] and [[Sean Watkins]]), [[Glen Phillips (singer)|Glen Phillips]], [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]], and [[Pete Thomas (drummer)|Pete Thomas]] collaborated on an EP, ''[[Mutual Admiration Society Solo Sampler]]''; an album, [[Mutual Admiration Society (album)|''Mutual Admiration Society'']] (recorded in 2000); and a brief tour.

The 2007 documentary film ''[[Arctic Tale]]'' featured a song by Watkins and musician [[Grant-Lee Phillips]], titled "Song of the North (Beneath the Sun)". Watkins lent her vocal talents to the film alongside other performers such as [[Aimee Mann]] and [[Brian Wilson]].<ref>[http://music.msn.com/album/?album=52045085&menu=credits{{Dead link|date=November 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "Arctic Tale [Original Soundtrack&#93;: Credits"]. ''[[MSN]]''. Retrieved April 22, 2008.</ref>

In January 2008, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' reported a new [[Supergroup (music)|supergroup]] octet tentatively named [[The Scrolls]], later named Works Progress Administration (W.P.A.). The octet is composed of Watkins, her brother [[Sean Watkins]] (guitar), [[Glen Phillips (singer)|Glen Phillips]] (guitar, vocals), [[Benmont Tench]] (piano), Luke Bulla (fiddle), [[Greg Leisz]] (various), [[Pete Thomas (drummer)|Pete Thomas]] (drums), and [[Davey Faragher]] (bass). The group released their album ''WPA'' in September 2009.

Watkins is featured on [[Needtobreathe]]'s 2009 CD ''[[The Outsiders (Needtobreathe album)|The Outsiders]]'' on the track "Stones Under Rushing Water".

In late January and early February 2010, Watkins undertook a short tour with [[Jerry Douglas]] and [[Aly Bain]] in Scotland and England under the "[[Transatlantic Sessions]]" banner, culminating in a performance in the [[Royal Festival Hall]] in London on February 6, 2010. In June 2010, Watkins appeared on the [[The Nerdist Podcast|Nerdist]] podcast as a musical guest, performing her best-known solo song, "Long Hot Summer Days" (a [[John Hartford]] cover). Later that summer, she participated in the Summer Love Tour with [[Garrison Keillor]] in venues across the United States.<ref>{{cite web |last=Finke |first=Nikki |url=https://www.deadline.com/2010/04/garrison-keillors-a-prairie-home-companion-skeds-summer-love-25-city-tour/ |title=Garrison Keillor's Prairie Home Companion Skeds "Summer Love" 25-City Tour |publisher=Deadline.com |date=April 14, 2010 |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=July 26, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726190050/http://www.deadline.com/2010/04/garrison-keillors-a-prairie-home-companion-skeds-summer-love-25-city-tour/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She guest hosted Keillor's show, ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'', on January 15, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prairiehome.publicradio.org/features/hodgepodge/2011/01/guest_host/index.shtml |title=January 15: Nickel Creek alum Sara Watkins; clawhammer banjo player Abigail Washburn; singer-songwriter Tom Brosseau |publisher=Prairiehome.publicradio.org |date=January 31, 2011 |access-date=May 6, 2015}}</ref> Watkins contributed fiddle, guitar, percussion, and vocals on [[The Decemberists]]' 2011 tour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.decemberists.com/news/the-decemberists-news-1-4-10/ |title=News 1.4.10 |publisher=Thedecemberists.com |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231905/http://www.decemberists.com/news/the-decemberists-news-1-4-10/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Also in 2011, she (and her brother Sean) began to perform as a musician and singer in the humor/retro-radio podcast "[[Thrilling Adventure Hour]]".

Watkins played violin and sang on "A Face To Call Home" on [[John Mayer]]'s 2012 album ''[[Born and Raised (John Mayer album)|Born and Raised]]''. During 2012 and 2013, she toured with Jackson Browne, both as an opening act and accompanying him during the performance.

Watkins and her brother Sean play regularly at the [[Largo (nightclub)|Largo]] nightclub in Los Angeles as "[[Watkins Family Hour]]". Keyboardist [[Benmont Tench]] (of [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]]) and bassist [[Sebastian Steinberg]] (formerly of Soul Coughing) are regular participants, and other guest musicians from the Largo family generally show up as well, including [[Jon Brion]], Fiona Apple, Don Heffington, [[Greg Leisz]], and former Nickel Creek bandmate [[Chris Thile]] when he is in town. The irregular collaborations led to a 2015 album and tour under the same name.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McCue|first1=Lori|title=Sean and Sara Watkins are taking their Watkins Family Hour on the road, and bringing famous friends|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2015/09/03/sean-and-sara-watkins-are-taking-their-watkins-family-hour-on-the-road-and-bringing-famous-friends/|access-date=July 14, 2016|newspaper=Washington Post|date=September 3, 2015|archive-date=August 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822083302/https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2015/09/03/sean-and-sara-watkins-are-taking-their-watkins-family-hour-on-the-road-and-bringing-famous-friends/|url-status=live}}</ref> Also in 2015, Watkins toured extensively with [[Sarah Jarosz]] and [[Aoife O'Donovan]] (of [[Crooked Still]] fame). The trio, who now play under the name [[I'm with Her (band)|I'm With Her]], hosted the radio show ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' on October 10, 2015. Watkins also performed vocals for "June & Johnny" on [[Jon Foreman]]'s 2015 EP ''[[The Wonderlands: Darkness]]''.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SaraWatkins|author=Sara Watkins|number=634774137374941186|date=August 21, 2015|title=I sang with @jonforeman on his song June and Johnny – out today on @Spotify!! Link below. Thanks Jon! Check it out!}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz|title=I'm With Her: 'We're about camaraderie, not Hillary'|first=Emma|last=John|date=February 18, 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref>

In 2020, she played fiddle on [[Phoebe Bridgers]]'s record ''[[Punisher (Phoebe Bridgers album)|Punisher]]'', on track 10 "Graceland Too".

In 2021, she played fiddle on [[The Killers]]'s record ''[[Pressure Machine]]'' (Tracks: ''West Fields'', ''Cody'', ''Pressure Machine'') and violin on ''In Another Life''.

===Personal life===
On August 16, 2008, Watkins married Todd Cooper in her parents' backyard in [[Vista, California|Vista]], California.<ref name="northampton">[http://sarawatkins.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=1 "Sept – Northampton, MA"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716005146/http://sarawatkins.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=1 |date=July 16, 2011 }}. Sarawatkins.com. September 2008. Retrieved September 16, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://glenphillips.net/blog/?p=70 "Summer Is Almost Over..."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412072047/http://glenphillips.net/blog/?p=70 |date=April 12, 2009 }}. Glenphillips.com. August 24, 2008. Retrieved August 30, 2008.</ref> On June 15, 2017, she announced via Twitter that she and her husband were expecting a child in September.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SaraWatkins|author=Sara Watkins|number=875344896118468609|date=June 15, 2017|title=Well, it's about time to fess up and tell you all that in September, my husband and I are…}}</ref>

| image_size        = 250px

| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|[[mandolin]]|[[banjo]]|guitar|[[octave mandolin]]}}

| occupation        = Singer-songwriter
| years_active      = 2009–present

'''Sarah Ellen Jarosz''' ({{IPAc-en|dʒ|ə|ˈ|r|oʊ|z}} {{respell|jə|ROHZ|'}}; born May 23, 1991) is an American singer-songwriter from [[Wimberley, Texas]]. Her debut studio album, ''[[Song Up in Her Head]]'', was released in 2009<ref name="auto">[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105374610 "A Bluegrass Debutante, A High School Graduate"] ''NPR All Songs Considered''. June 14, 2009. Retrieved January 21, 2010.</ref> and the song "Mansinneedof" was nominated for a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance|Best Country Instrumental Performance]].<ref>[http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/52nd_show/list.aspx#08 "52nd Annual Grammy Awards Nominees List"] ''Grammys''. Retrieved January 21, 2010.</ref> Her second studio album, ''[[Follow Me Down (album)|Follow Me Down]]'', released in 2011, received a Song of the Year nomination from the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Association's 2012 Honors and Awards]]. Her third studio album, ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'', was released on September 24, 2013 through [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'' was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]], and its title track was nominated for Best American Roots Song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees|title=GRAMMY.com - The Official Site of Music's Biggest Night|work=The GRAMMYs|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}</ref> In 2016, Jarosz released her fourth studio album, ''[[Undercurrent (Sarah Jarosz album)|Undercurrent]]''. The album won two Grammy Awards (Best Folk Album and [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Performance|Best American Roots Performance]] for the song "House of Mercy").

On June 5, 2020 she released the album ''[[World on the Ground]]'', her first solo studio album in four years. It was nominated for two Grammy Awards (Best American Roots Song and Best Americana Album) with Jarosz winning in the [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]] category.

==Early life and education==
Sarah Ellen Jarosz<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/903658223 |title=ANNABELLE LEE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 26, 2023}}</ref> was born in [[Austin, Texas]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Sarah Jarosz Build Me Up From Bones |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2013-10-04/sarah-jarosz-build-me-up-from-bones/ |publisher=[[Austin Chronicle]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=October 4, 2013}}</ref> and raised in [[Wimberley, Texas]]. Her parents were teachers. Her last name is [[Polish people|Polish]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-menaker/all-that-jarosz_b_865977.html|title=All That Jarosz|work=The Huffington Post|date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=August 5, 2015}}</ref> She began learning the [[mandolin]] at age 10 and later began learning to play the guitar, clawhammer banjo, and octave mandolin. During her senior year of high school, Jarosz signed a recording contract with [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] and released her debut album ''[[Song Up in Her Head]]'' in June 2009; it was produced by Jarosz and [[Gary Paczosa]]. Guest musicians on the album included [[Chris Thile]], [[Darrell Scott]], [[Stuart Duncan]], and [[Jerry Douglas]]. Jarosz enrolled in the [[New England Conservatory of Music]] in 2009, and graduated with honors in 2013 with a degree in Contemporary Improvisation.<ref name="auto"/>

==Career==
[[File:Sarah Jarosz 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Jarosz performing in [[San Francisco]], 2014]]
In 2010 Jarosz recorded the album ''Follow Me Down'' and again shared production duties with [[Gary Paczosa]].  The album was recorded in Nashville and features guest musicians [[Bela Fleck]], Jerry Douglas, Stuart Duncan, [[Viktor Krauss]], [[Dan Tyminski]], [[Shawn Colvin]], Darrell Scott, and bandmates Alex Hargreaves and Nathaniel Smith. A session with [[Punch Brothers]] in New York produced a cover of the [[Radiohead]] song  "The Tourist". An ''American Songwriter'' reviewer wrote that "Jarosz invites us along with her into a growing sonic space of collaboration and artistry at this the second step in what will surely be a long and productive musical journey."
In 2011 Jarosz performed at [[Jerry Douglas]]' the [[Transatlantic Sessions]] in Scotland. She performed [[Bob Dylan]]'s "Ring Them Bells."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ernesttroost.com/blog/sarah_jarosz__the_transatlantic_sessions/|title=Ernest Troost|work=ernesttroost.com|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}</ref>

In 2012, Jarosz appeared on [[Kate Rusby]]'s album ''[[20 (Kate Rusby album)|20]]'', collaborating with Rusby on the song "Planets".

In 2015, Jarosz toured extensively with [[Sara Watkins]] (a founding member of [[Nickel Creek]]) and [[Aoife O'Donovan]] (of [[Crooked Still]] fame) as well as going on tour with [[Garrison Keillor]] on ''The America the Beautiful Tour – A Prairie Home Companion''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2015/04/im-with-her-tour-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz-and-aoife-odonovan/ | title=I'm with Her Tour: Sara Watkins, Sarah Jarosz and Aoife O'Donovan | work=Folk Radio UK | date=April 26, 2015 | accessdate=April 23, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://prairiehome.org/america-the-beautiful/ | title=The America the Beautiful Tour | work=A Prairie Home Companion | accessdate=April 23, 2016}}</ref> In 2016, she became a regular performer on the weekly [[NPR]] series ''[[Live from Here]]'', hosted by [[Chris Thile]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.livefromhere.org/pages/performers-staff-writers/ | title=Live from Here with Chris Thile: Performers and Staff | work=[[National Public Radio|NPR]] | accessdate=June 24, 2020}}</ref>

Together with Watkins and O'Donovan, Jarosz became a founding member of the progressive-folk trio [[I'm With Her (band)|I'm With Her]]. They released their debut album, ''[[See You Around]]'', in 2018.

Her fourth studio album, ''Undercurrent'', was released on June 17, 2016.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/03/sarah-jarosz-announces-her-fourth-album-undercurre.html | title=Sarah Jarosz Announces Her Fourth Album Undercurrent For June Release | work=Paste Magazine | date=March 1, 2016 | accessdate=April 23, 2016}}</ref> It won the Grammy for [[Best Folk Album]] along with the song "House of Mercy" winning the Grammy for [[Best American Roots Performance]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|2017 Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7597556/grammys-nominees-complete-list-2017|title=Here Is the Complete List of Nominees for the 2017 Grammys|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=September 15, 2019}}</ref><ref name="GrammyDB">{{Cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=%22Sarah+Jarosz%22&field_nominee_work_value=&year=All&genre=All |title=Past winners search |website=grammy.org}}</ref>

In 2020, Jarosz returned to her solo career with her fifth studio album, ''[[World on the Ground]]''.<ref name="Betts">{{cite web |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Sarah Jarosz Previews New Album 'World on the Ground' With Wistful Song 'Johnny' |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/sarah-jarosz-previews-new-album-world-on-the-ground-with-wistful-song-johnny/ar-BB11DWbv |publisher=MSN |accessdate=7 April 2020}}</ref> This was followed 11 months later by the release of her sixth studio album, ''[[Blue Heron Suite]]''. The previously-shelved collection was originally written and recorded between 2017 and 2018.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Farthing |first1=Lydia |title=Sarah Jarosz To Release New Project, 'Blue Heron Suite' |url=https://musicrow.com/2021/04/sarah-jarosz-to-release-new-project-blue-heron-suite/ |website=Music Row |date=April 14, 2021 |publisher=Music Row Enterprises, LLC |access-date=25 June 2021}}</ref>

On September 7, 2023, Jarosz released the official video of her song "Jealous Moon", from her album ''[[Polaroid Lovers]]'', which was released on January 26, 2024.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w8SuGm1aD-A |title=Sarah Jarosz: Jealous Moon (Official video) |last=Jarosz |first=Sarah |date=September 7, 2023 |website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=September 8, 2023}}</ref>  October 10 saw the release of "Columbus & 89th", the second single off the album.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://femmusic.com/wp/2023/10/10/sarah-jarosz-columbus-89th/|title=Sarah Jarosz – Columbus & 89th|author=FEM MUSIC Staff|date=October 10, 2023|publisher=FEMMUSIC.com|accessdate=October 15, 2023}}</ref>

==Critical reception==
Jarosz has been called "a songwriter of uncommon wisdom" by the ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''.<ref>Moser, Margaret. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/review?oid=oid%3A792554 "Texas Platters: Sarah Jarosz"] ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''. June 12, 2009. Retrieved January 21, 2010.</ref> Jarosz has been interviewed by [[NPR]] and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and described as a contemporary-bluegrass [[Child prodigy|prodigy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105374610|title=A Bluegrass Débutante, A Highschool Graduate|work=[[All Things Considered]]|date=June 13, 2009|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=December 3, 2014}}</ref> A ''[[New York Times]]'' reviewer wrote that Jarosz is "widely regarded as one of acoustic music's most promising young talents: a singer-songwriter and mandolin and banjo prodigy with the taste and poise to strike that rare balance of commercial and critical success."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/us/08ttlanger.htm0l|title=Singer, Songwriter, Prodigy, All at 19"|last=Langer|first=Andy|date=May 7, 2011|work=[[The Texas Tribune]]|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=December 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908190303/https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/us/08ttlanger.html|archive-date=September 8, 2023}}</ref>
Her 2013 release, ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'', was dubbed by Stereo Subversion as an "organic masterwork...a warm, nuanced collection that wraps and enchants the listener", as well as "her boldest work yet" by WNYC Soundcheck.
[[File:Sarah Jarosz 1 - Ron Baker 2012.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Jarosz performing at Old Settler's Music Festival 2012]]

{{Awards table}}
|-

{{Infobox musical artist
| image             = Shawncamp-fls.jpg
| caption           = Performing at Suwannee Springtime Reunion, March 22, 2018
| name              = Shawn Camp
| background        = solo_singer
| birth_name        = Darrell DeShawn Camp<ref>{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&querytype=WriterID&keyid=520279&keyname=CAMP%20DARRELL%20DE%20SHAWN&CAE=128966143&Affiliation=BMI|title=Listing for Darrell DeShawn Camp|work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|access-date=January 19, 2010}}</ref>
| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1966|8|29}}
| origin            = [[Perryville, Arkansas]], US
| instrument        = Vocals, guitar, fiddle
| genre             = [[country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[americana (music)|Americana]]
| occupation        = Singer-songwriter
| years_active      = 1991–present
| label             = [[Reprise Records|Reprise]], Skeeterbit, [[Oh Boy Records|Oh Boy]]
| associated_acts   = [[Tim Mensy]]<br />[[Josh Turner]]<br />[[The Earls of Leicester]]
| partner           = Lisa Stewart (2021-present)
| website           = {{url|shawncamp.com}}
}}

'''Darrell DeShawn Camp''' (born August 29, 1966) is an American musician who performs [[country music|country]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] music. Originally signed to [[Reprise Records]] in 1993 as a recording artist, Camp charted two minor singles on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts that year. Since then he has found success as a songwriter, having co-written hit singles for many country music artists, including [[Willie Nelson]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[Josh Turner]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], and [[Blake Shelton]], although he continues to record his own material as well. The 2023 Grammy Awards presented the legendary Willie Nelson's "A Beautiful Time" with "Country Album of The Year". The title cut, along with album cut, "We're Not Happy ('Til You're Not Happy)", were both penned by Camp.

==Biography==
Camp was raised in [[Perryville, Arkansas]] by a musical family.<ref name="allmusic">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shawn-camp-mn0000015822/biography|title=Shawn Camp &#124; Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=January 22, 2020}}</ref> In 1987, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and worked in the backing bands of  acts including The Grand Prairie Boys, [[Osborne Brothers]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], and [[Trisha Yearwood]].<ref name="camp">{{Cite web|url=http://www.shawncamp.com/about.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070529181547/http://www.shawncamp.com/about.html|url-status=dead|title=Shawn Camp: About|archive-date=May 29, 2007}}</ref> In 1991, he was signed to [[Reprise Records]], with two minor Top 40 singles charting in 1993.<ref name="camp"/> The first of these, "Fallin' Never Felt So Good", was previously recorded by [[Dude Mowrey]].

Camp recorded a second album for Reprise, but never released it due to creative differences. He then began writing for other artists. Camp's first Number One as a songwriter came in early 1998, when [[Garth Brooks]] reached the top of the ''Billboard'' country charts with "[[Two Piña Coladas]]", a song co-written by Camp.<ref name="allmusic"/> Later in the same year, [[Brooks & Dunn]] reached Number One with "[[How Long Gone]]", another Camp co-write.<ref name="camp"/><ref name="pdf">{{cite web |url=http://ohboy.com/media/shawncamppublicity.pdf |title=Archived copy |website=ohboy.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040919173438/http://ohboy.com/media/shawncamppublicity.pdf |archive-date=19 September 2004 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

Camp released ''Lucky Silver Dollar'' in 2001.<ref name="camp"/> In 2006, he was nominated as Songwriter of the Year by the Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music; also, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranked him No.10 on their 2006 list of Hot Country Songwriters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cowboyjackclement.com/shawn_camp/ |title=Shawn Camp and Jack Clement |website=www.cowboyjackclement.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061108012231/http://www.cowboyjackclement.com/shawn_camp/ |archive-date=8 November 2006 |url-status=dead}}</ref> In the same year, two songs co-written by Camp entered the country charts: "[[Nobody But Me (Blake Shelton song)|Nobody But Me]]" by [[Blake Shelton]], and "[[Would You Go with Me]]" by [[Josh Turner]], which peaked at No.4 and No.1, respectively, on the ''Billboard'' U.S. [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Camp also co-wrote Turner's 2007 single "[[Firecracker (song)|Firecracker]]", [[George Strait]]'s 2008 single "[[River of Love]]", and [[Billy Currington]]'s 2011 single "[[Love Done Gone]]".

Since early 2007, Camp had been collaborating with country legend [[Loretta Lynn]] writing songs such as "I'm Dyin' for Someone to Live For" and "I'm More Alone When I'm With You" together. Camp has featured some of the photographs taken at the Cash Cabin Studios in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]] which many believe means he is going to be duetting on some of Lynn's upcoming albums. The pair usually wrote together at Lynn's home in [[Hurricane Mills, Tennessee]] (known as The Loretta Lynn Dude Ranch.)

In September 2010, Reprise Records issued the previously-unreleased 1994 album, retitled ''1994''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2010/09/03/shawn-camps-shelved-1994-album-to-be-released/|title=Shawn Camp's shelved 1994 album to be released|last=Cooper|first=Peter|date=September 3, 2010|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=September 27, 2010}}</ref>

In 2012, Camp won Album of the Year at the American Music Awards for his co production with [[Tamara Saviano]] of ''This One's for Him: A Tribute to Guy Clark''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://americanamusic.org/recipient-archive |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 6, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018055116/http://americanamusic.org/recipient-archive |archive-date=October 18, 2012 }}</ref>

In 2013, Camp became the lead vocalist for [[The Earls of Leicester]] and he has been a session musician.

In January 2014, Camp won a Grammy Award for his production of [[Guy Clark]]'s album ''[[My Favorite Picture of You]]''.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/movie-news/grammy-awards-2014-the-complete-winners-list-186621/|title=Grammy Awards 2014: The Complete Winners List|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 27, 2014|access-date=January 22, 2020}}</ref> This was his second Grammy nomination for Best Folk Album of the Year, in December, 2012, he and co-producer Tamara Saviano, were nominated for ''This One's for Him: A Tribute to Guy Clark''.

The 2023 Grammy Awards presented the legendary Willie Nelson's "A Beautiful Time" with "Country Album of The Year". The title cut, along with album cut, "We're Not Happy 'Til You're Not Happy", were both penned by Camp.

{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Sierra Hull
| image           = Sierra Hull.jpg
| image_size      = 250
| landscape       = yes
| caption         = Hull in 2009
| birth_name      = Sierra Dawn Hull
| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1991|09|27}}
| birth_place     = [[Byrdstown]], [[Tennessee]]
| genre           = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]
| occupation      = Musician, singer, songwriter
| instrument      = [[Mandolin]], guitar, vocals
| years_active    = 2002–present
| spouse         = [[Justin Moses]] (m. May 14, 2017)
| label           = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]
| website         = {{URL|www.sierrahull.com}}
}}
'''Sierra Dawn Hull''' (born September 27, 1991) is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-ott-0219-sierra-hull-20160218-story.html|title=How bluegrass prodigy Sierra Hull turned frustration into inspiration|first=Chrissie|last=Dickinson|website=chicagotribune.com|date=February 18, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bluegrassmusic.com/content/2016/feature/sierra-hull-takes-weight-off-mind/|title=Sierra Hull, Takes a Weight Off Her Mind|date=May 1, 2016|website=Bluegrass Unlimited}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/daybreak/1440792724|title=Daybreak by Sierra Hull|via=music.apple.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://patch.com/massachusetts/backbay/calendar/event/20180201/289125/sierra-hull-w-opener-phoebe-hunt-at-city-winery|title=Sierra Hull w/ Opener Phoebe Hunt at City Winery|date=January 26, 2018|website=Back Bay, MA Patch}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unifiednewsgroup.com/singer-songwriter-hull-to-perform-march/article_7a1322ab-d5da-5c5e-81c8-a45bdce0f1cb.html|title=Singer-songwriter Hull to perform March 4|first=Bill Livick Unified Newspaper|last=Group|website=Unified Newspaper Group|date=February 21, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lrbaggs.com/artists/sierra-hull|title=Sierra Hull|website=LR Baggs}}</ref> mandolinist, and guitarist.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ledgin|first=Stephanie|title=Homegrown Music: Discovering Bluegrass|year=2004|publisher=Praeger|isbn=978-0275981150|page=116|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7kgBY8tV6zYC&q=%22Sierra+Dawn+Hull%22&pg=PA116}}</ref>

Hull was signed to [[Rounder Records]] at the age of 13<ref name=Biography>{{citation | title= Sierra Hull Biography | author=Steve Leggett | work=Billboard.com | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=sierra hull|bio=true}} |accessdate=March 15, 2011 }}</ref> and released her debut vocal album, ''Secrets'', in 2008 at the age of 16. The album peaked at No.&nbsp;2 on the ''Billboard'' Top Bluegrass Albums chart.<ref name=Chart>{{citation | title= Secrets - Billboard.com | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=sierra hull|chart=all}} |accessdate=March 15, 2011 }}</ref> Her second album, ''Daybreak'', was released on March 8, 2011.<ref name=Daybreak>{{citation | title= Music Review – New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/arts/music/sierra-hull-sings-bluegrass-at-the-living-room-review.html |accessdate=March 15, 2011 | work=The New York Times | first=Jon | last=Caramanica | date=March 9, 2011}}</ref>

==Early life and career==
Sierra Hull was born and raised in [[Byrdstown, Tennessee|Byrdstown]], Tennessee and attended Pickett County High School before accepting a Presidential Scholarship to study at the [[Berklee College of Music]].<ref name=Scholarship>{{citation | title=2009–2010 Presidential Scholars | author=Berklee Media Relations | work=Berklee College of Music website | url=http://www.berklee.edu/news/1531/2009-2010-presidential-scholars | accessdate=March 15, 2011 }}</ref>

Hull began playing the mandolin at the age of eight and put out the album ''Angel Mountain'' at 10. She was soon playing jam sessions with other musicians in her family, and by 2001 she was entering local talent contests. Her parents, Stacy and Brenda Hull, took her to numerous bluegrass festivals and it was during an [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] festival that she came to the attention of [[Rounder Records]] chief talent scout Ken Irwin.<ref name=scout>{{citation | title= Teen Sierra Hull Is Turning Heads | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1595975/teen-sierra-hull-is-turning-heads-in-bluegrass.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081001201557/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1595975/teen-sierra-hull-is-turning-heads-in-bluegrass.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=October 1, 2008 | author= Edward Morris | work=CMT.com | accessdate=March 15, 2011 }}</ref> At age 11 she was mentored and befriended by [[Alison Krauss]], herself once a child prodigy on the fiddle.<ref>Steve Leggett, "[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sierra-hull-p1031466 Sierra Hull]," ''Allmusic''.  Retrieved: March 1, 2013.</ref> Hull and Krauss, along with [[Dan Tyminski]], performed at the [[White House]] on November 21, 2011.<ref>John Lawless, "[http://bluegrasstoday.com/sierra-hull-reporting-from-the-white-house/ Sierra Hull, reporting from the White House]," ''Bluegrass Today'', November 30, 2011.</ref>

[[File:Sierrahull-fls-2.jpg|left|thumb|Hull at MerleFest in 2017]]She has a brother, Cody, and is a distant cousin of former United States Secretary of State [[Cordell Hull]].<ref name=Cordell>{{citation | title=The Latest Gifted Hull | author=David McGee | work=The Bluegrass Special | url=http://www.thebluegrassspecial.com/archive/2008/may2008/shawhullfeaturemay08.php | accessdate=March 15, 2011 }}</ref>

Hull has won ten International Bluegrass Music Association awards between 2010 and 2023, including winning best mandolin player in 6 out of the past 8 years (2016-2023).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ibma.org/awards-by-year/|title=IBMA official website|year=2024|accessdate=August 23, 2024}}</ref>

Hull received the Bluegrass Star Award, presented by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation, on October 19, 2013.  The award is bestowed upon bluegrass artists who do an exemplary job of advancing traditional bluegrass music and bringing it to new audiences while preserving its character and heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrassheritage.org/bluegrass-star-award/|title=Bluegrass Heritage Foundation official website|year=2010|accessdate=December 28, 2015}}</ref>

==Touring==
Hull performed with the band Highway 111 at the Gettysburg Bluegrass festival in 2005. She continued to tour, even while she attended Berklee College of Music.<ref>"Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival, ''Strings'', newsletter of the Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society, October 2005</ref>

Hull has also recorded and toured with [[Cory Wong]], featured as a supporting act and collaborative partner on a 2022 tour.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-02 |title=Cory Wong Announces Two-Part Collaborative Tour with Sierra Hull, Victor Wooten and More |url=https://relix.com/news/detail/cory-wong-announces-two-part-collaborative-tour-with-sierra-hull-victor-wooten-and-more/ |access-date=2023-01-29 |website=Relix Media |language=en-US}}</ref>

==Recordings==

===''Secrets''===
Hull's vocal debut album on [[Rounder Records]], released in May 2008, was co-produced by [[Alison Krauss]] and [[Ron Block]] which follows a self-released CD ''Angel Mountain'', in 2002. The production by Hull and Ron Block paid tribute and honored the tradition and style of bluegrass music. The album contained 3 original songs penned by Hull. She was just 15 when she recorded the album and 16 when it was released.

===''Daybreak''===
On her 2011 second release on Rounder Records, the 20-year-old has composed seven of the 12 songs and it was produced by [[Alison Krauss & Union Station]] bassist [[Barry Bales]]. The album features collaborations with Bryan Sutton on guitar and Randy Kohrs on dobro. Guest singers include [[Dan Tyminski]], Shawn Lane and Ronnie Bowman.

=== ''Features'' ===
Hull was a guest vocalist with lead singer James Adkins on the male-female duet "Love Song",<ref>{{Cite web|title = Big Virginia Sky releases debut, self-titled album!|url = http://www.bigvirginiasky.com/news/2015/10/3/big-virginia-sky-releases-debut-self-titled-album|website = Big Virginia Sky|access-date = January 12, 2016}}</ref> featured on the 2015 self-titled album from Americana group [[Big Virginia Sky]].

=== ''Weighted Mind'' ===
Released on January 29, 2016, ''[[Weighted Mind]]'', Hull's third LP, was produced by the highly regarded banjo player [[Béla Fleck]], who encouraged Hull to consider recording it solo.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mandolincafe.com/forum/content.php?201-Sierra-Hull-The-Weighted-Mind-Interview|title=Mandolin Cafe – Sierra Hull – The Weighted Mind Interview|work=Mandolin Cafe Forum|access-date=April 10, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Hull, however, decided to enlist an accompanist, bassist Ethan Jodziewicz, who is featured on every track. The album also includes vocal contributions by [[Alison Krauss]], [[Abigail Washburn]], and [[Rhiannon Giddens]].

NPR reviewer Jewly Hight called ''Weighted Mind'' a "stunning coming-of-age album," adding that "Hull has joined the rarefied company of [[Nickel Creek]] expats [[Chris Thile]], [[Sara Watkins]] and [[Sean Watkins]], pedigreed virtuosos whose youthful, searching musical minds have taken them into postmodern singer-songwriter territory and beyond."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/01/20/463722383/first-listen-sierra-hull-weighted-mind|title=Review: Sierra Hull, 'Weighted Mind'|website=NPR.org|access-date=April 10, 2017}}</ref>

=== ''Treasure Of The Broken Land: The Songs Of Mark Heard'' ===
Hull contributed her cover of "Strong Hand of Love" in a [[Mark Heard]] tribute album entitled "Treasure Of The Broken Land: The Songs Of Mark Heard" (Storm Weathered Records) in 2017.

===''25 Trips''===
Released on February 28, 2020, co-produced by Hull and producer / engineer Shani Gandhi, features guitarist Mike Seal, bassist Ethan Jodziewicz, violinist Alex Hargreaves, and fiddler Christian Sedelmyer, together with bassist Viktor Krauss, guitarist Bryan Sutton, multi-instrumentalist Stuart Duncan, and steel guitarist Paul Franklin, and guest appearances by Molly Tuttle, Ron Block, Mindy Smith, Ronnie Bowman, Katie Pruitt, Angel Snow, and Hull's husband, multi-instrumentalist Justin Moses.

Liam Lewis opined, "25 Trips is an eclectic album, with a contemporary feel, showcasing Hull’s songwriting and exceptional vocals, crystal clear but with emotion and character, on 13 songs, self and co-written on the pleasures and travails of becoming the person and the musician she is today."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellesandgals.com/2020/03/12/review-sierra-hull-25-trips/|title=Review: Sierra Hull – 25 Trips|first=Liam|last=Lewis|date=March 12, 2020|accessdate=March 15, 2021}}</ref>

Hull appeared as one of the musicians on ''[[Cuttin' Grass, Vol. 1: The Butcher Shoppe Sessions|Cuttin' Grass]]'', the 2020 bluegrass album by [[Sturgill Simpson]].

==Personal life==
[[File:Bela Fleck concert for My Bluegrass Heart 2, April 12 2022.jpg|thumb|Hull (mandolin, second from left) and her husband Justin Moses (dobro, left) in 2022, playing on tour for [[Bela Fleck]]'s album [[My Bluegrass Heart]].]] 
Hull married fellow bluegrass musician [[Justin Moses]] on May 14, 2017. Hull and Moses tour together.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/congratulations-sierra-and-justin/ |title=Congratulations Sierra and Justin! |last=Lawless |first=John |website=Bluegrass Today |date=June 2, 2017 |access-date=August 31, 2018}}</ref> She lives in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tahoeonstage.com/genres/americana/sierra-hull-record/ |title=Sierra Hull sets record straight about her name and that ring |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=May 4, 2017 |website=Tahoe Onstage |access-date=August 31, 2018}}</ref>

| name             = Sonya Isaacs

| occupation       = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]]
| years_active     = 1999–present
| label            = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]
| current_member_of = [[The Isaacs]]
| spouse = {{marriage|[[Jimmy Yeary]]|2009}}

'''Sonya Melissa Isaacs''' (born July 22, 1974) is an American [[country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass gospel]] and [[Christian music]] singer. Isaacs grew up near [[Morrow, Ohio]], and graduated from [[Little Miami High School (Ohio)|Little Miami High School]] in 1992. Her maternal  grandparents are [[The Holocaust in Poland|Polish Jewish Holocaust]] survivors and were liberated from a concentration camp in Germany in 1945.<ref name="lufkin">{{cite news |last1=BARCLAY |first1=BRITTANY |title=The Isaacs to bring bluegrass gospel to The Pines |url=https://lufkindailynews.com/news/community/article_94d60ad4-b88c-5651-a672-7ce01b2b7c36.html |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=The Lufkin Daily News |language=en}}</ref><ref name="people">{{cite news |last1=Etienne |first1=Vanessa |title=The Isaacs Premiere 'The American Face' Music Video: 'United We Stand' |url=https://people.com/music/isaacs-premiere-the-american-face-music-video-united-we-stand/ |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=PEOPLE.com |language=en}}</ref>

She has released one album on [[Lyric Street Records]], and has charted five singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Three were included on her self-titled debut album, released in 2000. A fourth was a Christmas single included on the label's multi-artist collection ''No Wrapping Required: A Christmas Album''. Her highest-charting single, "No Regrets Yet", peaked at number 36 on the country charts but did not appear on an album.

She parted ways with Lyric Street in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/transportation-communications/communications-radio/4361802-1.html |title=On the Row: Compadre Records Signs Three Artists |access-date=January 4, 2008 |last=Stark |first=Phyllis |date=March 12, 2004 |work=Airplay Monitors}}</ref> Isaacs, along with several of her family members, also comprise a [[gospel music]] band called [[The Isaacs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050225200135/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 25, 2005 |title=The Isaacs biography |access-date=January 4, 2008 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}}</ref> Sonya recorded the song "The Battlefield" for the soundtrack to the 2006 film ''[[Broken Bridges]]''. She and [[Vince Gill]] contributed guest vocals to a cover of "[[Misty (song)|Misty]]" on [[Cledus T. Judd]]'s 2007 tribute album ''[[Boogity, Boogity – A Tribute to the Comedic Genius of Ray Stevens]]''.

She also sang a duet with [[Dolly Parton]] to "The Angels Rejoiced".

Isaacs married singer-songwriter [[Jimmy Yeary]] on December 20, 2009, with whom she co-wrote [[Martina McBride]]'s 2011 single "[[I'm Gonna Love You Through It]]".

Isaacs and Yeary have two sons born in 2011 and 2015, and a daughter born in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brad Schmitt |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2016/08/26/sonya-isaacs-healing-stillborn-birth/89225046/ |title=Sonya Isaacs healing from stillborn birth |publisher=Tennessean.com |access-date=August 26, 2016}}</ref>

As a member of ''The Isaacs'', Isaacs became a [[List of Grand Ole Opry members|member]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2021.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ricky Skaggs invites family bluegrass group The Isaacs to become Grand Ole Opry members |url=https://www.tennessean.com/videos/entertainment/2021/08/11/ricky-skaggs-invites-family-bluegrass-group-isaacs-become-grand-ole-opry-members/5566500001/ |access-date=8 March 2022 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Opry in the News: The Isaacs Inducted as Newest Members |url=https://www.opry.com/story/opry-in-the-news-the-isaacs-inducted-as-newest-members/ |website=Grand Ole Opry |access-date=8 March 2022 |language=en}}</ref>

'''Spirit Family Reunion''' is a band from [[Brooklyn]], New York influenced by traditional American music such as country, folk and gospel. Founded in 2009 by core members Nick Panken (vocals, acoustic guitar), Maggie Carson (five string banjo, vocal), and Stephen Weinheimer (washboard, bass drum, tambourine, vocals), and featuring a rotating cast of musicians such as Ken Woodward (bass, vocals), Or Zubalsky (drums), Noah Block-Harley (fiddle, vocals), Dylan Block-Harley (drums, vocals), [[Twain (musician)|Mat Davidson]] (fiddle, accordion, mandolin, vocals), and Pete Pezzimenti (drums, vocals).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/minkinsmusic/2015/06/put_your_hands_together_for_sp.html|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|work=cleveland.com}}</ref> They have referred to their style as "homegrown American music" and "open-door gospel", and are often compared to [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]] and [[Appalachian music|appalachian]] music.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greene|first1=David|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Music For Church Basements|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/07/29/157532251/spirit-family-reunion-music-for-church-basements|website=NPR Music|publisher=NPR Music|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Minkin|first1=Jay|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|url=http://nodepression.com/live-review/put-your-hands-together-spirit-family-reunion|website=No Depression|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Horowitz|first1=Hal|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Hands Together|url=http://americansongwriter.com/2015/04/spirit-family-reunion-hands-together/|website=American Songwriter|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Michael|title=Brooklyn ‘buskers' Spirit Family Reunion are Bangor-bound|url=http://www.irishnews.com/arts/2016/08/12/news/brooklyn-buskers-spirit-family-reunion-are-bangor-bound-647745/|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref>

== History ==

The band started out as Panken and Weinheimer playing with different people each night at the bar where they worked, and eventually became Spirit Family Reunion.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051136/http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 28, 2017|title=A Beer With Spirit Family Reunion|website=A Beer With the Band|publisher=A Beer With the Band|last1=Mitchell|first1=Kristen|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref> Officially formed in 2010, Spirit Family Reunion has self-produced and self-released two full-length albums, ''No Separation'' (2013) and ''Hands Together'' (2015).<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321121429/http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 21, 2016|website=Spirit Family Reunion|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They have toured with bands such as [[Trampled by Turtles]], [[Levon Helm]], [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]], [[Dr. Dog]], [[The Felice Brothers]], and [[Alabama Shakes]] and performed at the [[Newport Folk Festival]], [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]], [[Celebrate Brooklyn!]], [[FloydFest]], [[Bristol Rhythm & Roots Reunion]], [[Flood City Music Festival]], [[Buckle Up Music Festival|The Buckle Up Music Festival]], [[Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival]], and the [[Americana Music Festival & Conference]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=Hear Spirit Family Reunion Sing Away Blues With 'It Does Not Bother Me'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-spirit-family-reunion-sing-away-blues-with-it-does-not-bother-me-20150129|website=Rolling Stone Country|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They played a [[Tiny Desk Concerts|Tiny Desk Concert]] in 2012 and took part in the [[Bob Dylan in the 80s: Volume One|''Bob Dylan in the 80s'' project]]. They were also featured in [[The Deli Magazine|issue No. 34 of ''The Deli Magazine'']] in 2013.

{{Infobox musical artist
| name              = Super Grit Cowboy Band
| image             = 
| alias             =

| genre             = [[Country rock]], [[southern rock]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]
| years_active      = 1975-present
| label             = Sound Hut, Hoodswamp
| associated_acts   = [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]], [[Orrall & Wright]]
| website           = 
| current_members   = Mark Golladay<br />Dexter Horton<br />Mike Kinzie<br />Clyde Mattocks<br />Carroll Wade
| past_members      = Alan M Hicks<br />Bill Lyerly<br />[[Don Cox (singer)|Don Cox]]<br />Bill Ellis<br />Danny Vinson<br />Cliff Swanhart<br />Jason D. Smith<br />Bill Norton<br />[[Curtis Wright]]
}}
'''Super Grit Cowboy Band''' is an American [[country music]] band formed in [[North Carolina]].<ref name="whitburn">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=411|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> It was founded by Clyde Mattocks, Libby Mattocks, Bill Lyerly, Danny Vinson, Dave Cavanaugh  and Alfred Ward. Active since 1974, the band recorded first with Sound Hut Studios.<ref>[http://www.soundhutstudios.com/Clients.htm Sound Hut - Former Clients]</ref> Beginning with their 1981 album, the band has recorded on its own Hoodswamp label.

==History==
The band formed in 1974, comprising Clyde Mattocks ([[steel guitar]], [[Dobro]], [[banjo]], [[electric guitar]]), Danny Vinson ([[drum kit|drums]]), Mike Kinzie ([[fiddle]], [[saxophone]], [[piano]], [[harmonica]], [[acoustic guitar]]), Bill Ellis ([[bass guitar]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]]) and [[Curtis Wright]] ([[lead guitar]]).<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ASQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Curtis+wright%22+%22super+grit%22&pg=PT45 |title=Super Grit Cowboy Band — "If You Don't Know Me by Now" |date=1 August 1981 |magazine=Billboard |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>

The band recorded their first album in 1977 featuring Bill Lyerly (Bill Lyerly Band).<ref>[http://www.billlyerly.com/index.html Bill Lyerly Official Website]</ref>
Later the band recorded for its own label, Hoodswamp Records, and released three albums on it. In 1981, the band charted for the first time on [[Hot Country Songs]] with "If You Don't Know Me by Now," which reached No.&nbsp;71. Between then and 1983, four more of the band's singles reached the country charts, including its highest-charting, the No.&nbsp;48 "She Is the Woman." ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' gave the band's 1981 album ''If You Can't Hang'' a positive review, praising the instrumentation as well as the [[rock music|rock]] influences.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JiQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Curtis+wright%22+%22super+grit%22&pg=PT84 |title=Top Album Picks |date=4 July 1981 |magazine=Billboard |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>

At one point, [[Don Cox (singer)|Don Cox]] was a member of the band. He later recorded ''All Over Town'' for [[Step One Records]] and charted at No.&nbsp;29 on the country music charts with its title track.<ref>Whitburn, p. 106</ref> Wright later joined [[Vern Gosdin]]'s road band, of which he was a member until 1989. After quitting that band, Wright was a solo artist for Airborne and [[Liberty Records]], charting in the Top 40 with "She's Got a Man on Her Mind" in 1990 and releasing a self-titled album in 1992. He later recorded one album with [[Robert Ellis Orrall]] in the duo [[Orrall & Wright]],<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url=http://allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:kzfwxql5ldhe~T0 |title=Curtis Wright Biography |accessdate=2007-12-28 |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> then joined [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]] from 2000 to 2008. Wright has also written singles for Shenandoah, [[Ronnie Milsap]], [[Daryle Singletary]], and [[Carolina Rain]].

Since 2010, the band has consisted of Mattocks and Kinzie, along with guitarist Mark Golladay, drummer Dexter Horton and bass guitarist Carroll Wade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.supergritband.com/thegrits/ |title=The Grits |work=Super Grit Cowboy Band |accessdate=27 August 2010}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = Tammy Rogers
| image                 = 
| caption            = 
| image_size            = 
| background          = solo_singer
| birth_name          = 
| birth_place         =
| birth_date          = 1966
| origin              = [[Tennessee]], US
| instrument          = Vocals, [[fiddle]], violin, [[viola]], cello, [[mandolin]], guitar, [[banjo]]
| genre               = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[Country music|Country]]
| occupation          = Singer-songwriter, musician
| years_active        = 199x-present
| label               = [[Dead Reckoning Records|Dead Reckoning]]
| associated_acts     = [[Kieran Kane]], [[Buddy Miller]]
| website = {{URL|tammyrogers.com}}
}}
'''Tammy Rogers''' (born 1966) is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter and musician. In addition to releasing three albums on the [[Dead Reckoning Records]] label (which she founded with [[Kieran Kane]]), she is also a founding member of the [[Grammy Award]] winning bluegrass group [[The SteelDrivers]] and works as a studio musician, primarily on [[fiddle]], [[violin]] and [[viola]]. She also wrote "[[A Little Gasoline]]", a single released by [[Terri Clark]] from her album ''[[Fearless (Terri Clark album)|Fearless]]''.

== Early life ==
Although Tammy Rogers was born in Tennessee, she was raised in [[Irving, Texas]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web | last=Ankeny | first=Jason | title=Tammy Rogers biography | url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p119857/biography|pure_url=yes}} | work=[[Allmusic]] | accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref> Tammy was a member of the Texas All-State orchestra for four consecutive years, a feat as of 2023 has not been repeated. A graduate of Nimitz High School 1983 and later [[Belmont University]], she joined [[Patty Loveless]]' backing band after graduation, then moved on to back [[Trisha Yearwood]].<ref name="dead">{{cite web | title=Tammy Rogers | url=http://www.deadreckoners.com/artists/tammy_rogers.html | work=Dead Reckoners | accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref>

== Career ==
In the mid-1990s Rogers began working as a [[session musician]], working with artists such as [[Kieran Kane]] (formerly of [[The O'Kanes]]). Kane and Rogers, along with [[Harry Stinson (musician)|Harry Stinson]] and [[Kevin Welch]], founded [[Dead Reckoning Records]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62580393.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025073352/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62580393.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 25, 2012|title=Music: Kieran Kane/Kevin Welch |date=June 5, 1998|work=Minneapolis Star Tribune|accessdate=2009-04-08}}</ref> Rogers and [[Dean Miller]] co-wrote [[Terri Clark]]'s 2000 single "[[A Little Gasoline]]".<ref name="dead"/>

Rogers has contributed to most of [[Buddy Miller]]'s albums, and she cites him as a favorite artist.<ref name=TR-pokearound-2006>{{cite news|last1=Oakley|first1=Richard|title=A Q&A with the Steeldrivers' Tammy Rogers|url=http://thepokearound.com/2016/11/17/a-qa-with-the-steeldrivers-tammy-rogers/|accessdate=2 April 2017|work=The Pokearound|date=17 November 2006}}</ref>

Her first album, ''In the Red'' (with [[Don Heffington]]), was released in 1995, followed by a self-titled album in 1996 and ''Speed of Love'' in 1999.

In 2008, she helped to found the bluegrass band [[The SteelDrivers]] on fiddle and [[Vocal harmony|harmony vocals]].  The band signed to [[Rounder Records]] and released a self-titled debut in 2008. The album peaked at No.&nbsp;57 on the U.S. [[Billboard magazine|Billboard]] Top Country Albums chart.<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p790113|pure_url=yes}} Billboard], [[Allmusic]]</ref> The group was nominated for a [[Grammy award]] in 2009 for Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals for their song "Blue Side of the Mountain."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1603362/nashville-skyline-a-deserved-grammy-nod-for-steeldrivers.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205200136/http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1603362/nashville-skyline-a-deserved-grammy-nod-for-steeldrivers.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 5, 2009|title=NASHVILLE SKYLINE: A Deserved Grammy Nod for SteelDrivers|last=Flippo|first=Chet|date=22 January 2009|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|accessdate=13 September 2010}}</ref> In 2010, the group received two nominations for its second album, ''Reckless''. The album has been nominated for both [[Best Bluegrass Album]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal|Best Country Performance]] by a Duo or Group with Vocal for the song "Where Rainbows Never Die."<ref>{{cite web |title=Nominees |url=https://www.grammy.com/nominees |website=www.grammy.com |publisher=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=17 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227232900/https://www.grammy.com/nominees |archive-date=December 27, 2010 |language=en |date=2010}}</ref>

== Musical styles and critical reception ==
Rogers' debut album received a four-star review from [[Allmusic]] critic Richard Foss, who said that it showed country and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] influences with "delightful twists".<ref>{{cite web | last=Foss | first=Richard | title=''In the Red'' review | url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r216576|pure_url=yes}} | work=Allmusic | accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref> Her self-titled second album was also met with favorable reviews. ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' critic Norm Rosenfield also described ''Tammy Rogers'' favorably, with his review noting the multiple guest musicians and prominent bluegrass influence.<ref>{{cite web | last=Rosenfield | first=Norm | title=''Tammy Rogers'' review | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2651 | year=1996 | work=[[Country Standard Time]] | accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref> Tony Scherman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the album a B+ rating, saying that Rogers sounded like a "less-ethereal [[Alison Krauss]]".<ref>{{cite magazine | last=Scherman | first=Tony | title=''Tammy Rogers'' review | url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,292981,00.html  | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427123418/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,292981,00.html  | url-status=dead  | archive-date=April 27, 2009  | magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | accessdate=2009-04-08 | date=June 14, 1996}}</ref> ''Country Standard Time'' critic Dan Williams also compared Rogers to Krauss in his review of ''The Speed of Love'', saying that she sounded like Krauss' "less tradition-bound older sister", and that her "achingly sweet soprano" made even the weaker tracks "consistently listenable".<ref>{{cite web | last=Williams | first=Dan | title=''The Speed of Love'' review | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2650 | year=1999 | work=Country Standard Time | accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref>
